content.question: A turbojet aeroplane in straight and level flight is cruising at FL290. For a given mass and CG position, how will the high-speed buffet and low-speed buffet as an IAS vary when the flight is operated at FL330?

options.A: Both the low-speed buffet and high-speed buffet decrease.
options.B: The low-speed buffet decreases and the high-speed buffet increases.
options.C: Both the low-speed buffet and high-speed buffet increase.
options.D: The low-speed buffet increases and the high-speed buffet decreases.

key_points: Before the days of FMS, the buffet boundary was displayed on a chart
The buffet boundary has both low and high speed limits: The low speed buffet boundary describes the IAS at which we find the onset of the pre-stall buffet at a 10% margin above VS
The high speed buffet boundary describes the IAS at which we find the onset of Mach related buffet, normally MMO, but sometimes slightly below that
learning.explanation: Before the days of FMS, the buffet boundary was displayed on a chart. The buffet boundary has both low and high speed limits: The low speed buffet boundary describes the IAS at which we find the onset of the pre-stall buffet at a 10% margin above VS. The high speed buffet boundary describes the IAS at which we find the onset of Mach related buffet, normally MMO, but sometimes slightly below that. At low altitudes, these speeds are far apart, leaving a wide range of operating speeds. Although stalling IAS remains constant at first as altitude increases, it starts to increase at higher altitude. Also, the IAS at which we get Mach buffet will steadily decrease, because TAS increases in the climb and local speed of sound decreases. The two buffet boundaries will move closer toogether and eventually meet at an altitude where no margins exists, the coffin corner or aerodynamic ceiling, i.e. you cannot fly faster or slower because you will either stall or hit MMO. The right-hand limit on the graph shows the maximum indicated airspeed VMO and then at high altitude the maximum Mach number, MMO. The left-hand limit is based on the stall speed, 1.1 VS. Therefore, with increasing altitude, the low-speed buffet will increase and the high-speed buffet will decrease.

content.question: Regarding a piston engine, how will the fuel flow be affected with increasing altitude while maintaining the same power setting?

options.A: Decreasing air temperature over-compensates for the decrease in air density by decreasing the pressure, resulting in a lower fuel flow.
options.B: Due to decreasing air density with altitude, the reduced power output has to be compensated by a higher fuel flow.
options.C: Due to decreasing air density with altitude, less fuel is required for combustion, resulting in a lower fuel flow.
options.D: Decreasing air temperature will compensate for the decrease in air density by decreasing the pressure, leaving the fuel flow unchanged.

key_points: As altitude increases, the air density decreases, which means there is less oxygen available for combustion
Therefore, less fuel is required to maintain a constant power output
So, the fuel flow will decrease, not increase
learning.explanation: As altitude increases, the air density decreases, which means there is less oxygen available for combustion. Therefore, less fuel is required to maintain a constant power output. So, the fuel flow will decrease, not increase. Increasing the fuel flow in an effort to compensate for the decrease in air density would result in an over-rich mixture and potentially cause engine damage. What exactly do they mean by "maintaining the same power setting?". We believe it is referring to the amount of power the pilot is requesting from the engine, not the actual power output of the engine. In order to maintain the same power setting, the pilot will likely have to lean the mixture (decrease the fuel flow) to compensate for the decrease in air density at higher altitude. So, even though the pilot is requesting the same amount of power, the engine will produce less power due to the decrease in air density, and the fuel flow will decrease to match the decrease in oxygen available. Note: We are deciding that "power setting" means constant RPM/MAP for this question. Please let us know if you come across this question in your official exam.

content.question: Which of the jet engine ratings below is not a certified rating?

key_points: Maximum Take-off/Go around Thrust and Maximum Continuous Thrust are the two principal certified thrust ratings and these define the safe limits of operation of the engine
Maximum Take-off/Go around Thrust (TOGA): is the highest amount of thrust an aricraft is allowed to deliver in the first 5 minutes of take-off and flight
It is used when an aircraft is at its heaviest and only a small runway for take-off
learning.explanation: Maximum Take-off/Go around Thrust and Maximum Continuous Thrust are the two principal certified thrust ratings and these define the safe limits of operation of the engine. Maximum Take-off/Go around Thrust (TOGA): is the highest amount of thrust an aricraft is allowed to deliver in the first 5 minutes of take-off and flight. It is used when an aircraft is at its heaviest and only a small runway for take-off. This causes a lot of engine wear, so most of the time aricraft calculate the minimim thrust needed for an efficient take-off, and use that instead. Maximum Continuous Thrust (MCT): is the most thrust an engine can produce over a long period of time. An engine can produce more thrust than the maximum continuous level, but only for a few minutes - Maximum Take-off Thrust.

learning.explanation: Climb performance is a measure of excess thrust which generally increases lift to overcome other forces such as weight and drag. content.question: The Specific Ground Range (SGR) for a jet aeroplane is:

options.A: the air distance that the aircraft would fly per kilogram of fuel.
options.B: the air distance that the aircraft would fly per unit of thrust.
options.C: the ground distance divided by air distance.
options.D: the ground distance that the aircraft would fly per kilogram of fuel.

key_points: SPECIFIC RANGE There are two types of specific range, specific air range (SAR) and specific ground range (SGR)
Specific air range is the distance through the air covered per unit of fuel burnt, while SGR is the ground distance per unit of fuel
The difference is due to wind, in the same way that groundspeed is just true airspeed plus/minus wind
learning.explanation: SPECIFIC RANGE There are two types of specific range, specific air range (SAR) and specific ground range (SGR). Specific air range is the distance through the air covered per unit of fuel burnt, while SGR is the ground distance per unit of fuel. The difference is due to wind, in the same way that groundspeed is just true airspeed plus/minus wind. In the exam, and throughout the notes, consider specific range (SR) to be SAR if not otherwise told. In this question, however, they are asking about SGR (there is a very similar question that asks about SR, assumed to mean SAR, so watch out for that). Typically this is expressed in nautical miles per pound/kg of fuel Specific Ground Range = ground distance (nm) / fuel burnt (kg) Dividing both distance and fuel burnt by time: Specific Ground Range (nm) = GS/Fuel Flow

Which of the following graphs illustrate the effect on total drag when total mass is increased?

key_points: The constituent parts of the total power required curve are the induced power required and the parasite power required, just as the total drag curve is made up of induced drag and parasite drag
As the aircraft mass increases, the induced drag (lift dependent drag) increases, as the angle of attack increases to produce more lift so as to counteract for the increased mass
Thus, the induced power required, which is: INDUCED DRAG x TAS, increases too, whilst the parasite drag and as a consequence the parasite power required remains unchanged
learning.explanation: The constituent parts of the total power required curve are the induced power required and the parasite power required, just as the total drag curve is made up of induced drag and parasite drag. As the aircraft mass increases, the induced drag (lift dependent drag) increases, as the angle of attack increases to produce more lift so as to counteract for the increased mass. Thus, the induced power required, which is: INDUCED DRAG x TAS, increases too, whilst the parasite drag and as a consequence the parasite power required remains unchanged. Therefore, the total power required increases, and so does the VMP (the lowest point of the total power required curve). So, the total power required curve moves up and slightly to the right and the VMP moves to the right.

content.question: If a jet aircraft experiences a temperature drop of 5ºC during flight, what will happen to its range?

options.C: Range stays the same, SFC will increase.
options.D: Range stays the same, SFC will decrease.

key_points: To start with, we can assume that the jet aircraft is flying for best range, and when the temperature decreases, the aircraft continues to fly for best range

The decrease in temperature is good for a jet engine's specific fuel consumption, and cold temperatures and high RPM operation both count to decreasing the engine's specific fuel consumption, which allows it to produce more thrust per kg of fuel burnt

Specific Range = TAS/Fuel Flow and Fuel Flow = SFC x Drag So as the aircraft's SFC has decreased, and the Drag has remained the same (jets cruise at constant Mach numbers and when only the temperature changes, the IAS also remains constant), so Fuel Flow has decreased
learning.explanation: To start with, we can assume that the jet aircraft is flying for best range, and when the temperature decreases, the aircraft continues to fly for best range. The decrease in temperature is good for a jet engine's specific fuel consumption, and cold temperatures and high RPM operation both count to decreasing the engine's specific fuel consumption, which allows it to produce more thrust per kg of fuel burnt. Specific Range = TAS/Fuel Flow and Fuel Flow = SFC x Drag So as the aircraft's SFC has decreased, and the Drag has remained the same (jets cruise at constant Mach numbers and when only the temperature changes, the IAS also remains constant), so Fuel Flow has decreased. Now we can also say that TAS will decrease, as the density has increased. That means that both the top of the Specific Range equation (TAS) has decreased, and the bottom (Fuel Flow) has also decreased. We do not have exact figures, so how can we work out what the overall effect is? We know from the integrated range tables in the flight planning CAP (697) that a decrease in temperature causes a decrease in fuel consumption over the distances involved in the table, meaning the effect on specific fuel consumption must be the greater effect, and cold temperatures increase specific range. Now the question does not mention this, but with this colder temperature, the aircraft (ATC notwithstanding) will have a slightly higher optimum altitude, and at that altitude, will gain even higher efficiencies from this temperature drop if it able to climb to this higher altitude. content.question: The optimum airspeed to achieve the maximum Specific Range (SR) in a propeller aircraft is the minimum...

Propeller Aircraft Endurance Minimum fuel flow for a propeller aircraft occurs when power required is minimum, so the speed to fly for endurance is VMP. VMP is minimum power to maintain straight and level flight, always less than VMD which therefore means that the speed is unstable. Maximum Endurance Speed is the airspeed at which the aircraft burns the least possible amount of fuel, the minimum drag is produced and the minimum thrust is required, thus the maximum airborne time (maximum endurance) is gained
For turbojet aeroplanes, this Maximum Endurance Speed is the VMD
learning.explanation: Endurance is the time that the aircraft can remain airborne. Maximum Endurance Speed is the airspeed at which the aircraft burns the least possible amount of fuel, the minimum drag is produced and the minimum thrust is required, thus the maximum airborne time (maximum endurance) is gained. content.question: Consider a standard atmosphere and NO performance degradation due to increased altitude. During climb through FL260 with a constant CAS of 300 kt the indicated rate of climb is 2 000 feet per minute, and the Mach number is 0.76. You decide to continue the climb and maintain a constant speed of M 0.76. What will happen to the Rate of Climb and TAS?

options.A: Rate of Climb will increase and TAS will increase.
options.B: Rate of Climb will increase and TAS will decrease.
options.C: Rate of Climb will decrease and TAS will increase.
options.D: Rate of Climb will decrease and TAS will decrease.

key_points: M = TAS ÷ LSS If the Mach number is constant at M0
76, it means that the above equation needs to be balanced
If one of the variables is changing (for example TAS), the other one (LSS) needs to change in the same way to equalise the relationship
learning.explanation: M = TAS ÷ LSS If the Mach number is constant at M0.76, it means that the above equation needs to be balanced. If one of the variables is changing (for example TAS), the other one (LSS) needs to change in the same way to equalise the relationship. OAT decreases with increasing altitude. If the OAT decreases, the LSS will decrease as well, since LSS = 38.95 x √ (°K). Therefore, to maintain the balance in the above-mentioned equation, the TAS must decrease. If TAS decreases, the climb gradient and rate of climb increase because kinetic energy is converted into potential energy. Note: The sum of kinetic energy and potential energy may not exceed the total aircraft energy. The total energy is shared between the need for speed and the need for altitude.

content.question: In straight and level flight at a constant IAS and ignoring compressibility effects, changing which of the following would change the amount of induced drag?

key_points: The total drag is the resulting factor if you add induced drag and parasite drag together
Parasite drag is the simple one, that we know instinctively
It is the result of form drag and skin friction drag, and is what a car has to overcome (as well as road friction) when it drives along a flat road
learning.explanation: The total drag is the resulting factor if you add induced drag and parasite drag together. Parasite drag is the simple one, that we know instinctively. It is the result of form drag and skin friction drag, and is what a car has to overcome (as well as road friction) when it drives along a flat road. Parasite increases with the square of the airspeed, so gets very high when aircraft fly fast. Induced drag is more complex. Its full name is "lift-induced drag", and occurs due to our wings re-directing the airflow downwards. The pressure differential (high below, low above) caused by our wing's shape (aerofoil) makes the air want to take a shortcut around the wingtip, which creates sideways movement of air, and creates vortices of air around the wing. To cut an incredibly long explanation short, this energy loss (to create these vortices) is what we know as induced drag, and increases with Coefficient of lift. This means that induced drag is increased when: weight is increased (more weight = more lift required = higher lift coefficient). indicated airspeed, IAS, is decreased (less airflow means we need each particle of air to bend more, so higher lift coefficient - or just look at the lift equation, if speed reduces, something has to increase for the same lift to be made). Anything else causes an increased angle of attack (as angle of attack is directly proportional to coefficient of lift up until the stall). Therefore, given the possible options, the only correct one is "aircraft weight". Note: changing altitude does not affect induced drag in this question as we are flying at a constant IAS, which means that the same amount of air particles are flowing over the wing, no matter the altitude we are at, and compressibility effects are to be ignored.

content.question: On a non-precision approach with the autopilot engaged maintaining track and rate of descent, the wind changes from approximately 30 kt crosswind to 30 kt headwind. What action needs to be taken to maintain the correct vertical profile?

options.A: CAS must be decreased to compensate for the lower groundspeed.
options.B: Rate of descent shall be increased to compensate for the higher groundspeed.
options.C: Flap settings should be increased to increase rate of descent.
options.D: Rate of descent shall be decreased to compensate for the lower groundspeed.

key_points: With a change in the wind on the approach like this, there will be some ballooning effect to deal with if it is being hand-flown, but with the autopilot engaged, the rate of descent will be maintained quite closely, so this is not something that needs to be considered
The next change is that of the groundspeed

On the approach, a constant IAS/CAS is flown, so any increase in headwind decreases the groundspeed, and therefore, the aircraft will have to change it's rate of descent to maintain the same approach angle (usually 3º)
learning.explanation: With a change in the wind on the approach like this, there will be some ballooning effect to deal with if it is being hand-flown, but with the autopilot engaged, the rate of descent will be maintained quite closely, so this is not something that needs to be considered. The next change is that of the groundspeed. On the approach, a constant IAS/CAS is flown, so any increase in headwind decreases the groundspeed, and therefore, the aircraft will have to change it's rate of descent to maintain the same approach angle (usually 3º). If the aircraft did not change rate of descent, it will descend at the same amount of feet per minute, but take longer than expected to reach the Runway, so would get low on profile. The rate of descent on an approach is directly proportional to the groundspeed (for a 3º glidepath, the rate of descent [ft/min] is the GS [kt] x 5), and therefore a reduction in groundspeed requires a reduction in the rate of descent.

content.question: You are descending at a constant TAS and deploy the flaps. What will happen to your ROD (rate of descent) and your descent gradient?

key_points: When we add flaps, we increase our wing's coefficient of lift, and also its coefficient of drag (and sometimes wing area, depending on the flaps)

The increase in drag from flaps is always more than the increase in lift, as a wing has its best lift/drag ratio when clean (no flaps), this is the point we want to fly at when gliding for range, as it gives us the shallowest descent gradient and furthest glide distance

Note that the increase in lift is not actually useful in this question, as it only allows us to fly slower without stalling, but this question mentions that we are at a constant TAS, so that doesn't matter
learning.explanation: When we add flaps, we increase our wing's coefficient of lift, and also its coefficient of drag (and sometimes wing area, depending on the flaps). The increase in drag from flaps is always more than the increase in lift, as a wing has its best lift/drag ratio when clean (no flaps), this is the point we want to fly at when gliding for range, as it gives us the shallowest descent gradient and furthest glide distance. Note that the increase in lift is not actually useful in this question, as it only allows us to fly slower without stalling, but this question mentions that we are at a constant TAS, so that doesn't matter. The increased drag from flaps increases our gradient of descent in accordance with the following formula. Gradient of Descent (%) = [(D - T) / W] x 100 As we are maintaining a constant TAS (True Airspeed), then the Rate of Descent increases also, due to the following formula. ROD (ft/m) = TAS x Gradient of Descent Note: we are not taking into account any wind in these calculations, therefore the gradients of descent are "still air" gradients, but wind would not change the answers at all.

options.B: Take off distance will increase by a small amount because the increase in pressure altitude reduces the effects of the increase in temperature.

key_points: AIR DENSITY As air density decreases (altitude and/or temperature increases), both engine and aerodynamic performance decrease
Aircraft performance depends on air density, which directly affects lift and drag, engine power, and propeller efficiency

Take-off distance: When an aircraft is taking off at a pressure altitude above ISA sea level, it will still get airborne at the same indicated airspeed (IAS) as at sea level, but because of the lower air density the true airspeed (TAS) will be greater
learning.explanation: AIR DENSITY As air density decreases (altitude and/or temperature increases), both engine and aerodynamic performance decrease. Aircraft performance depends on air density, which directly affects lift and drag, engine power, and propeller efficiency. Take-off distance: When an aircraft is taking off at a pressure altitude above ISA sea level, it will still get airborne at the same indicated airspeed (IAS) as at sea level, but because of the lower air density the true airspeed (TAS) will be greater. To achieve this higher speed with the same engine power, a longer take-off run will be needed.

content.question: A jet aeroplane is flying at the speed for maximum range, below the optimum altitude. How does the specific range change when altitude increases? The specific range…

options.A: increases only if there is no wind.

key_points: Optimum Altitude It is defined as being the pressure altitude which provides the greatest specific range or fuel mileage at a given weight and speed
Flying higher or lower than the optimum altitude will decrease the range of the airplane
It is important to understand that the optimum altitude is not fixed
learning.explanation: Optimum Altitude It is defined as being the pressure altitude which provides the greatest specific range or fuel mileage at a given weight and speed. Flying higher or lower than the optimum altitude will decrease the range of the airplane. It is important to understand that the optimum altitude is not fixed. As the weight decreases through fuel burn, the drag curve moves down and left. Therefore, the best range speed, 1.32VMD, falls and the total drag decreases. With decreasing weight, the airplane needs to slow down to maintain the best range speed. As it does so, the Mach number will also decrease meaning that the airplane is not limited by the high Mach number and corresponding high drag. This fact allows the airplane to climb a little. As the airplane climbs, the Mach number will increase again to its previous limiting value and drag will increase back to its previous value. But more importantly the higher altitude has decreased the specific fuel consumption. This means that over time, as the weight decreases with fuel burn, the optimum altitude increases. SPECIFIC RANGE (SR) = TAS ÷ FUEL FLOW Reaching the optimum level, the aircraft specific range increases. As the aircraft mass decreases due to fuel consumption the optimum level will be higher. If the aircraft does not climb to the new optimum altitude the specific range decreases.

ASDA consists of TORA plus the stopway if available. The ASDA is the Accelerate-Stopping Distance available, for use in case of a Rejected Take-Off (RTO). The majority of the statements in this question are quite simple, the ASDA includes the TORA (Take-Off Run Available), and the stopway for the take-off runway, but not the clearway. The other two statements are a little more complex. A starter extension is where a displaced threshold exists, and an aircraft can begin the take-off roll before the threshold of the runway. Therefore, any starter extension is part of the take-off run, and is included in the ASDA. However, the opposite runway stopway (if present) is not automatically considered a starter extension for the take-off runway, so is not included. Note: we have reason to believe that this may show up as a tick box question in the UK CAA exams.

options.B: The NM flown per kg of fuel.

key_points: The overall fuel efficiency of a jet engine is usually expressed in terms of its Specific Fuel Consumption (SFC) and its propulsive and thermal efficiencies
The overall fuel efficiency of a piston engine is measured by its Specific Fuel Consumption (SFC) only
SFC is the mass of fuel required to produce a given amount of power/thrust for a given period of time
learning.explanation: The overall fuel efficiency of a jet engine is usually expressed in terms of its Specific Fuel Consumption (SFC) and its propulsive and thermal efficiencies. The overall fuel efficiency of a piston engine is measured by its Specific Fuel Consumption (SFC) only. SFC is the mass of fuel required to produce a given amount of power/thrust for a given period of time. The Specific Fuel Consumption (SFC) formulae are: For a propeller aircraft: SFC = Fuel Flow / Power. For a jet aircraft: SFC = Fuel Flow / Thrust. So, for a propeller aircraft, Fuel Flow = SFC x Power, which means that for a given SFC the fuel flow is proportional to the power required. Thus, the lower the SFC, the better the efficiency.

For best angle of climb we need maximum excess thrust. If thrust were constant at all airspeeds, then at VMD where drag is minimum, the excess thrust and climb angle would be maximum. For maximum endurance we must fly at the speed at which fuel flow is minimum. Rate of climb is maximum when excess power is maximum. This occurs at approximately VMP. In prop aircraft fuel flow is proportional to power, so minimum fuel flow occurs at the speed at which power required is minimum. This speed is VMP. Rate of climb is equal to excess power divided by aircraft weight.

During this climb, the ‘’Power Required vs. TAS’’ curve will move (1) _____ and the ‘’Power Available vs. TAS’’ curve will move (2) _____.

options.A: (1) down and right; (2) up and right
options.B: (1) up and right; (2) down and right
options.C: (1) down and left; (2) up and left
options.D: (1) up and left; (2) down and left

key_points: Power required is the power needed at any given speed to overcome the particular amount of drag that exists at that speed and Power available is the rate of application of thrust at a given speed

Both powers are given by the formulae: Power available = Thrust x Speed (TAS) Power required = Thrust Required x Speed (TAS) The aircraft flying at constant lift, resulting from constant Indicated Airspeed and angle of attack, will essentially fly at a higher True Airspeed at a higher altitude, because the loss of air density must be compensated for by an increased speed of flight to maintain the required dynamic pressure on the wings
Thus, the power required increases with increasing altitude, moving the Power Required vs
learning.explanation: Power required is the power needed at any given speed to overcome the particular amount of drag that exists at that speed and Power available is the rate of application of thrust at a given speed. Both powers are given by the formulae: Power available = Thrust x Speed (TAS) Power required = Thrust Required x Speed (TAS) The aircraft flying at constant lift, resulting from constant Indicated Airspeed and angle of attack, will essentially fly at a higher True Airspeed at a higher altitude, because the loss of air density must be compensated for by an increased speed of flight to maintain the required dynamic pressure on the wings. Thus, the power required increases with increasing altitude, moving the Power Required vs. TAS up and right along the tangent to the origin. Thrust produced by an engine decreases with altitude, because of the decreasing air density, which does not allow the engine to burn as much fuel. Also, the True Airspeed will increase for a constant Indicated Airspeed, but at a lower rate than the thrust reduces. Thus, the power available will decrease with increasing altitude and the "Power availbale vs. TAS" curve will move down and right.

It is also the speed that has the lowest total drag penalty, VMD = minimum drag speed Therefore, this speed also represents the best lift-drag ratio (best aerodynamic efficiency)
And because minimum aircraft drag requires minimum thrust (i
learning.explanation: Minimum drag speed (VMD) is the speed at which induced and profile drag values are equal. It is also the speed that has the lowest total drag penalty, VMD = minimum drag speed Therefore, this speed also represents the best lift-drag ratio (best aerodynamic efficiency). And because minimum aircraft drag requires minimum thrust (i.e., thrust = drag), and given that thrust is a product of engine power and fuel consumption is a function of engine power used, the aircraft thus has its lowest fuel consumption in terms of fuel used per hour. In this case, to minimise fuel consumption, the pilot should maintain altitude, keep the aircraft clean and reduce the speed to VMD.

content.question: A jet powered aeroplane is flying at its cruising altitude and the outside air temperature increases. What will happen to the Specific Range (SR) and the Specific Fuel Consumption (SFC)?

key_points: To start with, we can assume that the jet aircraft is flying for best range, and when the temperature decreases, the aircraft continues to fly for best range

The increase in temperature is bad for a jet engine's specific fuel consumption, as cold temperatures and high RPM operation are best for decreasing an engine's specific fuel consumption, so warmer air is not as efficient, which means that it burns more fuel per unit of thrust produced

Specific Range = TAS/Fuel Flow and Fuel Flow = SFC x Drag So as the aircraft's SFC has increased, and the Drag has remained the same (jets cruise at constant Mach numbers and when only the temperature changes, the IAS also remains constant), so Fuel Flow has increased
learning.explanation: To start with, we can assume that the jet aircraft is flying for best range, and when the temperature decreases, the aircraft continues to fly for best range. The increase in temperature is bad for a jet engine's specific fuel consumption, as cold temperatures and high RPM operation are best for decreasing an engine's specific fuel consumption, so warmer air is not as efficient, which means that it burns more fuel per unit of thrust produced. Specific Range = TAS/Fuel Flow and Fuel Flow = SFC x Drag So as the aircraft's SFC has increased, and the Drag has remained the same (jets cruise at constant Mach numbers and when only the temperature changes, the IAS also remains constant), so Fuel Flow has increased. Now we can also say that TAS will increase, as the density has decreased. That means that both the top of the Specific Range equation (TAS) has increased, and the bottom (Fuel Flow) has also increased. We do not have exact figures, so how can we work out what the overall effect is? We know from the integrated range tables in the flight planning CAP (697) that an increase in temperature causes a increase in fuel consumption over the distances involved in the table, meaning the effect on specific fuel consumption must be the greater effect, and warmer temperatures decrease specific range. Therefore the correct answer is "SR decreases, SFC increases."

content.question: Compared to a more forward position, a Centre of Gravity close to, but not beyond, the aft limit:

key_points: The total mass of aircraft is said to be act through one point called the center of gravity
The total lift acts through a point called the center of pressure
In straight and level flight these forces are in balance
learning.explanation: The total mass of aircraft is said to be act through one point called the center of gravity. The total lift acts through a point called the center of pressure. In straight and level flight these forces are in balance. Putting the center of gravity forward of the center of pressure means the aircraft tends to have a pitch down attitude. This requires a balancing downforce from the tail plane. With this extra force from the tail plane, lift from the wings must be increased to balance the forces. More lift means more induced drag, which means higher fuel consumption consequently decreasing the maximum range. For an aft CG position, the opposite applies, lower fuel consumption and maximum range increases.

key_points: Thrust: 33 000 lbs x 2 = 66 000 lbs total, 66 000 x 4
4 = 290 400 N Weight: 89 350 kg x 10 = 893 500 N* *we use 10 for acceleration due to gravity in this question, it may sometimes tell you to use 9

Using a standard force diagram for an aircraft in the climb gives the equations: (Thrust - Drag)/Weight = sin(angle of climb) Lift/Weight = cos(angle of climb) The first equation is the one to use, and 7% Notes: The force diagram image uses α (alpha) for the climb angle and we are using γ (gamma), either is fine to use, but α is often used for angle of attack so we avoid it for angle of climb. Assuming "Lift = Weight" is a bit of a stretch, yes, as lift does not equal weight in the climb, but it is what EASA want you to do, so they can give you more complex questions like this without you having to do too much maths. This allows us to use L/D ratio very easily, so works nicely, even if not fully correct. sin(γ) is a good approximation of the gradient for small angles, even though tan is technically the one to use, they are very close in the angles we usually climb at. content.question: Upon first contact with their destination aerodrome, the crew of a jet aeroplane is informed to expect a few holds due to high traffic. What can the crew do to increase their aircraft's maximum endurance?

options.A: Cruise with VMAX RANGE in order to increase the fuel mileage.
options.B: Climb to the optimum altitude in order to increase specific range.
options.C: Cruise with VMD in order to minimise fuel used per unit of time.
options.D: Request a continuous descent in order to reduce the thrust setting.

key_points: The pilot of an aircraft in this scenario knows that they are going to have to wait some time before landing, which usually means entering a holding pattern
In order to maximise the amount of fuel they have left at this point, the crew should slow down and fly the rest of the way at the best endurance speed
As they are only going to end up holding anyway, they might as well save some fuel in the cruise, and have to do less holding patterns later on
learning.explanation: The pilot of an aircraft in this scenario knows that they are going to have to wait some time before landing, which usually means entering a holding pattern. In order to maximise the amount of fuel they have left at this point, the crew should slow down and fly the rest of the way at the best endurance speed. As they are only going to end up holding anyway, they might as well save some fuel in the cruise, and have to do less holding patterns later on. This is assuming that they have already "joined the queue" at their destination airport, which is implied in the question. The best endurance speed in a jet aircraft is the speed at which the engines need to produce the least thrust, as thrust is directly proportional to fuel flow, and we want to make our fuel flow the lowest it can be. The speed of minimum thrust required is the speed of least drag (as thrust directly opposed drag). We called this VMD, for minimum drag speed, and it is the speed that aircraft fly in the holding pattern, and when it is time in the air that is most desirable, rather than distance gone. It occurs at the bottom of the "total drag" curve as shown in the annex above, where the combination of induced and parasite drag equals the lowest value. There is no point climbing up to the optimum altitude at this stage, as it is not an efficient use of fuel to climb just before descent. Also, that option is not correct because we do not care about maximum range now, only maximum endurance.

content.question: An aircraft has two certified landing flaps positions, 25° and 35°. If a pilot chooses 35° instead of 25°, the aircraft will have:

options.A: a reduced landing distance and degraded go around performance.
options.B: an increased landing distance and better go around performance.
options.C: an increased landing distance and degraded go around performance.
options.D: a reduced landing distance and better go around performance.

key_points: EFFECT OF FLAPS ON LANDING/TAKE-OFF RUN AND CLIMB GRADIENT The use of high life devices (Flaps) will have an impact on the take-off and Landing roll and climb gradient
For a given runway length and airplane weight, selecting a greater flap setting will increase the lift coefficient, which reduces the stalling speed
As a consequence, the take-off speeds are reduced (the same lift will be created at smaller air speed due to greater lift coefficient)
learning.explanation: EFFECT OF FLAPS ON LANDING/TAKE-OFF RUN AND CLIMB GRADIENT The use of high life devices (Flaps) will have an impact on the take-off and Landing roll and climb gradient. For a given runway length and airplane weight, selecting a greater flap setting will increase the lift coefficient, which reduces the stalling speed. As a consequence, the take-off speeds are reduced (the same lift will be created at smaller air speed due to greater lift coefficient). This will reduce the take-off run. Flap extension during landings provides several advantages by: producing greater lift and permitting lower landing speed; producing greater drag, permitting a steep descent angle without airspeed increase. => Reducing the length of the landing roll. The down side of the use of flaps is that it generates more parasite drag: We get our best angle of climb and, therefore, our best gradient where there is the biggest gap between the thrust available and thrust required. The parasite drag from the extended flap closes the gap and the climb angle and climb gradient will reduce => go around performance is deteriorated. Hence as soon as we can after take off we accelerate and retract the flap and climb clean.

content.question: While cruising at VMD, the pilots observed that the aircraft's fuel consumption was higher than expected. They decided to reduce speed to VMP. The fuel flow will (1)_____ and the power required will (2)_____.

key_points: Minimum Power Speed (VMP) is the speed at which minimum power is required
For a propeller aircraft, maximum endurance (time aloft) occurs when the minimum power is used to maintain steady level flight
VMP is the minimum power required speed, thereby the speed of minimum fuel flow
learning.explanation: Minimum Power Speed (VMP) is the speed at which minimum power is required. For a propeller aircraft, maximum endurance (time aloft) occurs when the minimum power is used to maintain steady level flight. VMP is the minimum power required speed, thereby the speed of minimum fuel flow. As a result, any speed below or above VMP increases fuel consumption.

content.question: Other factors remaining constant, the effect an increase of altitude, in a standard atmosphere, has on the value of VX and VY in terms of TAS is:

VY best ROC speed
VY is plotted on the Power v TAS curve and VY is where the greatest excess of power available over power required exists

(Note that the power available lines for a jet and prop are different.) VX is normally derived from the excess of thrust over drag but it can be plotted on the power required curve. VX for a jet is where the tangent from the origin just touches the power required curve, this is VMD, which is VX for a jet. VX for a prop is very close to VMP, the bottom of the power required curve. content.question: An Operator is considering Johannesburg international airport as a new cargo destination. The aerodrome is at approximately 5 500 ft above mean sea level, and in summer the temperatures can reach 30°C. What effect should the operator consider these conditions might have on the maximum landing mass compared to standard atmosphere conditions at an aerodrome at mean sea level?

options.A: There is NO effect on landing mass because standard atmosphere conditions are used when calculating the maximum landing mass.
options.B: The maximum landing mass would be lower because the actual landing distances would increase.
options.C: The maximum landing mass would be the higher because the landing distances would decrease.
options.D: Warmer ambient temperatures affect the landing distance but NOT the landing mass.

key_points: Aeroplane performance depends on a number of different variables, some of which cannot be influenced by the operator
These include environmental conditions such as aerodrome pressure and temperature
Air density directly affects aircraft performance in terms of both aerodynamic and engine performance
learning.explanation: Aeroplane performance depends on a number of different variables, some of which cannot be influenced by the operator. These include environmental conditions such as aerodrome pressure and temperature. Air density directly affects aircraft performance in terms of both aerodynamic and engine performance. As the density of the air increases (lower density altitude), aircraft performance increases. Conversely, as air density decreases (higher density altitude), aircraft performance decreases. Higher temperature means lower air density at any given pressure altitude, extending both the take-off run and distance and lowering the performance-limited take-off mass for that day.

content.question: What issues you may experience with the take-off, if you were to pick up a new aircraft from a factory in Europe on a cold day?

options.A: A high V2 giving good aircraft performance.
options.B: A low VR making an engine failure easier to handle.

learning.explanation: VMCG is defined as the minimum speed, whilst on the ground, that directional control can be maintained, using only aerodynamic controls, with one engine inoperative (critical engine on two engine airplanes) and take-off power applied on the other engine(s). content.question: A pilot is flying at the speed for the best rate of climb. He decides to slow down to VMD. What will happen to the climb gradient at VMD?

key_points: VX - Best Angle of Climb Speed The IAS at which the airplane generates the greatest amount of Excess Thrust (Thrust minus Drag) and is therefore capable of its steepest climb gradient, is called VX
For an airplane powered by jet engines, VX is the same IAS as VMD
VX for a propeller airplane is less than VMD and at low altitudes will be in the region of VMP due to the way power is produced by propeller aircraft
learning.explanation: VX - Best Angle of Climb Speed The IAS at which the airplane generates the greatest amount of Excess Thrust (Thrust minus Drag) and is therefore capable of its steepest climb gradient, is called VX. For an airplane powered by jet engines, VX is the same IAS as VMD. VX for a propeller airplane is less than VMD and at low altitudes will be in the region of VMP due to the way power is produced by propeller aircraft. This is also roughly the same speed as maximum endurance due to the minimum drag/power required. VY - Best Rate of Climb Speed The speed to gain more altitude with the least time (Greatest Rate of Climb). This speed is faster than VX as the rate of climb can be improved by speeding up the aircraft. Even though this means higher drag, this drag increase is overwhelmed by the speed increase, which means the aircraft is climbing up a shallower slope, but at a higher speed, so has an overall greater climb rate. It is roughly the same speed as that of maximum range. For a jet, this means it is higher than VMD (usually quoted as 1.32 VMD with maximum range), and for a prop aircraft, this speed should be around VMD. For this question, then, we have to assume that a jet aircraft is being flown, as in a propeller aircraft, VY is effectively the same speed as VMD in most cases, so they could not slow down to VMD If the pilot is flying at VY and slows down to VMD (which is VX), the climb gradient will increase, but the rate of climb will decrease (after the airspeed has stabilised at VX).

content.question: Consider a fixed-pitch propeller aeroplane at take-off. When the aeroplane accelerates during the take-off run phase, the blade angle of attack will (1) _____ and the thrust produced by the propeller will (2) _____.

key_points: Note: This should not really be a Performance question, as it is more closely related to Principles of Flight
Question 812798 is the PoF counterpart, but this question has been identified at least twice in Performance exams, so we have put it in both subjects
The figure shows the changes that take place as the aircraft speed (TAS) increases
learning.explanation: Note: This should not really be a Performance question, as it is more closely related to Principles of Flight. Question 812798 is the PoF counterpart, but this question has been identified at least twice in Performance exams, so we have put it in both subjects. The figure shows the changes that take place as the aircraft speed (TAS) increases. Assuming that propeller RPM and blade pitch angle remains constant, at a low speed the angle of attack will be large, giving a lot of thrust. Alpha will reduce with increasing speed and at about 4 degrees the blade will be operating at its best lift/drag ratio, i.e. the propeller is achieving its highest efficiency. Higher speeds (which can usually only be reached in a dive) will reduce the blade angle of attack to its zero lift value of about minus 4 degrees. At this point, the propeller will be producing zero thrust. The thrust that is produced by the propeller depends on the angle of attack of the blade. The angle of attack of the blade depends in turn on the airspeed and induced airflow through the propeller. At low airspeeds the angle of attack will be large, near the stall, and thrust will be at its maximum. As forward speed increases, the angle of attack decreases and thrust reduces. That means that the maximum thrust produced by a propeller driven aircraft, also occurs at zero forward airspeed and reduces with forward speed. A fixed propeller can only have one optimum combination of forward airspeed and engine RPM and only one optimum propeller efficiency. At all other combinations it operates less efficiently. This effect can be offset to an extent by using a variable pitch propeller, which can change the blade angle, coarsening the blade angle at higher speeds to maintain the optimum angle of attack.

These values, which are intended to be practically achievable, are: 500 fpm for jet aeroplanes, and 100 fpm for propeller aeroplanes The climb limited mass is also known as a WAT limited mass (Weight, Altitude, and Temperature) or MAT limited mass (Mass, Altitude, and Temperature)

learning.explanation: SERVICE CEILING The service ceiling is the altitude at which the rate of climb reduces to a specified (continious) value. These values, which are intended to be practically achievable, are: 500 fpm for jet aeroplanes, and 100 fpm for propeller aeroplanes The climb limited mass is also known as a WAT limited mass (Weight, Altitude, and Temperature) or MAT limited mass (Mass, Altitude, and Temperature). As we understood from the definition above; mass and the dissemination of the weight to the compartments of aircraft directly effects the service ceiling. FACTORS AFFECTING TAKE-OFF DISTANCE REQUIRED The take-off distance required (TODR) varies with aerodrome conditions, aeroplane mass, and aeroplane configuration. AEROPLANE MASS A heavier aeroplane accelerates more slowly and needs to achieve a faster take-off speed. This results in a longer take-off distance required. When the TODR equals the take-off distance available (TODA), the aeroplane is at its field limited take-off mass (FLTOM) for the given flap setting. AERODROME PRESSURE ALTITUDE The higher an aerodrome’s pressure altitude, the longer the TODR. This is because the air is less dense, which affects both the engine thrust and actual speed at rotation. The reduction in air density reduces the engine mass flow and, therefore, thrust, which results in slower acceleration. Second, the reduced air density results in a faster TAS for the same calibrated airspeed VR. TEMPERATURE Hotter temperatures result in lower air density. Again, this reduces the thrust and, therefore, acceleration of the aeroplane and necessitates a faster TAS for the same VR. WIND The head or tailwind component along the runway affects the ground speed of the aeroplane for the same rotate speed, VR, which is a CAS. A reducing headwind or increasing tailwind increases the actual ground speed, which equates to the same VR. Acceleration to a faster actual ground speed results in a longer take-off run and distance.

So, the induced drag increases and, thus, the induced power required increases too. The parasite drag and as a result the parasite power required remain unchanged. Thus, the total power required curve, affected only by the increased induced power required, moves up and slightly right. The power required is: DRAG x AIRSPEED. With increased Lift required, the induced drag increases and as a result the total drag increases, too. Therefore, with increased airspeed and drag, the power required increases, as well.

content.question:
Refer to figure.
Which of the figures shows the change in the total drag graph when density altitude is increased?

key_points: When density altitude increases, the air gets "thinner", meaning that there are less air particles per cubic metre, and therefore less air particles will hit our aircraft and flow over its wings per mile flown
This would decrease lift and drag if we were trying to maintain the same TAS
However, to counteract this effect, we fly our aircraft at a constant IAS/CAS (Indicated Airspeed/Calibrated Airspeed), which is a simple measure of dynamic pressure
learning.explanation: When density altitude increases, the air gets "thinner", meaning that there are less air particles per cubic metre, and therefore less air particles will hit our aircraft and flow over its wings per mile flown. This would decrease lift and drag if we were trying to maintain the same TAS. However, to counteract this effect, we fly our aircraft at a constant IAS/CAS (Indicated Airspeed/Calibrated Airspeed), which is a simple measure of dynamic pressure. This value measures the amount of air particles hitting the aircraft, and their speed. If we fly at a constant IAS, but climb higher in the atmosphere, the lower air density means that we have to fly faster to get the same amount of dynamic pressure, meaning the same amount of air particles over the wing, etc. This is an increase in TAS (True Airspeed) for a constant IAS. IAS directly controls our drag and our lift, as they vary proportionally to dynamic pressure, see the lift or drag equation for the mathematical proof here, it is very easy to spot. D = (1/2 x ρ x V2)x CD x S As dynamic pressure is 1/2 x ρ x V2, which is measured by the IAS, then drag is directly proportional to IAS, coefficient of drag, and surface area. If the graph was for total drag against IAS, then the curve would remain in exactly the same position with increased altitude (ignoring compressibility at very high altitudes). As the X-axis on the graphs is TAS, not IAS, then with an increase in altitude, the drag curve will look the same, but will be shifted to the right, due to the increased TAS for the same IAS at higher altitudes, but as the same forces of drag exist at each point on the curve, the curve will not move up or down. The answer is therefore figure 3, moving to the right.

key_points: FEATHERING In a propeller aircraft, an engine failure not only means the loss of that engine's thrust, and perhaps the slipstream induced lift from its backwash, but also, the propellers are now stopped, causing extra drag, or perhaps windmilling (where the airflow turns the engine) which is even worse for drag

learning.explanation: FEATHERING In a propeller aircraft, an engine failure not only means the loss of that engine's thrust, and perhaps the slipstream induced lift from its backwash, but also, the propellers are now stopped, causing extra drag, or perhaps windmilling (where the airflow turns the engine) which is even worse for drag. This is where feathering the propeller comes in. The blade angle can be sent from its usual pitch setting to around 90º. In other words, the propeller is pointing directly into the airflow, and producing the least amount of drag possible. If the dead engine is not feathered, there will be a noticeable drag penalty for the aircraft, and this may even cause the aircraft to be unable to climb, depending on the power of the live engine and the altitude, etc. Now we are not sure from the wording of this question if maximum continuous power has been set on the live engine, or just enough power to remain level with one engine inoperative, but given the options, it does not matter. Not feathering the dead engine propeller is the only option that would cause increased drag.

content.question: The critical engine of a multi-engined, propeller-driven aeroplane is the one whose failure would result in the most adverse effect on the aeroplane’s...

key_points: CRITICAL ENGINE of a multi-engine, fixed-wing propeller-driven aircraft is defined as the one whose failure would most adversely affect the performance or handling qualities of an aircraft
For a multi-engine airplane, the largest asymmetric thrust moment occurs when an outboard engine fails

That engine failure which most adversely affects the performance is deemed the critical power unit and is used to determine the limiting control speeds that will ensure adequate directional control in such an event
learning.explanation: CRITICAL ENGINE of a multi-engine, fixed-wing propeller-driven aircraft is defined as the one whose failure would most adversely affect the performance or handling qualities of an aircraft. For a multi-engine airplane, the largest asymmetric thrust moment occurs when an outboard engine fails. That engine failure which most adversely affects the performance is deemed the critical power unit and is used to determine the limiting control speeds that will ensure adequate directional control in such an event. For propeller-driven airplanes the direction of propeller rotation determines the critical engine. Viewed from behind, a clockwise rotation dictates that the outboard left engine is critical.

For planning purposes, determine the net distance travelled down to 4 000 ft for a single-engine piston aircraft following an engine failure at 8 000 ft. Given the following data:
TAS: 120 kts
GS: 150 kts
Gross gradient of descent 11%
Gross/net gradient decrement 0.5%
Still air distance (ft) = (Height difference (ft) x 100) / % net gradient
Ground distance = still air distance x (groundspeed / TAS)

key_points: The question asks for the net distance, which means that we can use the net gradient
Air OPS states that, for the purpose of flight planning, the gross glide gradient to reach such places where the aeroplane can safely land, must be increased by 0
learning.explanation: The question asks for the net distance, which means that we can use the net gradient. Air OPS states that, for the purpose of flight planning, the gross glide gradient to reach such places where the aeroplane can safely land, must be increased by 0.5%. Net gradient = Gross Gradient + 0.5% = 11.5% Now let’s calculate the net glide distance: Still Air Distance = (Height Difference (ft) x 100) / Net Gradient (%) Still Air Distance (ft) = (4 000 x 100) / 11.5 = 34 783 ft 34 783 ft/ 6076 = 5.7 NM Ground Distance = Still Air Distance x (GS/TAS) Ground Distance = 5.7 x (150/120) Ground Distance = 7.1 NM

content.question: While performing an obstacle limited take-off, you inadvertently set a lower take-off flap setting (less flap) than the calculated and required. Compared to a take-off at the correct flap setting , the aircraft will pass the departure end of the runway at…

options.A: greater height, as the lower flap setting means that more lift is generated.
options.B: greater height, as the lower flap setting means that a shorter take-off distance is required.
options.C: lower height, as the lower flap setting means that a greater take-off distance is required.
options.D: lower height, as the lower flap setting means that more drag is generated.

key_points: TRAILING EDGE FLAPS Aircraft are fitted with high lift devices to reduce the take-off and landing distances and when low airspeeds are beneficial
This permits operation at greater weights from given runway lengths and enables greater payloads to be carried
Returning the flaps to their neutral position when no longer required, returns the wing to its former aerodynamic characteristics
learning.explanation: TRAILING EDGE FLAPS Aircraft are fitted with high lift devices to reduce the take-off and landing distances and when low airspeeds are beneficial. This permits operation at greater weights from given runway lengths and enables greater payloads to be carried. Returning the flaps to their neutral position when no longer required, returns the wing to its former aerodynamic characteristics. The increase in lift comes mainly from the variation in effective camber that occurs when the flaps are deflected. This alters the lift curve and also produces a higher maximum coefficient of lift. In some instances, the trailing edge flaps may also increase the wing's surface area. Extending the trailing edge flaps alters the pressure distribution around the wing. USE OF TRAILING EDGE FLAPS FOR TAKE-OFF For take-off purposes, the flaps are normally lowered to a position that provides the best lift-drag ratio that can be obtained with the flaps in any position other than fully up. Since the required lift is obtained at a lower airspeed, the take-off run is also reduced. Larger amounts of flap cause a significant increase in drag, which greatly reduces the acceleration and increases the take-off run. The reduced stalling angle of attack and increased drag associated with flaps also reduces the rate and angle of climb. After take-off, a minimum climb gradient is required in the take-off configuration. Climb gradient is reduced by flap, so if climb gradient is limiting, a lesser flap angle may be selected even though it gives a longer take-off distance.

options.C: to a point 1000 ft above a runway onto which a successful emergency landing can be made and there should be no cloud below the minimum safe altitude.
options.D: from an altitude where the rate of climb is at least 300 fpm to a point 1000 ft above a runway, onto which a successful landing can be made.

key_points: According to the Acceptable Means of Compliance (AMC) and Guidance Material (GM) for CAT flights: AMC1 CAT
POL
A
learning.explanation: According to the Acceptable Means of Compliance (AMC) and Guidance Material (GM) for CAT flights: AMC1 CAT. POL. A.320 En-route — Single-engined Aeroplanes - ENGINE FAILURE: CAT. POL. A.320 (a) requires the operator to ensure that in the event of an engine failure, the aeroplane should be capable of reaching a point from which a safe forced landing can be made. Unless otherwise specified by the competent authority, this point should be 1 000 ft above the intended landing area. GM1 CAT. POL. A.320 En-route — Single-engined Aeroplanes - ENGINE FAILURE: (a) In the event of an engine failure, single-engined aeroplanes have to rely on gliding to a point suitable for a safe forced landing. Such a procedure is clearly incompatible with flight above a cloud layer that extends below the relevant minimum safe altitude. (b) The operator should first increase the scheduled engine-inoperative gliding performance data by 0.5% gradient when verifying the en-route clearance of obstacles and the ability to reach a suitable place for a forced landing. content.question: In comparison to both engines operative, the power required for a Performance Class B multi engined aeroplane to maintain level flight with the critical engine inoperative is...

options.A: greater, due to the decrease in total drag.
options.B: greater, due to the increase in total drag.
options.C: doubled, as the aeroplane loses 50% of its performance.
options.D: constant, provided the pilot counteracts the yaw.

key_points: If a twin-engine aircraft loses an engine total thrust is reduced by 50%, but the excess thrust (the thrust, minus aerodynamic drag) is reduced by more than 50% due to additional drag of the dead engine and the compensation of the yaw moment
The drag of the dead engine and propeller depends whether the propeller is windmilling, stopped or feathered
Drag from a windmilling propeller is high
learning.explanation: If a twin-engine aircraft loses an engine total thrust is reduced by 50%, but the excess thrust (the thrust, minus aerodynamic drag) is reduced by more than 50% due to additional drag of the dead engine and the compensation of the yaw moment. The drag of the dead engine and propeller depends whether the propeller is windmilling, stopped or feathered. Drag from a windmilling propeller is high. It is being driven by the relative airflow and is generating both drag and torque. If a propeller is stationary, it is generating drag but no torque. Drag from a stationary propeller is less than from one which is windmilling. A feathered propeller generates the least drag. There is no torque because it is not rotating, and the parasite drag is a minimum because the blades are edge on to the relative airflow.

content.question: What effect will an increase in temperature and pressure altitude have on landing distance?

options.A: Landing distance increases due to reduced air density.
options.B: Landing distance decreases due to reduced air density.
options.C: Landing distance decreases due to increased air density.
options.D: Landing distance increases due to increased air density.

key_points: Landing distance is affected by air density in the following way

The denser the air, the slower the aircraft's TAS will be on final approach (as approaches are flown to a calculated IAS), so therefore the aircraft will only have to stop from a lower speed, reducing the landing distance

As higher temperatures mean lower air density, and higher pressure altitudes also mean lower air density (hot and high), the lower air density will cause the aircraft to require a higher TAS on final approach for the same approach IAS
learning.explanation: Landing distance is affected by air density in the following way. The denser the air, the slower the aircraft's TAS will be on final approach (as approaches are flown to a calculated IAS), so therefore the aircraft will only have to stop from a lower speed, reducing the landing distance. As higher temperatures mean lower air density, and higher pressure altitudes also mean lower air density (hot and high), the lower air density will cause the aircraft to require a higher TAS on final approach for the same approach IAS. This will lead to a longer landing distance required.

content.question:
Consider a multi-engine aeroplane with an MTOW < 5700kg. The aeroplane is flying at 2 000 ft with an engine failed, maintaining maximum power and the minimum control speed (VMC) for this altitude.
If the pilot descends, maintaining the same speed and power setting, the directional control of the aeroplane will be (1) _____, because VMC (2) _____ as altitude decreases.

key_points: VMC is what's known as the minimum control speed
There are 2 different minimum control speeds, VMCA (minimum control speed in the air) and VMCG (minimum control speed on the ground)
If you ever just see VMC, you can assume that it is referring to VMCA
learning.explanation: VMC is what's known as the minimum control speed. There are 2 different minimum control speeds, VMCA (minimum control speed in the air) and VMCG (minimum control speed on the ground). If you ever just see VMC, you can assume that it is referring to VMCA. The concept behind VMCA is that, if an engine fails, there will be a resulting thrust asymmetry, which will be constantly trying to yaw the aircraft away from the live engine. The more thrust the engine is producing, the higher the asymmetry. We cannot accept this yaw, so have to use the rudder to input enough opposite yaw to fly straight (there is still some sideslip, but the heading is remaining the same). The bigger the rudder, or the larger its movement, the easier this is, so we can counteract a larger asymmetry. For a specific aircraft though, the only way to make the rudder more powerful is by flying faster, as this allows higher airflow over the control surface, providing a larger yawing force. Now imagine that an aircraft has an engine failure when flying at low speed. The remaining engine will be producing up to full thrust, with the rudder receiving very little airflow, so it may be unable to keep the aircraft straight. This is which we have a "minimum control speed", VMC, above which, there should be enough airflow over the rudder to keep the aircraft straight, even with the remaining engine(s) producing their full thrust, and therefore the maximum asymmetry. VMC changes with many factors, mostly to do with the thrust from the engines, the higher the thrust, the larger the asymmetry, meaning that the rudder needs higher airflow to counteract this large yaw, so VMC is higher. In this question, then, the aircraft is descending to a lower altitude. This means that the air will be more dense, and the engines (whether piston or turbine) will produce more power/thrust, therefore larger asymmetry, etc., causing higher VMC. As the aircraft is flying at the "old VMC", but the VMC has increased, the aircraft is now flying below the new VMC. It is a minimum control speed, so below it, the aircraft will not be capable of full directional control, as the rudder does not have enough yawing power available at full extension. Note: this scenario is not really possible, because the pilot would either accelerate due to the extra power, or reduce the power to allow them to remain controllable, but the examiner is not examining this.

content.question: Changing the take-off flap setting from flap 15° to flap 5° will normally result in:

options.A: a shorter take-off distance and an equal climb.
options.B: a longer take-off distance and a better climb.
options.C: a shorter take-off distance and a better climb.
options.D: a better climb and an equal take-off distance.

key_points: TODR: Take-off distance required The above graph shows that the take-off distance required decreases as flaps increase to an optimum value (normally about 15°) and then increases again
Flaps increase the camber and coefficient of lift of the wing
This reduces the take-off speed for a particular aeroplane mass and the distance needed to accelerate to that slower speed
learning.explanation: TODR: Take-off distance required The above graph shows that the take-off distance required decreases as flaps increase to an optimum value (normally about 15°) and then increases again. Flaps increase the camber and coefficient of lift of the wing. This reduces the take-off speed for a particular aeroplane mass and the distance needed to accelerate to that slower speed. The flaps, however, also increase parasite drag. At settings greater than the optimum, the increase in drag reduces the acceleration so much that it takes a longer distance to reach the slower take-off speed.

content.question: For Class B aircraft, the obstacle accountability area is defined as:

options.A: An area just before the LDA within which obstacles are considered for the purpose of landing.
options.B: The area after the TODA within which obstacles must be considered for the purposes of a go around.
options.C: The area beyond the TORA within which obstacles are considered for the purposes of takeoff climb performance.
options.D: The area beyond the TODA within which obstacles are considered for the purposes of takeoff climb performance.

key_points: OBSTACLE ACCOUNTABILITY AREA Obstacles are considered if they lie in an area called the "Obstacle Accountability Area"

For aircraft with a wing span of less than 60m semi width of such area is calculated: 125D+ 60 m + half the wingspan - If the flight path requires a change of track direction between 0 and 15 deg then the area reaches a maximum semi width of 300m; - If the flight path requires a change of track direction above 15 deg then the area reaches a maximum semi width of 600m
For aircraft with a wing span of more than 60m semi width of such area is calculated: 0
learning.explanation: OBSTACLE ACCOUNTABILITY AREA Obstacles are considered if they lie in an area called the "Obstacle Accountability Area". For aircraft with a wing span of less than 60m semi width of such area is calculated: 125D+ 60 m + half the wingspan - If the flight path requires a change of track direction between 0 and 15 deg then the area reaches a maximum semi width of 300m; - If the flight path requires a change of track direction above 15 deg then the area reaches a maximum semi width of 600m. For aircraft with a wing span of more than 60m semi width of such area is calculated: 0.125 D + 90 m. D = Horizontal distance travelled from the end of TODA or TOD.

content.question:
A single-engined piston aeroplane is flying at an altitude of 5 000 ft with a constant headwind component of 25 kt. Given the following information, if the engine fails at this altitude, what should be the expected net glide distance over ground with an elevation of 250 ft?
L/D: 9.1:1
TAS: 140 kt
Assume 1 NM = 6 080 ft
Still Air Distance = (Height difference / Net gradients) x 100
Ground Distance = Still Air Distance x (GS / TAS)

key_points: If an engine fails, the pilot will put the aircraft into a glide at the best glide speed, VMD
The glide gradient may be given as a Lift/Drag ratio at VMD
A L/D ratio of 9
learning.explanation: If an engine fails, the pilot will put the aircraft into a glide at the best glide speed, VMD. The glide gradient may be given as a Lift/Drag ratio at VMD. A L/D ratio of 9.1:1 implies a glide gradient of: 1/9.1 = 0.11 or 11%. According to the Annex IV - Part-CAT - GM1 CAT. POL. A.320: En-route - Single-engined aeroplanes: ENGINE FAILURE: (b) The operator should first increase the scheduled engine-inoperative gliding performance data by 0.5% gradient when verifying the en-route clearance of obstacles and the ability to reach a suitable place for a forced landing. Thus, the en-route glide gradients will be steeper than the gross gradients, by 0.5%. The question asks for the net distance, so we use the net gradient for our calculations. The assumed en-route gradient shall be the gross gradient of descent increased by a gradient of 0.5% (worse than the average gradient), thus giving us a safety margin. So, we use a descent gradient of 11.5%. Using the formulae given, we get: 1. Still air distance = (Height difference x 100) / Net gradient % = [(5 000 ft - 250 ft) x 100] / 11.5 = 41 304 ft or 41 304 ft/6 076 = 6.8 NM. 2. Ground distance = Still air distance x (GS/TAS) = 6.8 NM x (140 kt - 25 kt) / 140 kt = 5.59 NM. (Closest answer is 5.6 NM)

content.question: How does an approach and landing with full flaps compare to one with zero flaps? The full flap approach and landing will have a...

options.A: slower approach speed and shorter ground roll distance.
options.B: slower approach speed and larger ground roll distance.
options.C: faster approach speed and shorter ground roll distance.
options.D: faster approach speed and larger ground roll distance.

key_points: EFFECT OF FLAPS ON LANDING/TAKE-OFF RUN AND CLIMB GRADIENT The use of high life devices (Flaps) will have an impact on the take-off and Landing roll and climb gradient
For a given runway length and airplane weight, selecting a greater flap setting will increase the lift coefficient, which reduces the stalling speed
As a consequence, the take-off speeds are reduced (the same lift will be created at smaller air speed due to greater lift coefficient)
learning.explanation: EFFECT OF FLAPS ON LANDING/TAKE-OFF RUN AND CLIMB GRADIENT The use of high life devices (Flaps) will have an impact on the take-off and Landing roll and climb gradient. For a given runway length and airplane weight, selecting a greater flap setting will increase the lift coefficient, which reduces the stalling speed. As a consequence, the take-off speeds are reduced (the same lift will be created at smaller air speed due to greater lift coefficient). This will reduce the take-off run. Flap extension during landings provides several advantages by: producing greater lift and permitting lower landing speed; producing greater drag, permitting a steep descent angle without airspeed increase. => Reducing the length of the landing roll. The down side of the use of flaps is that it generates more parasite drag: We get our best angle of climb and, therefore, our best gradient where there is the biggest gap between the thrust available and thrust required. The parasite drag from the extended flap closes the gap and the climb angle and climb gradient will reduce => go around performance is deteriorated. Hence as soon as we can after take off we accelerate and retract the flap and climb clean.

content.question: Which of the following is correct concerning fuel consumption change at altitude of a propeller driven aeroplane?

key_points: Minimum Power Speed (VMP) is the speed at which minimum power is required
For a propeller aircraft, maximum endurance (time aloft) occurs when the minimum power is used to maintain steady level flight
VMP is the minimum power required speed, thereby the speed of minimum fuel flow
learning.explanation: Minimum Power Speed (VMP) is the speed at which minimum power is required. For a propeller aircraft, maximum endurance (time aloft) occurs when the minimum power is used to maintain steady level flight. VMP is the minimum power required speed, thereby the speed of minimum fuel flow. As a result, any speed below or above VMP increases fuel consumption.

content.question:
Refer to figure.
Given the following information, calculate the obstacle clearance for a departure on runway track from RWY 27 in a class B SEP aircraft:
Climb Gradient: 4.5%
TAS: 115 kt
Wind: 230°/14 kt
Height Difference = ((GD x climb gradient) / 100) x (TAS/GS)
1 NM = 6 080 ft

key_points: Note: The question did not mention whether the climb gradient of 4
5% is in still air, or after the wind has been applied

They have given us a height difference formula, though, which includes a correction for TAS being different from groundspeed, and therefore a wind correction will apply itself automatically in that formula, so we can assume the 4
learning.explanation: Note: The question did not mention whether the climb gradient of 4.5% is in still air, or after the wind has been applied. They have given us a height difference formula, though, which includes a correction for TAS being different from groundspeed, and therefore a wind correction will apply itself automatically in that formula, so we can assume the 4.5% is in still air, which is also what you would usually get from using a climb gradient graph or calculation. The height difference formula that they have given us is a lovely addition to this question, and makes it a lot more simple. Calculating the head/tailwind requires us to use trigonometry, or one of the wind component charts like in the CAP. The headwind (in this case) is the windspeed* multiplied by cosine of the angle difference from runway heading, so as our wind is 230º and runway is 27 (270º), the difference is 40º, meaning that the headwind component is 14 x cos(40º) = 10.7 knots. *Note that the full windspeed is used, as we are trying to make an actual height calculation here, not a legal minimum height as we would do in MEP and class A aircraft. SEP aircraft have no obstacle clearance requirements, so there are no such "50% of headwind, 150% of tailwind" rules to apply. This means that the groundspeed is 115 - 10.7 = 104.3 kts. The ground distance off the figure before the obstacle (control tower) is 3 NM, so 3 x 6080 = 18 240 ft Using the formula then, the height difference is ((18240 x 4.5)/ 100) x (115/104.3) = 905 ft This is the height difference, and is added to the 50 ft screen height which is assumed to be gained at the end of the runway, so the total altitude upon reaching the obstacle is 955 ft. Minus the obstacle height of 200 ft, this means that the obstacle clearance is 755 ft, closest answer 753 ft.

content.question: Consider a climb with a piston engine aeroplane. What will happen to the fuel flow if the pilot maintains the same power setting?

options.A: The temperature decreases and thereby compensates for the decreasing air density which is caused by the decreasing pressure. Therefore the fuel flow remains the same.
options.B: The temperature decreases and thereby over-compensates for the decreasing air density which is caused by the decreasing pressure. This results in a decreasing fuel flow.
options.C: With increasing altitude air density decreases and the power output of the engine decreases. This has to be compensated for by an increased fuel flow.
options.D: With increasing altitude air density decreases, therefore less fuel is required for combustion, so the fuel flow decreases.

key_points: As altitude increases, the air density decreases, which means there is less oxygen available for combustion
Therefore, less fuel is required to maintain a constant power output
So, the fuel flow will decrease, not increase
learning.explanation: As altitude increases, the air density decreases, which means there is less oxygen available for combustion. Therefore, less fuel is required to maintain a constant power output. So, the fuel flow will decrease, not increase. Increasing the fuel flow in an effort to compensate for the decrease in air density would result in an over-rich mixture and potentially cause engine damage. What exactly do they mean by "maintaining the same power setting?". We believe it is referring to the amount of power the pilot is requesting from the engine, not the actual power output of the engine. In order to maintain the same power setting, the pilot will likely have to lean the mixture (decrease the fuel flow) to compensate for the decrease in air density at higher altitude. So, even though the pilot is requesting the same amount of power, the engine will produce less power due to the decrease in air density, and the fuel flow will decrease to match the decrease in oxygen available. Note: We are deciding that "power setting" means constant RPM/MAP for this question. Please let us know if you come across this question in your official exam.

content.question:
A high tension cable is located 1 NM from the DER (departure end of runway). Calculate the obstacle clearance for a class B single engine piston aircraft with the following conditions.
Climb Gradient: 5%
TAS: 133 kt
Tailwind Component: 10 kt
Cable Height: 104 ft

However, it is good airmanship to calculate obstacle clearance like this
