content.question: A Performance Class B, multi engined aeroplane is used for Commercial Air Transport. The Take-Off Distance calculations must take into account...

options.B: at most only 50% of the reported Tailwind Component.
options.C: at least 150% of the reported Tailwind Component.

key_points: Wind effect on the Take-Off distance Headwinds will reduce the ground speed at the required take-off airspeed and reduce the take-off distance and it is this reason why pilots always aim to take off into wind
A tailwind does the opposite to a headwind
Tailwinds will increase the ground speed and increase the take-off distance
learning.explanation: Wind effect on the Take-Off distance Headwinds will reduce the ground speed at the required take-off airspeed and reduce the take-off distance and it is this reason why pilots always aim to take off into wind. A tailwind does the opposite to a headwind. Tailwinds will increase the ground speed and increase the take-off distance. The Regulations for all classes of aircraft require that in calculating the take-off distance, no more than 50% of the headwind component is assumed and no less than 150% of a tailwind component is assumed. This is to allow for variations in the reported winds during take-off. CS 23.1587 Performance information Unless otherwise presented, performance information must be provided over the altitude and temperature ranges required by CS 23.45(b). (a) For all aeroplanes, the following information must be furnished: (1) The stalling speeds VSO, and VS1 with the landing gear and wing flaps retracted, determined at maximum weight under CS 23.49 and the effect on these stalling speeds of angles of bank up to 60°; (2) The steady rate and gradient of climb with all engines operating, determined under CS 23.69(a); (3) The landing distance, determined under CS 23.75 for each aerodrome altitude and standard temperature and the type of surface for which it is valid; (4) The effect on landing distance of operation on other than smooth hard surfaces, when dry, determined under CS 23.45(g); and (5) The effect on landing distance of runway slope and 50% of the headwind component and 150% of the tailwind component.

content.question: The pilot of an aircraft has calculated a 4000 m service ceiling, based on the forecast general conditions for the flight and a take-off mass of 3250 kg. If the take-off mass is 3000 kg, the service ceiling will be:

options.A: only a new performance analysis will determine if the service ceiling is higher or lower than 4000 m.

key_points: Considering question; there is no limitation ( Planned take off mass is lower than actual take of mass )for gaining more altitude above service ceiling
Absolute ceiling: is the altitude at which the rate of climb theoretically is zero
Service ceiling: the altitude where the rate of climb reduces to 100 ft/min
learning.explanation: Considering question; there is no limitation ( Planned take off mass is lower than actual take of mass )for gaining more altitude above service ceiling. Absolute ceiling: is the altitude at which the rate of climb theoretically is zero. Service ceiling: the altitude where the rate of climb reduces to 100 ft/min. Aerodynamic ceiling: is the altitude at which the speeds for low speed buffet and for high speed buffet are the same.

content.question:
Refer to figure or to CAP 698 figure 3.1.
Given the following information, calculate the Take-off Distance Required (TODR) for a multi-engine piston aircraft take-off, and determine whether the TODR is within the legal limits for a CAT flight from this departure aerodrome.
Mass: 4 700 lbs
Pressure Altitude: 6 000 ft
Temperature: ISA
Runway slope: 2.5% upslope
Runway condition: wet grass
Tailwind component: 2 kt
TORA: 5 000 ft
TODA: 6 000 ft
ASDA: 5 400 ft

options.A: TODR = 3 750 ft, which is within limits.
options.B: TODR = 4 020 ft, which is within limits.
options.C: TODR = 3 680 ft, which is outside limits.
options.D: TODR = 4 650 ft, which is outside limits.

key_points: The Figure 3

1 is used to determine the take-off run (ground roll) and take-off distance applying the following method: Enter where the pressure altitude of 6 000 ft intercepts the ISA TEMP line, and travel horizontally right to the weight reference line
Proceed down the weight reference lines for a single small box to the weight of 4 700 lb
learning.explanation: The Figure 3.1 is used to determine the take-off run (ground roll) and take-off distance applying the following method: Enter where the pressure altitude of 6 000 ft intercepts the ISA TEMP line, and travel horizontally right to the weight reference line. Proceed down the weight reference lines for a single small box to the weight of 4 700 lb. Continue horizontally right to the wind component reference line and move parallel with the grid lines to the wind component 2 kt tailwind. Continue horizontally from the wind component to the ground roll reference line. For the take-off distance continue from the ground roll reference line parallel with the grid lines to read 2 550 ft. This must be factorised for the runway slope, surface and condition: The factorisation for runway upslope is 5% for each 1% slope, so 2.5% slope is a 12.5% correction (multiplier of 1.125) The factorisation for runway surface and condition are combined for an MEP, and is a multiplier of 1.3 for wet grass. The TODR is therefore 2 550 x 1.3 x 1.125 = 3 730 ft, closest answer 3 750 ft. To determine if this is within legal limits from this aerodrome then, we need to compare this TODR figure to a factored version of TORA, TODA and ASDA separately, as per the following requirement. Field Length Requirements When a stopway and/or clearway is available the take-off distance required must: i) not exceed TORA ii) when multiplied by 1.3, not exceed ASDA iii) when multiplied by 1.15, not exceed TODA Consequently, we will have the following distances: i) TORA = 5 000 ft ii) ASDA = 5 400 ft / 1.3 = 4153.8 ft iii) TODA = 6 000 ft / 1.15 = 5217.4 ft Choose the most limiting: 4153.8 ft The TODR is lower than 4153.8 ft, so the take-off performance is within limits.

content.question:
Refer to figure or CAP file 4.1.
During an approach and landing on Rwy 07, the controller informs the pilot that the weather has changed significantly according to the last report and the wind is now 220°(M)/25 kt. Considering that the Rwy 07/25 is fully operational and available, which of the following options provides the greatest performance safety margin?

options.A: There is a tailwind of approximately 22 kt on Rwy 07; the pilot should request landing on runway 25 instead.
options.B: Rwy 07 only has a tailwind of 7 kt and a normal approach and landing on Rwy 07 should continue.
options.C: The 22 kt headwind on Rwy 07 means the pilot should continue the approach and land on Rwy 07.
options.D: There is a headwind of 12 kt on Rwy 25 and a request to land on it should be considered.

key_points: Use the graph to determine the headwind and tailwind components on Rwys 07 and 25 with the following manner: Draw the angle difference radius between the Rwy 07 magnetic direction and the wind magnetic direction: 220° - 070° = 150°
From the intersection point between the radius and the 25 kt arc move horizontally to the left vertical axis to read the tailwind component 22 kt
Draw the angle difference radius between the Rwy 25 magnetic direction and the wind magnetic direction: 250° - 220°= 030°
learning.explanation: Use the graph to determine the headwind and tailwind components on Rwys 07 and 25 with the following manner: Draw the angle difference radius between the Rwy 07 magnetic direction and the wind magnetic direction: 220° - 070° = 150°. From the intersection point between the radius and the 25 kt arc move horizontally to the left vertical axis to read the tailwind component 22 kt. Draw the angle difference radius between the Rwy 25 magnetic direction and the wind magnetic direction: 250° - 220°= 030°. From the intersection point between the radius and the 25 kt arc move horizontally to the left vertical axis to read the headwind component 22 kt. From each intersection point between the radius and the 25 kt arc move vertically down to the bottom axis to read the crosswind component. For both runways it is 13 kt approximately. The greatest performance safety margin is provided when taking-off or landing on a runway which experiences a headwind component instead of a tailwind. Thus, the pilot should request landing on Rwy 25, instead of 07, because of the tailwind of approximately 22 kt on Rwy 07, after the wind direction change according to the last report. NOTE: The runway designators show the magnetic direction of the runway in two digits to the nearest one tenth of magnetic azimuth.

content.question:
Calculate the minimum required TODA for a multi-engine piston aeroplane used for commercial air transport, given the following information:
De-factored take-off distance required: 3700 ft
Runway slope: 2.5% upslope
Runway surface: Paved
Runway condition: Wet
Aerodrome field lengths: Unbalanced
If the runway surface is other than level, dry and paved, the factors below must be used when determining the take-off distance:
Take-off distance should be increased by 5% for each 1% upslope. No factorisation is permitted for downslope.
Grass (On firm soil), dry: factor 1.2
Grass (On firm soil), wet: 1.3
Paved, wet: 1.0

key_points: Take-off performance factors for performance class B aircraft: CAP 698 – Take-Off Field Length Requirements a) When no stop way or clearway is available the take-off distance when multiplied by 1
25 must not exceed TORA
b) When a stopway and/or clearway is available the take-off distance must: not exceed TORA when multiplied by 1
learning.explanation: Take-off performance factors for performance class B aircraft: CAP 698 – Take-Off Field Length Requirements a) When no stop way or clearway is available the take-off distance when multiplied by 1.25 must not exceed TORA. b) When a stopway and/or clearway is available the take-off distance must: not exceed TORA when multiplied by 1.3, not exceed ASDA when multiplied by 1.15 not exceed TODA c) If the runway surface is other than dry and paved the following factors must be used when determining the take-off distance in a) or b) above: Surface type Condition Factor Grass (on firm soil) up to 20 cm. Long Dry x 1.2 Wet x 1.3 Paved Wet x 1.0 d) Take-off distance should be increased by 5% for each 1% upslope. No factorisation is permitted for downslope. Therefore, for this question, start with the de-factored take-off distance required, 3700 ft. This must be factored for the 2.5% upslope and the paved, wet runway. The paved, wet runway is a simple 1.0 factor, so there is no change. For the 2.5% upslope, multiply 2.5 by 5 to get 12.5% factorisation. This means we must multiply 3700 x 1.125 = 4162.5 ft. Then, as we are calculating minimum required TODA and the field lengths are unbalanced, we must multiply this figure by 1.15. Minimum TODA required 4162.5 x 1.15 = 4787 ft To put this into context, the minimum required distances available are as follows, TORA = 4162 ft, TODA = 4787 ft, ASDA = 5411 ft. If any distances of the real runway are shorter than these, then it cannot be used.

content.question:
Refer to figure or CAP files 3.9.
Calculate the stall speed for a multi-engine piston Performance Class B aircraft with a mass of 3450 lb on landing.

key_points: The speed across the threshold is described as VREF (reference landing speed), but for Class B aircraft also in some manufacturer's graphs as the "barrier speed"
From the Figure 3
9, the barrier speed can be extracted as: Enter with mass of 3450 lb
learning.explanation: The speed across the threshold is described as VREF (reference landing speed), but for Class B aircraft also in some manufacturer's graphs as the "barrier speed". From the Figure 3.9, the barrier speed can be extracted as: Enter with mass of 3450 lb. Move vertically upwards and read the barrier speed of 80 kt. According to CS 23.73, the barrier speed for a Class B reciprocating engine-powered aeroplane must not be less than the higher of: VMC with take-off flap configuration, or 1.3 VS0 (Stall speed or minimum flight speed in landing configuration). Thus, the stall speed in the landing configuration (VS0) is: barrier speed / 1.3 = 80 kt / 1.3 = 61.5 kt. Closest available answer: 61 kt.

content.question:
You are the pilot of an airline whose fleet is composed of only single-engine aircraft. For flight planning purposes and considering the following data, what distance should you use in the appropriate landing distance graph to get the maximum permissible landing mass?
Landing distance available: 3150 ft
Runway surface: Paved
Runway condition: Wet
Runway slope: 1.4% downslope

key_points: Refer to CAP 698 - Section 2 Data for Single-Engine Piston Aeroplane (SEP1) 5
2 - Landing Requirements - Field Length Requirements a) The landing distance, from a screen height of 50 ft, must not exceed 70% of the landing distance available, i
e
learning.explanation: Refer to CAP 698 - Section 2 Data for Single-Engine Piston Aeroplane (SEP1) 5.2 - Landing Requirements - Field Length Requirements a) The landing distance, from a screen height of 50 ft, must not exceed 70% of the landing distance available, i.e. a factor of 1.43. b) If the landing surface is grass up to 20 cm long on firm soil, the landing distance should be multiplied by a factor of 1.15. c) If the METAR or TAF or combination of both indicate that the runway may be wet at the estimated time of arrival, the landing distance should be multiplied by a factor of 1.15. d) The landing distance should be increased by 5% for each 1% downslope. No allowance is permitted for upslope. e) The despatch rules for scheduled (planned) landing calculations are in JAR - OPS 1.550 (c). In this exercise, we should start with the given Landing Distance Available (LDA) and divide by each factor to obtain the defactored landing distance. The factors we will be using are: - 1.43 for the 70% LDA - 1.15 for the 15% runway wet - 1.07 for the 1.4% downslope (5 x 1.4 = 7%) Therefore, the defactored landing distance will be: 3150 ÷ 1.43 ÷ 1.15 ÷ 1.07 = 1790 ft Note: All the factors are cumulative and can be applied in any order.

content.question:
Refer to figure or to CAP 698 figure 2.2.
Given the following information, calculate the field length limited take-off mass (FLLTOM) for a performance class B aircraft operating under CAT.
TODA: 2 150 ft
(TORA = TODA = ASDA)
Runway surface: paved (wet)
Slope: 2% down

key_points: The question tells us that TORA = TODA = ASDA, which means that the runway is a balanced field
This length must be factorised for regulatory safety margin, and then factored for the surface, condition and slope (if required)
Only then can the graph be used to calculate the field length limited take-off mass (FLLTOM)

This length must be factorised for regulatory safety margin, and then factored for the surface, condition and slope (if required). content.question:
A commercial air transport flight is to be conducted in a single-engined piston aircraft. At the most critical point during the flight, the distance to be travelled to a safe landing place is 10 NM. Given the following information, what is the lowest altitude the aircraft should fly over this critical point?
Terrain elevation: 0 ft
Gross glide gradient: 10.2%
TAS: 110 kt
Expected tailwind component: 10 kt
1 NM = 6080 ft

key_points: EASA Part CAT
POL
A
learning.explanation: EASA Part CAT. POL. A.320 En-route – single-engined aeroplanes (a) In the meteorological conditions expected for the flight, and in the event of engine failure, the aeroplane shall be capable of reaching a place at which a safe forced landing can be made, unless the operator is approved by the competent authority in accordance with Annex V (Part-SPA), Subpart L — SINGLE-ENGINED TURBINE AEROPLANE OPERATIONS AT NIGHT OR IN IMC (SET-IMC) and makes use of a risk period. (b) For the purposes of point (a), it shall be assumed that, at the point of engine failure: (1) the aeroplane is not flying at an altitude exceeding that at which the rate of climb equals 300 ft per minute, with the engine operating within the maximum continuous power conditions specified; and (2) the en-route gradient is the gross gradient of descent increased by a gradient of 0.5%. Net glide gradient = Gross glide gradient + 0.5% = 10.7% The glide gradient is a still air gradient. We must therefore work out the still air distance with the expected wind conditions. Ground Speed = 110 kt + 10 kt = 120 kt. Ground distance = 10 NM Ground distance = Still Air Distance x (GS / TAS) Still Air Distance = Ground Distance / (GS / TAS) = 10 / (120 / 110) = 9.17 NM (from NM to feet) 9.17 NM x 6080 = 55 753.6 ft (still air distance) Still air distance = (height difference / net gradient) x 100 (Still air distance / 100) x net gradient = height difference Height difference = (55 753.6 / 100) x 10.7 = 5966 ft The terrain is 0 ft, so the minimum altitude for the aircraft to glide clear at the critical point is 5966 ft.

The pilot is on the single-engine fleet of aircraft, so using that value, it is a factorisation of 1.15. This reduces the aircraft performance, so the landing distance available must be divided by 1.15 to give the corresponding "wet paved" runway distance for entry into the performance graphs, making the new value; 3150 / 1.15 = 2739 ft In same way, we can see that the landing performance factored for the downslope. The landing distance increased by 7% for each 1% downslope. For 1.4% downslope → 0.07 x 1.4 = 0.098 → 1.098 factor. So the landing distance available must be divided by 1.098 ⇒ 2739 / 1.098 = 2495 ft The landing distance available can also not be assumed to be fully used by the aircraft on landing. Due to the fact this is a commercial air transport operation, the top paragraph in the annex dictates that only 70% of the LDA can be used for performance calculations, allowing for a safety margin. Therefore, the figure must also be multiplied by 0.7. Therefore, the landing distance to enter into the performance graphs is 2495 ft x 0.7 = 1746 ft

A commercial air transport flight is to be conducted in a single-engined piston aircraft. At the most critical point during the flight, the distance to be travelled to a safe landing place is 10 NM. Given the following information, what is the lowest altitude the aircraft should fly over this critical point?
Terrain elevation: 0 ft
Gross glide gradient: 10%
TAS: 110 kt
Expected tailwind component: 20 kt
1 NM = 6080 ft
Still air distance = (height difference / net gradient) x 100
Ground distance = Still Air Distance x (GS / TAS)

key_points: EASA Part CAT
POL
A
learning.explanation: EASA Part CAT. POL. A.320 En-route – single-engined aeroplanes (a) In the meteorological conditions expected for the flight, and in the event of engine failure, the aeroplane shall be capable of reaching a place at which a safe forced landing can be made, unless the operator is approved by the competent authority in accordance with Annex V (Part-SPA), Subpart L — SINGLE-ENGINED TURBINE AEROPLANE OPERATIONS AT NIGHT OR IN IMC (SET-IMC) and makes use of a risk period. (b) For the purposes of point (a), it shall be assumed that, at the point of engine failure: (1) the aeroplane is not flying at an altitude exceeding that at which the rate of climb equals 300 ft per minute, with the engine operating within the maximum continuous power conditions specified; and (2) the en-route gradient is the gross gradient of descent increased by a gradient of 0,5%. Net glide gradient = Gross glide gradient + 0.5% = 10.5% The glide gradient is a still air gradient. We must therefore work out the still air distance with the expected wind conditions. Ground Speed = 110 kt + 20 kt = 130 kt. Ground distance = 10 NM Ground distance = Still Air Distance x (GS / TAS) Still Air Distance = Ground Distance / (GS / TAS) = 10 / (130 / 110) = 8.46 NM (from NM to feet) 8.46 NM x 6080 = 51436.8 ft (still air distance) Still air distance = (height difference / net gradient) x 100 (Still air distance / 100) x net gradient = height difference Height difference = (51436.8 / 100) x 10.5 = 5400.8 ft The terrain is 0 ft, so the minimum altitude for the aircraft to glide clear at the critical point is 5400 ft.

Ground distance = 10 NM Ground distance = Still Air Distance x (GS / TAS) Still Air Distance = Ground Distance / (GS / TAS) = 10 / (130 / 110) = 8.46 NM (from NM to feet) 8.46 NM x 6080 = 51 436.8 ft (still air distance) Still air distance = (height difference / net gradient) x 100 (Still air distance / 100) x net gradient = height difference Height difference = (51 436.8 / 100) x 10.7 = 5504 ft The terrain is 0 ft, so the minimum altitude for the aircraft to glide clear at the critical point is approximately 5500 ft.

key_points: The gained height of the single-engined piston aeroplane at a distance of 250 m is given by the formula: Height Difference = ((GD x TAS)/GS) x Gradient/100 = (250 m x 60 kt / 50 kt) x 0

learning.explanation: The gained height of the single-engined piston aeroplane at a distance of 250 m is given by the formula: Height Difference = ((GD x TAS)/GS) x Gradient/100 = (250 m x 60 kt / 50 kt) x 0.09 = 27 m. For a single-engined aeroplane, we assume that the required climb gradient will be achieved at the end of TODA (reference zero) at the screen height of 50ft (15 m). Thus, the height difference from the aerodrome elevation will be: 27 m + 15 m = 42 m. Since the obstacle's height is 8 m, then the aircraft will clear the obstacle by: 42 m - 8 m = 34 m. Alternatively: The Rate of Climb is given by the formula: RoC = % Climb gradient x TAS = 9% x 60 kt = 540 ft/min. The ground distance until the obstacle will be covered in: Climb time = GD / GS = (250 m / 1 852 m) / (60 kt - 10 kt) = 0.0027 hr or 0.16 min. With a RoC of 540 ft/min the aircraft will gain: 540 ft/min x 0.16 min = 87 ft or 27 m. For a single-engined aeroplane, we assume that the required climb gradient will be achieved at the end of TODA (reference zero) at the screen height of 50ft (15 m). All obstacles encountered in the accountability area must be cleared by a vertical interval of 50 ft" The "all engine" and "single engine" ROC values can be found using the graph provided: 1650 ft/min and 300 ft/min respectively The exercise can be solved in 2 steps: 1) AEO gradient (with fatorization of 0.77) from 50 ft to cloud base (200 ft): Net gradient = 1 650 x 0.77 = 1 271 ft/min Climb = 200 (cloud base) - 50 ft (screen height) = 150 ft 150 ft ÷ 1 271 ft/min = 7.08 sec (7.08 sec x 110 kt) / 3 600 = 0.216 NM And, consequently, we have 0.5 NM - 0.216 NM = 0.284 NM to go to reach the obstacle. 2) Determine the height gain for a distance of 0.284 NM (0.284 NM x 6076 ft = 1 726 ft): The gradient used will be the OEI gradient = 300 ft/min Time to cover a distance of 1 726 ft with a GS of 110 kt: (1 726 x 3 600) / (110 x 6076) = 9.30 sec At a rate of climb of 300 ft/min, in 9.30 sec, we can climb: 9.30 x 300 / 60 = 46.5 ft The aircraft climbs initially to the cloud base at 200 ft over the threshold elevation, the engine is assumed to fail, then the aircraft climbs an extra 46.5 ft before it is overhead the obstacle. content.question:
In case of landing on a flooded runway and in stormy conditions you will:
1. increase your approach speed,
2. land firmly in order to obtain a firm contact of the wheels with the runway and immediately land your nose gear,
3. decrease your approach speed,
4. use systematically all the lift dumper devices,
5. land as smoothly as possible,
6. apply maximum braking pressure
7. apply brakes up to antiskid activation
The combination regrouping all the correct statements is:

key_points: Heavy rain will form a film of water on an aircraft and increase its weight slightly, maybe as much as 1 - 2% this in itself will increase stall speed
Hence there is a theoretical argument for increasing approach speed in heavy rain
On wet/flooded or slush covered runways the tire may hydroplane which reduces the braking forces between the tire and runway significantly
learning.explanation: Heavy rain will form a film of water on an aircraft and increase its weight slightly, maybe as much as 1 - 2% this in itself will increase stall speed. Hence there is a theoretical argument for increasing approach speed in heavy rain. On wet/flooded or slush covered runways the tire may hydroplane which reduces the braking forces between the tire and runway significantly. Therefore, in such conditions, a positive (firm, not hard) landing is required to break through the layers of water on the runway, thus minimising the risk of aquaplaning. A "greaser of a landing" is most certainly not the answer, because you will only add to the risk of aquaplaning. Furthermore wheel spin-up can be delayed on slippery runways, which affects the proper functioning of the antiskid system and the deployment of ground spoilers. When on the runway, you should apply reverse thrust and lift dumper devices. The lift dumpers are basically ground spoilers that are used to 'dump' lift which, consequently, puts the weight down on the wheels and increases control/braking action.

content.question: When compared to dry conditions, how does a wet or contaminated runway affect the Take-Off Distance and Accelerate Stop Distance? The Take-Off Distance:

options.A: increases, and the Accelerate Stop Distance increases.
options.B: increases, and the Accelerate Stop Distance decreases.
options.C: decreases, and the Accelerate Stop Distance increases.
options.D: decreases, and the Accelerate Stop Distance decreases.

key_points: Even on a smooth runway there will be rolling resistance due to the bearing friction
If the runway is contaminated by snow, slush or standing water, there will be additional drag due to fluid resistance
This drag will increase with speed, until a critical speed is reached, the hydroplaning speed, above which the drag will start to decrease
learning.explanation: Even on a smooth runway there will be rolling resistance due to the bearing friction. If the runway is contaminated by snow, slush or standing water, there will be additional drag due to fluid resistance. This drag will increase with speed, until a critical speed is reached, the hydroplaning speed, above which the drag will start to decrease. Any contamination will increase the drag and hence increase the take-off distance. If the take-off is rejected and braking is required, the coefficient of braking friction is severely reduced on a runway which is wet, icy or contaminated by snow or slush. This means that the brake pressure must be severely reduced to prevent skidding. Thus, the stopping distance is greatly increased.

content.question: Which of the following sets of factors will increase the climb-limited TOM (every factor considered independently)?

options.A: Low flap setting, low PA, low OAT.
options.B: High flap setting, low PA, low OAT.
options.C: Low flap setting, high PA, low OAT.
options.D: Low flap setting, high PA, high OAT.

key_points: The takeoff climb or flight path typically extends from 35 feet above the takeoff surface to 1 500 feet above the surface
However, during a contaminated runway takeoff, the takeoff climb begins at 15 feet instead of 35 feet
The reference zero point is the location on the ground directly below the 35-foot screen
learning.explanation: The takeoff climb or flight path typically extends from 35 feet above the takeoff surface to 1 500 feet above the surface. However, during a contaminated runway takeoff, the takeoff climb begins at 15 feet instead of 35 feet. The reference zero point is the location on the ground directly below the 35-foot screen. The takeoff climb has two main requirements that must be met in the event of an engine failure at VEF, as engine failure must be accounted for in all flight phases for Class A aircraft. Firstly, the aircraft must be able to achieve the minimum climb gradients, and secondly, it must maintain sufficient obstacle clearance. Summary of some factors that can increase the Climb limited take-off mass, which in turn increases the maximum achievable climb gradient. These factors include: Lower flap setting: Extended flaps or gear beyond their normal retraction points cause additional drag, which reduces excess thrust and takeoff climb performance (which reduces climb gradient). Therefore, a lower flap setting positively affects the Climb limited take-off mass. Higher air density: Air density is typically higher at lower airport elevations, resulting in more thrust being available (depending on the engine). Conversely, lower air density results in a lower climb gradient, leading to a lower Climb limited take-off mass. Lower outside air temperature: Lower temperatures increase air density, which improves climb gradient. This concept is similar to the effect of higher air density at lower airport elevations.

key_points: Engine Failure and Drift Down In the case of an engine failure, the remaining thrust is not sufficient to balance the drag force and the cruise speed cannot be maintained
The only solution is to descend to a lower flight altitude, where the remaining engine can provide enough thrust to balance the drag and allow level flight

As the airplane descends into the lower atmosphere where density is greater, the remaining engine can develop more thrust which will equal the drag force, this is the GROSS level-off altitude, but would give no performance margin
learning.explanation: Engine Failure and Drift Down In the case of an engine failure, the remaining thrust is not sufficient to balance the drag force and the cruise speed cannot be maintained. The only solution is to descend to a lower flight altitude, where the remaining engine can provide enough thrust to balance the drag and allow level flight. As the airplane descends into the lower atmosphere where density is greater, the remaining engine can develop more thrust which will equal the drag force, this is the GROSS level-off altitude, but would give no performance margin. So the DRIFT DOWN PROCEDURE is continued to a lower altitude, the NET level-off altitude.

content.question: The flight crew of a medium size commercial jet airliner prepares for landing. A local storm just passed through the aerodrome and the runway is now reported as wet and the wind on the landing runway is a 5 kt tailwind. What is the effect of these new conditions on the actual maximum landing mass compared to the planned for a dry runway in still wind conditions?

options.A: The wind and runway conditions will increase the maximum landing mass by increasing the landing distance.
options.B: The wind and runway surface will NOT affect the maximum landing mass, they only affect the landing distance.
options.C: The wind will decrease the maximum landing mass, but the surface condition will increase the maximum landing mass.
options.D: The wind and runway conditions will decrease the maximum landing mass.

key_points: The Maximum Landing Mass (MLM) is the mass at which a landing is permitted
MLM is either a structural limit not to be exceeded in normal operations, or a performance limit
Wind and runway conditions are two of the main factors that affect the Landing Distance Required (LDR): A headwind will reduce the LDR by reducing the aircraft's groundspeed
learning.explanation: The Maximum Landing Mass (MLM) is the mass at which a landing is permitted. MLM is either a structural limit not to be exceeded in normal operations, or a performance limit. Wind and runway conditions are two of the main factors that affect the Landing Distance Required (LDR): A headwind will reduce the LDR by reducing the aircraft's groundspeed. On the other hand, a tailwind will increase the LDR by increasing the aircraft's groundspeed. The effectiveness of the brakes depends partly on the friction between the tyres and the runway. Water on the runway surface causes poor braking action and may also lead to hydroplaning, both of which increase the LDR. For this question, we assume that the planned LDR is equal to the aerodrome's LDA. Thus, since the LDR cannot be further increased, the new conditions forces the pilot to reduce the Maximum Landing Mass so as to remain within the aircraft's performnce limits.

content.question: What will be the effect on the landing distance for an aircraft A crossing the threshold at 100 ft, instead of 50 ft, (higher than recommended) and another aircraft B crossing the threshold at 50 ft, but 5 kt faster than the correct VREF?

options.A: Both will have a greater Landing Distance, but depending on the braking action can stop within the LDA.
options.B: Aircraft A will have a greater Landing Distance and aircraft B will have the same landing distance.
options.C: The Landing distance will not be affected.
options.D: Aircraft B will have a greater landing distance and aircraft A will have the same landing distance.

key_points: For the final approach and landing, the aim is to have as low a speed as possible to reduce the kinetic energy of the aircraft to get as short a landing distance as possible
To achieve this, we deploy high lift devices such as slats and flaps, which will reduce the stall speed
Once the aircraft is on the ground, the retarding forces are drag, braking and reverse thrust
learning.explanation: For the final approach and landing, the aim is to have as low a speed as possible to reduce the kinetic energy of the aircraft to get as short a landing distance as possible. To achieve this, we deploy high lift devices such as slats and flaps, which will reduce the stall speed. Once the aircraft is on the ground, the retarding forces are drag, braking and reverse thrust. The speed on the approach is not less than the landing reference speed VREF, but is often slightly higher, reducing to VREF at the screen height. The landing begins from the point where the aircraft crosses the threshold, until it comes to a rest and it is split into the landing airborne distance and the landing ground run (roll). Increased VREF, means a significant increase in the kinetic energy given by the following formula, since the speed is squared: Kinetic Energy = ½ M V2. As a consequence, an increased speed and kinetic energy, during the approach and landing phase, will increase the total landing distance, both the airborne distance and the ground run, but depending on the braking action it may stop within the LDA. For instance, a 10% increase in the VREF speed, may result in a 20% increase of the landing distance, assuming a normal flare and touchdown. Also, crossing the threshold higher than recommended (at 100 ft instead of 50 ft) means that the touchdown point will be further than expected, thus increasing the airborne landing distance and as a result increasing the total landing distance, but depending on the braking action it may stop within the LDA. Therefore, either crossing the threshold higher or faster than recommended, the landing distance will increase, but depending on the braking action the aircraft may stop within the LDA.

The range of speeds (margin) between high and low speed buffeting can be decreased by: Higher aircraft weight - As the aircraft mass increases, the low speed buffet increases and the high speed buffet decreases
Higher altitude - As the aircraft climbs higher, the low speed buffet increases and the high speed buffet decreases
learning.explanation: For each mass and altitude, a low and high speed buffet will be identified, which will then limit the range of speeds for the specific mass and altitude. The range of speeds (margin) between high and low speed buffeting can be decreased by: Higher aircraft weight - As the aircraft mass increases, the low speed buffet increases and the high speed buffet decreases. Higher altitude - As the aircraft climbs higher, the low speed buffet increases and the high speed buffet decreases. At the max altitude, there will be one available speed only (coffin corner). Higher load factor - lift increases, so low speed buffet increases and high speed buffet decreases (due to faster airflow over the wing). More forward CG position - lift increases due to elevator downforce, same effect as above. A climb will increase the altitude even further, and will be putting the aircraft even further into "coffin corner". We do not fly aircraft higher than the 1.3 G buffett boundary limit, as 1.3 G is a safe margin in order to conduct up to 40º bank angle turns (though that much bank angle would be silly). We must therefore tell ATC that we are unable to climb due to performance. Note: The question does mention a turn at 45º angle of bank. This would cause a stall at this height (and be illegal to do under IFR anyway), so is ridiculous, but is either wrongly fed back or is badly worded from the examiner, who is trying to get accross that we really cannot afford to climb any further.

content.question: What statement regarding screen height is true, when taking off from a wet runway with a performance class A aeroplane?

options.A: The screen height may be lowered to 15 feet for the calculation of the all engine TOD.
options.B: The screen height may be lowered to 15 feet for the calculation of the one engine inoperative TOD.
options.C: The screen height may be lowered to 15 feet and MTOM may then be higher than on a dry runway of equal length.
options.D: The screen height may only be lowered to 15 feet if taking off from a runway defined as a limited length runway.

key_points: CS 25

113 Take-off distance and takeoff run (a) Take-off distance on a dry runway is the greater of – (1) The horizontal distance along the take-off path from the start of the take-off to the point at which the aeroplane is 11 m (35 ft) above the take-off surface, determined under CS 25

111 for a dry runway; or (2) 115% of the horizontal distance along the take-off path, with all engines operating, from the start of the take-off to the point at which the aeroplane is 11 m (35 ft) above the take-off surface, as determined by a procedure consistent with CS 25
learning.explanation: CS 25.113 Take-off distance and takeoff run (a) Take-off distance on a dry runway is the greater of – (1) The horizontal distance along the take-off path from the start of the take-off to the point at which the aeroplane is 11 m (35 ft) above the take-off surface, determined under CS 25.111 for a dry runway; or (2) 115% of the horizontal distance along the take-off path, with all engines operating, from the start of the take-off to the point at which the aeroplane is 11 m (35 ft) above the take-off surface, as determined by a procedure consistent with CS 25.111. (See AMC 25.113(a)(2), (b)(2) and (c)(2).) (b) Take-off distance on a wet runway is the greater of – (1) The take-off distance on a dry runway determined in accordance with sub-paragraph (a) of this paragraph; or (2) The horizontal distance along the take-off path from the start of the take-off to the point at which the aeroplane is 4,6 m (15 ft) above the take-off surface, achieved in a manner consistent with the achievement of V2 before reaching 11 m (35 ft) above the take-off surface, SUMMARY: Class A - take off dry => 35 ft Class A – take off wet => 15 ft Class B – take off dry/wet => 50 ft Class A – landing dry/wet => 50 ft Class B – landing dry/wet => 50 ft On a wet runway the screen height may be lowered to 15 ft in the calculation of OEI only. The reason for this is that a wet V1 is used, which is lower than a dry V1. Consequently, the stopping chances are improved.

metadata.topic: 25/Applicable Operational Requirements Performance Class A – Theory

content.question: Minimum V2 speed (V2MIN) is limited by both the stall speed (VSR) and minimum control speed (VMC). Which statement is correct?

options.A: At high-density altitudes and high weight, V2MIN is often limited by the speed for minimum control (VMC).
options.B: V2MIN cannot be lower than the highest of 1.05 times VMC and 1.2 times VSR.
options.C: V2MIN is calculated with all engines operating, for flight with one engine inoperative, another safety speed must be used.
options.D: At high-density altitudes and high weight, V2MIN is often limited by the stall reference speed (VSR).

key_points: CS 25

107 Take-off speeds (b) V2MIN, in terms of calibrated airspeed, may not be less than – (1) 1·13 VSR for – (i) Two-engined and three-engined turbo-propeller powered aeroplanes; and (ii) Turbojet powered aeroplanes without provisions for obtaining a significant reduction in the one-engineinoperative power-on stall speed; (2) 1·08 VSR for – (i) Turbo-propeller powered aeroplanes with more than three engines; and (ii) Turbojet powered aeroplanes with provisions for obtaining a significant reduction in the one-engine-inoperative power-on stall speed: and (3) 1·10 times VMC established under CS 25
learning.explanation: CS 25.107 Take-off speeds (b) V2MIN, in terms of calibrated airspeed, may not be less than – (1) 1·13 VSR for – (i) Two-engined and three-engined turbo-propeller powered aeroplanes; and (ii) Turbojet powered aeroplanes without provisions for obtaining a significant reduction in the one-engineinoperative power-on stall speed; (2) 1·08 VSR for – (i) Turbo-propeller powered aeroplanes with more than three engines; and (ii) Turbojet powered aeroplanes with provisions for obtaining a significant reduction in the one-engine-inoperative power-on stall speed: and (3) 1·10 times VMC established under CS 25.149. V2 is the minimum speed that needs to be maintained up to acceleration altitude, in the event of an engine failure after V1. VMC is not affected by weight in straight and level flight, only by the weight of the airplane in a bank. When it is banked, a component of the aircraft weight acts along with the horizontal component of lift to create a more effective sideslip towards the operating engine. So for a given bank, the heavier the airplane, the lower the aircraft’s VMC. The lighter the airplane, the higher the aircraft’s VMC. However, it is affected by density altitude due to the asymmetric engine thrust – which increases with air density (low altitudes, temperatures and humidity). Based on this, VMC limit is likely a controlling factor at low density altitudes and low aircraft weights (where 1.13 VSR limit is lower). Based on this at high density altitudes with high weight V2MIN is likely to be limited by VSR.

options.B: decreases with a headwind due to the greater air resistance.

Reduced density will reduce the thrust and/or power that the engine can generate. Therefore, acceleration will be less, and the maximum TOM decreases. Density affects the TAS for a given IAS. Reduced density will increase the true airspeed for a given indicated airspeed. Getting to a higher TAS, consequently ground speed can lead to a tyre speed limited take-off. The angle of the initial climb. Since there is less thrust and/or power in low density, the angle of climb will reduce. Therefore, getting to the screen height will require a longer horizontal distance, which could not be enough to be clear of obstacles.

content.question: Which statement is correct regarding the endurance for a turbojet aeroplane?

options.A: The endurance increases up to an optimum altitude, then decreases.
options.B: The endurance decreases linearly in a headwind condition.
options.C: The endurance reaches its maximum value at lower altitudes.
options.D: The endurance is increased by a tailwind component.

key_points: For a jet aircraft, it states: Specific Fuel Consumption (SFC) = Fuel Flow / Thrust
Which means that for a given SFC, the fuel flow is proportional to the thrust required
We will get the lowest fuel flow at a particular altitude at the speed for minimum thrust required, which is VMD
learning.explanation: For a jet aircraft, it states: Specific Fuel Consumption (SFC) = Fuel Flow / Thrust. Which means that for a given SFC, the fuel flow is proportional to the thrust required. We will get the lowest fuel flow at a particular altitude at the speed for minimum thrust required, which is VMD. The lowest fuel flow will give us the greatest airborne time, called as maximum endurance. This means that the speed for jet maximum endurance is VMD. The operation at low levels will lead to high values of SFC and therefore by implication to poor values of endurance. Higher altitudes lead to better SFC and as thrust reduces with altitude, SFC is further improved up to an optimum altitude, above which it starts decreasing. The endurance is independent of the wind conditions, since the wind affects only the range.

content.question: Compared with a balanced field with no stopway or clearway, how will the use of a clearway in the take-off calculations affect the field length limited take-off mass (FLLTOM) and the V1?

key_points: CLEARWAY is an area beyond the paved runway, free of obstructions and under the control of the airport authorities

The length of the clearway may be included in the length of the takeoff distance available (and the clearway cannot be more than 50% of the length of the TORA) If TORA = TODA then the mass is limited by TODA because the aircraft must be at 35ft at the end of TODA with an engine out
(The V1 will be established on TODA and ASDA) If we now have a clearway then TODA is increased and the aircraft does not need to be at 35 ft until a later point at the end of TODA
learning.explanation: CLEARWAY is an area beyond the paved runway, free of obstructions and under the control of the airport authorities. The length of the clearway may be included in the length of the takeoff distance available (and the clearway cannot be more than 50% of the length of the TORA) If TORA = TODA then the mass is limited by TODA because the aircraft must be at 35ft at the end of TODA with an engine out. (The V1 will be established on TODA and ASDA) If we now have a clearway then TODA is increased and the aircraft does not need to be at 35 ft until a later point at the end of TODA. The FLLTOM increases. The V1 will be decreased, as the ASDA has remained the same but the weight has increased. This decrease in V1 is acceptable as the aircraft could continue the takeoff with an engine failure at a lower speed, due to the extra length of the clearway allowing it to reach the screen height.

content.question: Which statement below describes a situation where the obstacle-limited take off mass is more restrictive than the climb-limited take off mass?

options.A: There are obstacles close to the end of the runway requiring use of more flaps to reduce the take off distance.
options.B: The headwind component increases and therefore reduces the actual flight path gradient the aeroplane is able to achieve.
options.C: There is a headwind, since the minimum take off climb gradient is unaffected by wind and NO credit can be taken.
options.D: The climb gradient to clear obstacles by the required margin is greater than the minimum take off climb gradient.

key_points: The Climb-Limited TOM requires minimum air gradients at certain phases of the climb
According to CS-25, the second segment of the Net Take-Off Flight Path in Class A, for example, is usually more restrictive and specifies a minimum air climb gradient of 2
4% for a twin-engine aircraft
learning.explanation: The Climb-Limited TOM requires minimum air gradients at certain phases of the climb. According to CS-25, the second segment of the Net Take-Off Flight Path in Class A, for example, is usually more restrictive and specifies a minimum air climb gradient of 2.4% for a twin-engine aircraft. Using this as an example, the Obstacle-Limited TOM will be more restrictive when: The obstacles are higher than the net flight path that you would get with the minimum air gradient of 2.4%. So, a greater climb gradient will be required to clear the obstacles by the required margin in this case. A tailwind makes the minimum climb air gradient a lower climb ground gradient, increasing the chance of the above. Thus, the statement "The climb gradient to clear obstacles by the required margin is greater than the minimum take off climb gradient" can be considered as correct, as it describes a situation where the obstacle-limited take off mass is more limiting than the climb-limited take off mass.

content.question: A pilot preparing for a flight has manually extracted the relevant figures from the aircraft performance charts. They then cross-check these figures with the ones produced by the software on their EFB, and see differences in the results. What might have caused these results to vary from each other?

options.A: The EFB is more accurate as it does not need to interpolate any parameters.
options.B: The tables include an extra safety factor of 1.5.
options.C: The EFB is more accurate and its outputs are more conservative.
options.D: The tables are no longer accurate for aircraft with such a high level of automation.

key_points: Note: This is just a re-worded version of question 329036, and we have had reports of both different wordings being seen in (different) exams recently
Please let us know if you see this in the exam, thank you! Learning Objective 032
learning.explanation: Note: This is just a re-worded version of question 329036, and we have had reports of both different wordings being seen in (different) exams recently. Please let us know if you see this in the exam, thank you! Learning Objective 032.04.01.10.04: Describe why data from an EFB can differ from data derived from RTOM tables or similar. EFB (Electronic Flight Bag) means any portable electronic device for use by the flight crew, which may be a laptop, a tablet or an integrated device within the flight deck. Many EFBs include commercial navigation packages, enabling the whole flight to be planned and executed on the same device. It may also hold charts and AFMs and are widely used in an effort to reduce the amount of paper flying around a cockpit. It is very common to use software on the EFB to make performance calculations, as the software is easier to use, more accurate, and much faster than manually going through the paper charts and tables. The reason the EFB produced performance figures may be slightly different from those from the charts are mostly down to accuracy. When using paper charts and tables, interpolation has to be done, and the charts can sometimes be difficult to follow with high accuracy, so they are then made with slightly conservative figures, and the operator is not able to interpret them to the same accuracy as the EFB software can interpret its own data, creating slight inconsistencies between the two sources.

content.question:
Refer to figure.
The annex above shows takeoff performance data from two separate calculations using a computerised performance tool. Due to some recent reports of windshear, which would require the use of full TOGA thrust as per their SOPs, the pilots prepare the performance data for both a TOGA take-off and a take-off at an assumed (FLEX) temperature of 43°C.
The only difference between the data is the thrust setting, however, one result of the different calculations is that...

options.A: both take-offs have the same ratio between the TOD and the ASD as this will always give an optimum performance on a balanced field runway.
options.B: the TOGA take-off uses the principle of a balanced field take-off, as this gives the best relationship between distances and weight.
options.C: both take-offs use the principle of an unbalanced field take-off since the all-engine, engine-out, and accelerate-stop distances are different.
options.D: the take-off using assumed (FLEX) temperature method is based on having the fastest possible V1 as the ASD uses the entire runway length.

key_points: Note: This question has been reported a few times, but never fully, so there may well be some discrepancies between this and the real exam
We believe this question is quite on the edge, and not only strays quite far from the learning objectives, but also has some questionable wording
We have combined the feedback to make a somewhat answerable question
learning.explanation: Note: This question has been reported a few times, but never fully, so there may well be some discrepancies between this and the real exam. We believe this question is quite on the edge, and not only strays quite far from the learning objectives, but also has some questionable wording. We have combined the feedback to make a somewhat answerable question. Please let us know if you see this in the exam, and anything you can remember from it, thank you! A balanced field is where the TODA (Take-Off Distance Available) is the same as the ASDA (Accelerate-Stop Distance Available). This occurs when a runway has no stopway/clearway, or the stopway and clearway are the same length. This allows the "best use of space" for takeoff performance, in that a balanced runway of 2000 m will allow a higher FLLTOM (Field-Length Limited Take-Off Mass) than an 1800 m runway with a 200 m stopway, for instance. Still 2000m being used, but the stopway on its own is "less useful". This question makes a lot of the windshear scenario here, but that is just a way to ask us how the performance calculation changes based on full thrust versus a reduced thrust take-off. We could dive into the possible reasons for all the different values of TOD, ASD, etc., but without extensive information about the airport, conditions and aircraft, it would all be speculation. Lets consider each option: "both take-offs have the same ratio between the TOD and the ASD as this will always give an optimum performance on a balanced field runway." This is clearly incorrect. If you calculate the ratios of the ASD to the TOD for each case, you will see they are very different. "the TOGA take-off uses the principle of a balanced field take-off, as this gives the best relationship between distances and weight." We believe this is the most correct. If you assume that the ASD and TOD are effectively the same (13 m apart is very little, and this is considered the same, as computer performance tools almost always produce a small split like this), then this is correct, as a balanced field does give the best FLLTOM for a given distance (as mentioned above), and therefore the best safety margin when not at FLLTOM. "both take-offs use the principle of an unbalanced field take-off since the all-engine, engine-out, and accelerate-stop distances are different." Whilst this looks appealing as an answer, the TOGA takeoff has an ASD and TOD that are so close they are effectively the same, and even discounting that, the all-engine TOD would not be expected to align with the engine out TOD/ASD, balanced or unbalanced field, so the explanation in this option is wrong. "the take-off using assumed (FLEX) temperature method is based on having the fastest possible V1 as the ASD uses the entire runway length." The fastest possible V1 is usually not desirable. Also, there will not be a range of V1s available for that takeoff thrust setting, as it is using a reduced thrust, so the performance is therefore right on the limit.

content.question: Under what circumstances can the improved climb performance procedure be used?

options.A: If a stopway is available, the climb limited take-off mass and the climb gradient can be increased by decreasing V1.
options.B: If sufficient excess runway is available, the climb limited take-off mass and the climb gradient can be increased by increasing V2.
options.C: If a clearway is available, the climb limited take-off mass and the climb gradient can be increased by increasing V1.
options.D: If a sufficient excess runway is available, the climb limited take-off mass and the climb gradient can be increased by decreasing V2.

key_points: Increased V2 Take-Off In case of engine failure, the initial climb out speed is V2
However, V2 is not the best climb angle speed and is significantly slower than Vx
The purpose of the improved climb procedure is to achieve an increased V2 in order to be closer to VX, this will in turn improve climb performance
learning.explanation: Increased V2 Take-Off In case of engine failure, the initial climb out speed is V2. However, V2 is not the best climb angle speed and is significantly slower than Vx. The purpose of the improved climb procedure is to achieve an increased V2 in order to be closer to VX, this will in turn improve climb performance. Consequently, the climb limit mass can increase, increasing the performance limited take-off mass. The aircraft is held on the runway for longer during the take-off to build up more speed. However, this is only possible when there is an excess of available field length due to the increased take-off distance required.

content.question: Compared with a take off at an airport with low air density ambient conditions, take off at an airport with high air density ambient conditions will result in…

key_points: V2MIN means minimum take-off safety speed
V2 is defined as the take-off safety speed, the take-off climb speed or the speed at 35 ft
Generally, for Class B aircraft, it is the highest of: VMC VS1 1
learning.explanation: V2MIN means minimum take-off safety speed. V2 is defined as the take-off safety speed, the take-off climb speed or the speed at 35 ft. Generally, for Class B aircraft, it is the highest of: VMC VS1 1.1 VMC for twin engine. And for Class A airctaft it is the highest of: 1.13 VSR 1.10 VMCA VR plus the speed increment before reaching at 35 ft. The effect of combining the above limits is to produce a V2MIN that is often constant at light weights and increases with weight. V2MIN as an airspeed is affected by the air density (pressure altitude and temperature). At high air density airport engine thrust would be higher, therefore in case of engine failure the effect of assymetric thrust is more pronounced. This increase VMCA which would increase V2MIN too. Thus, high air density ambient conditions (low temperature and/or low pressure altitude) will result in an increased V2MIN.

content.question: An aircraft delays its departure by some hours. The OAT significantly increases. What happens to the VMCG?

key_points: In simple words, VMCG is established as being the lowest speed at which rudder effect alone is sufficient to regain and maintain directional control after a sudden engine failure
The major factor that affects VMCG is the difference in engine thrust
VMCG will therefore be lower at higher airport elevations and at a higher OAT, due to the associated lower thrust
learning.explanation: In simple words, VMCG is established as being the lowest speed at which rudder effect alone is sufficient to regain and maintain directional control after a sudden engine failure. The major factor that affects VMCG is the difference in engine thrust. VMCG will therefore be lower at higher airport elevations and at a higher OAT, due to the associated lower thrust. If conditions are hot, high and humid the air is less dense. This reduces thrust and, consequently, when you lose the critical engine on take-off, there is less yawing effect from asymmetric thrust than there would be in denser air.

content.question:
Take-off performance data, for the ambient conditions, show the following limitations with flap 10° selected:
Runway limit: 5 270 kg
Obstacle limit: 4 630 kg
Estimated take-off mass is 5 000 kg.
Considering a take-off with flaps at:

options.A: 20°, the obstacle limit is increased but the runway limit decreases.
options.C: 5°, the obstacle limit is increased but the runway limit decreases.

key_points: Flap has two effects, more flap gives a greater FLLTOM but decreases the CLTOM and OLTOM because of the reduced climb gradient
Less flap reduces the FLLTOM but increases the CLTOM and OLTOM because of the improved climb gradient
Less flaps means better climb gradient after getting airborne due to less drag but increases the ground roll due to less lift
learning.explanation: Flap has two effects, more flap gives a greater FLLTOM but decreases the CLTOM and OLTOM because of the reduced climb gradient. Less flap reduces the FLLTOM but increases the CLTOM and OLTOM because of the improved climb gradient. Less flaps means better climb gradient after getting airborne due to less drag but increases the ground roll due to less lift. Thus better climb gardient increases the obstacle limit and increased ground roll decreases the runway limit. So this fits with the chosen answer; 5 deg increases the obstacle limit and decreases the runway limit. The more flap you've got selected up to the optimum for T/O improves the field length limit. The downside of flap is that it degrades climb performance. So by selecting 5 flap instead of 10 flap the field limit decreases and the climb limit increases.

content.question: Which of the following statements is true for a turbo-engined aircraft descending in standard conditions?

options.A: EAS decreases, TAS and Mach increase.
options.B: IAS remains constant, EAS increases, TAS and Mach decrease.
options.C: EAS remains constant, TAS and Mach increase.
options.D: EAS, TAS and Mach remain constant and IAS increases.

key_points: A usefool tool in determining the changing relationship between EAS, CAS, TAS and Mach in climbs and descents below the tropopause, is the ECTM graphs
CAS can be considered to be identical to IAS

The ECTM graphs are used to determine what happens to the other three speeds when climbing or descending, whilst holding one speed constant, by drawing initially the parameter that is to be held constant as a vertical line and drawing, later, connecting lines to the remaining letters
learning.explanation: A usefool tool in determining the changing relationship between EAS, CAS, TAS and Mach in climbs and descents below the tropopause, is the ECTM graphs. CAS can be considered to be identical to IAS. The ECTM graphs are used to determine what happens to the other three speeds when climbing or descending, whilst holding one speed constant, by drawing initially the parameter that is to be held constant as a vertical line and drawing, later, connecting lines to the remaining letters. The lines are always in the sequence "ECTM", in the standard atmosphere and the speed held constant is drawn vertically. A normal descent profile for a turbo-engined aircraft would be to initially descend at a constant Mach number, then to hold a constant IAS and finally to reduce to 250 kt at 10000 ft to comply with the ATC restrictions. According to the ECTM graph, with constant IAS/CAS descent, EAS increases, TAS and Mach decrease.

You can do this in the comments or by email to info@atplquestions.com, thank you! Learning Objective 032.04.01.01.08: Explain how loss of TORA due to alignment is accounted for. EASA AMC1 CAT. POL. A.205 - Take-off LOSS OF RUNWAY LENGTH DUE TO ALIGNMENT (a) The length of the runway that is declared for the calculation of take-off distance available (TODA), accelerate-stop distance available (ASDA) and take-off run available (TORA) does not account for line-up of the aeroplane in the direction of take-off on the runway in use. This alignment distance depends on the aeroplane geometry and access possibility to the runway in use. Accountability is usually required for a 90°-taxiway entry to the runway and 180°-turnaround on the runway. There are two distances to be considered: (1) the minimum distance of the main wheels from the start of the runway for determining TODA and TORA,’L’; and (2) the minimum distance of the most forward wheel(s) from the start of the runway for determining ASDA,’N’. Where the aeroplane manufacturer does not provide the appropriate data, the calculation method given in (b) should be used to determine the alignment distance. The AMC (Acceptable Means of Compliance) is not hugely specific about the scenarios when this is required, but adding a bit of common sense leads it to be used any time the aircraft lines up on the runway, other than when they can be fully lined up at the start of the runway threshold. Thankfully, there is only one option close to this, and the other options are all flawed or unrelated in some way.

content.question: Which of the following statements, concerning tires, is the major consideration when establishing the tyre speed limit?

options.A: rotation rate of the tyre and temperature.
options.C: rotation rate of the tyre and VMBE.

key_points: Tyre Speed Limit The reason for a tyre speed limit is because naturally there is resistance between the wheel and the runway
As the wheel rotates this resistance generates heat
The greater the wheel speed and/or the greater the load on the wheel, the greater the heat generated
learning.explanation: Tyre Speed Limit The reason for a tyre speed limit is because naturally there is resistance between the wheel and the runway. As the wheel rotates this resistance generates heat. The greater the wheel speed and/or the greater the load on the wheel, the greater the heat generated. Too much heat may also expand the air within the tyre and over pressurize it. This may result in a tyre blow out, although in some aircraft fusible plugs are installed to prevent this. There is a maximum ground speed and maximum mass that the wheels can be subject to. The maximum ground speed that the tyre will experience will be at VLOF, and as a result, tyre speed limits are designed to be greater than or equal to the fastest VLOF.

content.question:
What will be the result if the pilot decides to set a TOGA thrust instead of a FLEX thrust, when commencing the take-off run, after having entered the following data into the FMS?
V1: 165 kt
VR:170 kt
V2: 174 kt
TFLEX: 46°C

options.A: The take-off speeds will be incorrect and too low. If an engine were to fail at the most critical time for a continued take-off, the aeroplane would fail to achieve the calculated performance.
options.B: It is NOT legal to commence a take-off run with a thrust setting other than the one calculated as the take-off performance cannot be assured using incorrect speeds.
options.C: The engine will achieve a higher thrust setting and take-off performance will be improved when compared to the calculated values.
options.D: The aeroplane will have an improved climb performance but because the speeds are calculated for a reduced thrust setting, the aeroplane will fail to achieve the required take-off distance and obstacle clearance.

key_points: When an aircraft is neither climb nor field length limited nor obstacle limited on take-off, there is essentially performance to spare
There is no point in taking-off with the maximum take-off thrust set, when clearly this is unnecessary
Any thrust setting, less than the maximum, will provide substantial benefits in terms of engine life, maintenance and operating costs
learning.explanation: When an aircraft is neither climb nor field length limited nor obstacle limited on take-off, there is essentially performance to spare. There is no point in taking-off with the maximum take-off thrust set, when clearly this is unnecessary. Any thrust setting, less than the maximum, will provide substantial benefits in terms of engine life, maintenance and operating costs. In such cases, it is normal for operators to use approved procedures to reduce the thrust, so that the aircraft is at or close to its performance limits at the reduced thrust setting. There are two different procedured that operators may follow: The "Flex take-off" or "Reduced thrust take-off" or "Asssumed temperature take-off" and The "Derated thrust take-off" The Flex take-off is achieved by calculating an assumed or “flex” temperature that is higher than the ambient, which, when entered into the FMS, will give a thrust setting lower than the full thrust. The flex temperature will always be higher than the ambient temperature and if done correctly the aircraft will perform at or close to its minimum performance requirements at the reduced thrust setting in the event of an engine failure. On a Flex take-off, Take-Off/Go Around (TOGA) thrust can be applied, if required, at any stage of the take-off, because the control speeds, VMCG and VMCA are based on that maximum thrust value and must be correct for full thrust, not for a reduced setting. Thus, the result of using a TOGA setting, instead of a FLEX setting, will be an improved performance.

content.question: Assuming the same runway and associated conditions, which statement below best describes the reason for the differences between the performance figures produced by the modern performance software in an Electronic Flight Bag (EFB), when compared to those derived from the Regulated Take-Off Weight (RTOW) tables?

options.A: The EFB figures are more accurate because a computer is able to consider more accurate parameters and apply these without interpolation.
options.B: EFB calculations are more accurate and will therefore produce more conservative performance figures than retrieved from RTOW tables.
options.C: Performance figures from the RTOW tables are more conservative as they include a safety factor of 1.15 that is NOT applied in the EFB calculations.
options.D: The RTOW tables are typically older and therefore NOT suitable for use in a modern aeroplane where a lot of processes are automated.

key_points: The Regulated Take-off Mass is the most restrictive of the Field-Length-Limited TOM, Climb-Limited TOM, Obstacle-Limited TOM, Tyre-Speed-Limited TOM and the Maximum Structural TOM
All these limits are taken into account by both Electronic Flight Bag (EFB) take-off and landing calculations and Regulated Take-Off Weight (RTOW) tables
EFB means any portable electronic device for use by the flight crew, which may be a laptop, a tablet or an integrated device within the flight deck
learning.explanation: The Regulated Take-off Mass is the most restrictive of the Field-Length-Limited TOM, Climb-Limited TOM, Obstacle-Limited TOM, Tyre-Speed-Limited TOM and the Maximum Structural TOM. All these limits are taken into account by both Electronic Flight Bag (EFB) take-off and landing calculations and Regulated Take-Off Weight (RTOW) tables. EFB means any portable electronic device for use by the flight crew, which may be a laptop, a tablet or an integrated device within the flight deck. Many EFBs include commercial navigation packages, enabling the whole flight to be planned and executed on the same device. It may also hold charts and AFMs and are widely used in an effort to reduce the amount of paper flying around a cockpit. An RTOW table is produced for a specific aircraft type on a particular runway and shows the MTOM and speeds for a variety of temperatures and pressure altitudes, sometimes giving different configuration options. If the ambient temperature and wind conditions do not fall on a discrete column or row, the FCOM will advise whether interpolating is required or whether the pilot should choose the more conservative data points, not interpolate, and accept a slight performance penalty. Comparing EFBs with RTOW tables, EFBs are more accurate because a computer is able to consider more accurate parameters and apply these without interpolation. Airbus estimates that use of the EFB allows between 300 kg and 1 200 kg of additional payload when compared to paper-based calculations from RTOW tables, because of the conservative corrections within the RTOW for temperature, wind and minor unserviceabilities.

content.question: A large jet transport aircraft is on the approach to an airfield, flying at its VMCL speed. If the aircraft were to suffer an engine failure, would it have sufficient performance to conduct a go-around immediately?

options.A: Only the approach can be made, but not the go around.
options.B: There is sufficient performance for a go-around and another approach.
options.C: No, a go-around cannot be performed.
options.D: No, so the approach cannot be continued.

key_points: VMCL is the minimum control speed during the approach and landing
It covers the situation where an aircraft is making an approach, in trim and with all engines operating, and then has to initiate a go-around at which point one engine fails
The immediate situation is that the live engine is at full go-around power and producing powerful yawing moments before the pilot has had time to re-trim the aircraft for that conditions
learning.explanation: VMCL is the minimum control speed during the approach and landing. It covers the situation where an aircraft is making an approach, in trim and with all engines operating, and then has to initiate a go-around at which point one engine fails. The immediate situation is that the live engine is at full go-around power and producing powerful yawing moments before the pilot has had time to re-trim the aircraft for that conditions. As long as the aircraft is at or above VMCL, the aircraft will be controllable, in accordance with the criteria below, which do cover the worst case scenario. CS 25.149 Minimum control speed (f) (See AMC 25.149 (f)) VMCL, the minimum control speed during approach and landing with all engines operating, is the calibrated airspeed at which, when the critical engine is suddenly made inoperative, it is possible to maintain control of the aeroplane with that engine still inoperative, and maintain straight flight with an angle of bank of not more than 5º. VMCL must be established with: (1) The aeroplane in the most critical configuration (or, at the option of the applicant, each configuration) for approach and landing with all engines operating; (2) The most unfavourable centre of gravity; (3) The aeroplane trimmed for approach with all engines operating; (4) The most unfavourable weight, or, at the option of the applicant, as a function of weight; (5) For propeller aeroplanes, the propeller of the inoperative engine in the position it achieves without pilot action, assuming the engine fails while at the power or thrust necessary to maintain a 3 degree approach path angle; and (6) Go-around power or thrust setting on the operating engine(s).

content.question: Which of the following options is true with regards to hydroplaning?

options.A: Rotating wheels are more sensitive to hydroplaning.
options.B: It is prohibited to operate with rotating wheels on a contaminated surface.
options.C: Rotating and non-rotating wheels are equally sensitive to hydroplaning.
options.D: Non-rotating wheels are more sensitive to hydroplaning.

key_points: On wet surfaces, aeroplane tyres can lose traction and grip due to hydroplaning
This is where the water on the surface can create a slippery layer between the runway and the tyres
This has very low friction, so the tyre will have no traction available to applying braking force, the wheel will "lock up" and the tyre will just skid on a "wedge of water"
learning.explanation: On wet surfaces, aeroplane tyres can lose traction and grip due to hydroplaning. This is where the water on the surface can create a slippery layer between the runway and the tyres. This has very low friction, so the tyre will have no traction available to applying braking force, the wheel will "lock up" and the tyre will just skid on a "wedge of water". Hydroplaning occurs differently whether the tyres are spinning or not, and the speed it occurs at is governed by the following two formulas. Tyres are not spinning when the aircraft touches down, hence the increased risk of hydroplaning during landing, rather than during a rejected take-off, which is the other time it could cause problems. (non-rotating wheel) Hydroplaning speed = 7.7 x √(tyre pressure (psi)) (rotating wheel) Hydroplaning speed = 9 x √(tyre pressure (psi)) Therefore the hydroplaning speed is lower for non-rotating wheels, meaning that they are more sensitive to hydroplaning.

content.question:
You are about to take-off at Mykonos airport in Greece on a short runway 1905 m facing the sea in a large jet transport aircraft. For this take-off, you are not limited by the climb gradient, which of the following allowable take-off configurations is best to obtain the maximum runway length limited TOM?
Configuration 1: 1 stage of slats and flaps
Configuration 2: 2 stages of slats and flaps
Configuration 3: 2 stages of slats and 3 stages of flaps

options.A: Configuration 1 because it results in greater take-off speeds and lower take-off distance than using configuration 2 or 3.
options.B: Configuration 2 because it results in lower take-off distance and a higher runway limited mass than using configuration 3.
options.C: Configuration 3 because it results in lower take-off speeds and higher runway limited mass than using configuration 1 or 2.
options.D: Configuration 1 because it results in lower take-off distance and a higher climb gradient than using configuration 2 or 3.

key_points: Note: This question is a highly requested modification of Q323946, with much more detail in the question, as seen recently in exams
When we do our take-off performance calculations for a specific runway in specific conditions, the biggest factor (and often the figure we are trying to find) is our maximum take-off mass (MTOM)
In actual fact, there are many different MTOMs, and we have to find the most limiting, which will be the lowest of the set
learning.explanation: Note: This question is a highly requested modification of Q323946, with much more detail in the question, as seen recently in exams. When we do our take-off performance calculations for a specific runway in specific conditions, the biggest factor (and often the figure we are trying to find) is our maximum take-off mass (MTOM). In actual fact, there are many different MTOMs, and we have to find the most limiting, which will be the lowest of the set. This is called our RTOM (regulated take-off mass), and is the most limiting of our climb limited take-off mass (CLTOM), obstacle limited take-off mass (OLTOM), field length limiting take-off mass (FLLTOM) and maximum structural take-off mass (MSTOM). The most limiting (smallest value) of these will be the one where our aircraft will struggle most for performance, so if we have a long runway surrounded by mountains, then we will likely be limited by the obstacle limited take-off mass, as its value will be lower than all the others. The questions asks for which configuration we should choose in this scenario. Using more flaps for take-off decreases our take-off distance, as we can rotate and lift off at a slower speed, but also decreases or climb gradient. Increasing the amount of flaps therefore increases our FLLTOM, but decreases our OLTOM and CLTOM. In this question, we have a short runway and very low required climb gradient. Therefore the FLLTOM will be the most limiting, and to increase this, we would take-off with a higher flap setting. This stands to reason, as we would rotate at a lower speed to use less runway (good for the short runway), but then have quite a poor climb gradient relative to using less flaps, which is no problem over the sea. Therefore, we should choose Configuration 3.
