content.question: What is the effect of a lower gross weight on a jet aircraft's optimum altitude, specific fuel consumption and specific range?

options.A: An increased optimum altitude, decreased specific fuel consumption and increased specific range.
options.B: An increased optimum altitude, increased specific fuel consumption and decreased specific range.
options.C: A decreased optimum altitude, decreased specific fuel consumption and increased specific range.
options.D: A decreased optimum altitude, increased specific fuel consumption and decreased specific range.

key_points: Specific fuel consumption (SFC) in a jet is the fuel flow per unit of thrust, while SFC for a propeller is the fuel flow per unit of power
It is a measurement of efficiency, lower SFC means less fuel used for the same thrust, so is better
A lower SFC leads to the aircraft being able to obtain a higher specific range (SR), which is the distance covered per unit of fuel burnt (higher is better)
learning.explanation: Specific fuel consumption (SFC) in a jet is the fuel flow per unit of thrust, while SFC for a propeller is the fuel flow per unit of power. It is a measurement of efficiency, lower SFC means less fuel used for the same thrust, so is better. A lower SFC leads to the aircraft being able to obtain a higher specific range (SR), which is the distance covered per unit of fuel burnt (higher is better). In a turbojet engine, SFC is lowest (which is best) when the air temperature is low, and also when the engine is running at its design RPM of approximately 90 to 95% rpm. It also means that the engine-aircraft combination is most efficient at high altitude where the air is cold and the thrust required to overcome drag is approximately 90 to 95% of the thrust available. This creates an optimum altitude for a turbojet powered aircraft. Flying at this altitude allows the specific range of the aircraft to be the highest By decreasing an aircraft's weight (which happens due to fuel burn throughout flight normally), the aircraft has lower induced drag and larger buffet margins, so can safely climb higher. This means that the optimum altitude of the aircraft will increase also. This means lower temperatures (which decrease SFC) and a higher TAS for the same drag, so specific range is increased also.

121 (c), but may not less than 1

The NTFP may be divided into four segments: Segment 1 starts at the screen height, 35ft above the reference zero point at V2 and ends when the gear retraction is completed. content.question:
With regard to Obstacle-Limited Take-Off Mass, which of the following statements is correct?
1. Maximum Obstacle-Limited Take-Off Mass is the limiting take-off mass if the climb gradient to clear obstacle with required margins is higher than the minimum climb gradient.
2. Obstacle limitations may overcompensate the positive effects of headwinds.

key_points: Note: The feedback for this one was limited, and made very little sense
We have modified the wording to what we believe is the closest possible question
We therefore require any further exam feedback about this one
learning.explanation: Note: The feedback for this one was limited, and made very little sense. We have modified the wording to what we believe is the closest possible question. We therefore require any further exam feedback about this one. Please send feedback to us via the comments, the exam feedback section on your dashboard, or by email to info@atplquestions.com, thank you! When we do our take-off performance calculations for a specific runway in specific conditions, the biggest factor (and often the figure we are trying to find) is our maximum take-off mass (MTOM). In actual fact, there are many different MTOMs, and we have to find the most limiting, which will be the lowest of the set. This is called our MATOM (maximum allowed take-off mass), and is the most limiting of our climb limited take-off mass (CLTOM), obstacle limited take-off mass (OLTOM), field length limiting take-off mass (FLLTOM) and maximum structural take-off mass (MSTOM). The most limiting (smallest value) of these will be the one where our aircraft will struggle most for performance, so if we have a long runway surrounded by mountains, then we will likely be limited by the obstacle limited take-off mass, as its value will be lower than all the others. In this question, then, we can say that statement 1 is incorrect, as that is only comparing OLTOM to CLTOM, but the OLTOM is only limiting if it is the lowest of all those masses mentioned above. Statement 2 requires a little more thought. When we calculate OLTOM, we are allowed to include the wind effects, as a headwind will allow us a steeper climb gradient than in still air (and shallower with a tailwind). We are, however, only allowed to use up to 50% of the headwind component, and not less than 150% of the tailwind, to give a safety margin. This means that we underestimate the effect of a headwind on our obstacle clearance, so statement 2 is incorrect.

content.question: For departure, the APU is on, and is supplying the bleed air for all onboard systems. What effect will this have on the take-off performance?

options.A: The take-off performance will be reduced as less thrust is available from the engines.
options.B: The take-off performance will be reduced as less fuel flow will be supplied to the engines.
options.C: Increased takeoff performance as there will be more thrust available from the engines.
options.D: Increased performance as there will be increased fuel flow to the engines.

key_points: Learning Objective 032
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 032.04.01.02.02: Explain the effects of the following aeroplane variables on take-off distance: aeroplane mass; take-off configuration; bleed-air configurations. Bleed air is a pneumatic source in an aircraft, used for processes such as pressurisation, air conditioning, de-icing/anti-icing, etc. It is usually taken from the compressor stage of the engines, and therefore reduces the amount of air that gets sent to the combustion chamber for ignition. Bleed air is also used for starting the engines, and for the first engine to be started, it is either taken from the APU (auxiliary power unit) bleed air supply or from a pneumatic GPU (ground power unit). APUs are small turbine engines in the tail of large jets that provide extra power and bleed air for operations, usually when on the ground with the main engines off. This means that "bleeds", as they are commonly called, do decrease engine thrust, due to reduced mass flow. It is not a large decrease, but it is enough that operators sometimes require the bleeds to be switched off for performance critical take-offs to provide the best possible thrust. In this scenario, however, the APU is providing all the bleed air supplies for the aircraft, meaning that the main engine thrust will be increased from usual, and therefore take-off performance will be improved. It is assumed that aircraft usually take-off with engine bleed air on, unless the extra performance is required.

content.question: Optimum altitude can be increased progressively during the flight due to the...

options.D: movement of the centre of gravity.

key_points: Optimum Altitude It is defined as being the pressure altitude which provides the greatest specific range or fuel mileage at a given weight and speed
Flying higher or lower than the optimum altitude will decrease the range of the airplane
It is important to understand that the optimum altitude is not fixed
learning.explanation: Optimum Altitude It is defined as being the pressure altitude which provides the greatest specific range or fuel mileage at a given weight and speed. Flying higher or lower than the optimum altitude will decrease the range of the airplane. It is important to understand that the optimum altitude is not fixed. As the weight decreases through fuel burn, the drag curve moves down and left. Therefore, the best range speed, 1.32VMD, falls and the total drag decreases. With decreasing weight, the airplane needs to slow down to maintain the best range speed. As it does so, the Mach number will also decrease meaning that the airplane is not limited by the high Mach number and corresponding high drag. This fact allows the airplane to climb a little. As the airplane climbs, the Mach number will increase again to its previous limiting value and drag will increase back to its previous value. But more importantly the higher altitude has decreased the specific fuel consumption. This means that over time, as the weight decreases with fuel burn, the optimum altitude increases.

content.question: A multi-engine piston aircraft is in a constant-speed descent from 2000 feet. If the descent was started at VMC, at a lower altitude, the aircraft may become (1) _____ due to the (2) _____ in VMC with decreasing pressure altitude.

key_points: When a multi-engine aircraft suffers an engine failure several variables affect both the yawing moment and the rudder moment which is used to oppose it
There is a minimum IAS (VMC), below which it is impossible for the pilot to maintain directional control with asymmetric thrust
Airworthiness Authorities, in this case the EASA, have laid down conditions which must be satisfied when establishing the minimum airspeeds for inclusion in the Flight Manual of a new aircraft type
learning.explanation: When a multi-engine aircraft suffers an engine failure several variables affect both the yawing moment and the rudder moment which is used to oppose it. There is a minimum IAS (VMC), below which it is impossible for the pilot to maintain directional control with asymmetric thrust. Airworthiness Authorities, in this case the EASA, have laid down conditions which must be satisfied when establishing the minimum airspeeds for inclusion in the Flight Manual of a new aircraft type. As in most other cases, the conditions under which the minimum control airspeeds are established are ‘worst case’. VMC is affected by the amount of thrust being developed by the operating engine. As altitude and/or temperature increases, the thrust from an unsupercharged engine will decrease. In conditions of high air density, the engines produce a high thrust output and the loss of the output from one engine during take-off is a proportionate loss of a high output. This will require a considerable amount of force to counteract the tendency to yaw. VMC increases with increasing density. Air density will be highest when the aerodrome pressure altitude is lowest (high atmospheric pressure), the air temperature is lowest and the water-vapour content of the air is lowest. Considering a descent at constant speed and flying initially at VMC, as the aircraft descends, VMC increases, leading to flight at a speed lower than VMC at lower altitudes. This can be potentially dangerous as the aircraft becomes uncontrollable below VMC. LO 032.04.05.01.02: Explain the effect of descending at constant IAS.

options.B: The value of the critical Mach number at various masses and altitudes.
options.C: The value of maximum operating Mach number (MMO) at various masses and power settings.

key_points: The Buffet Margin An altitude can be reached where there is only one speed at which the aircraft can fly
In the case of a 1g manoeuvre, this altitude is called the ‘Aerodynamic Ceiling’
Operating an aircraft at its aerodynamic ceiling would leave no safety margin
learning.explanation: The Buffet Margin An altitude can be reached where there is only one speed at which the aircraft can fly. In the case of a 1g manoeuvre, this altitude is called the ‘Aerodynamic Ceiling’. Operating an aircraft at its aerodynamic ceiling would leave no safety margin. In 1g flight the aircraft would be constantly on the point of stall. Regulations require an aircraft to be operated with a minimum buffet margin of 0.3g. Buffet Onset To more accurately calculate the high and low speed buffets or the buffet boundary, a buffet onset chart found within the aircraft flight manual is used. The chart provides the values of the Mach number at which low speed and Mach buffet occur at various masses and altitudes.

content.question: A Standard Instrument Departure (SID) requires a 15º left turn shortly after take-off. This will cause total drag to (1) _____ and climb gradient to (2) _____?

key_points: The flight path after take-off is carefully calculated to make sure that obstacle and terrain clearance can be maintained, even if an engine fails at the most critical point during take-off
Any turns on the departure track cause the aircraft's lift vector to go to the side, reducing the effective lift upwards that is required to counteract the weight
Doing this means that the pilot has to apply back pressure in the turn to produce enough extra lift
learning.explanation: The flight path after take-off is carefully calculated to make sure that obstacle and terrain clearance can be maintained, even if an engine fails at the most critical point during take-off. Any turns on the departure track cause the aircraft's lift vector to go to the side, reducing the effective lift upwards that is required to counteract the weight. Doing this means that the pilot has to apply back pressure in the turn to produce enough extra lift. This increases induced drag, so the aircraft has either reduced acceleration, or a reduced rate of climb. In this question, then, the total drag increases and the climb gradient decreases due to the turn. This is why a climb gradient reduction is applied to any turns when the net take-off flight path is being calculated.

content.question: A runway covered with 4 mm thick water, is said to be:

A runway is considered to be contaminated when more than 25% of the runway surface area (whether in isolated areas or not) within the required length and width being used is covered by the following: (a) surface water more than 3 mm (0,125 in) deep, or by slush, or loose snow, equivalent to more than 3 mm (0,125 in) of water; (b) snow which has been compressed into a solid mass which resists further compression and will hold together or break into lumps if picked up (compacted snow); or (c) ice, including wet ice
"Damp runway"
learning.explanation: EASA AIR OPS Annex I to VIII "Contaminated runway". A runway is considered to be contaminated when more than 25% of the runway surface area (whether in isolated areas or not) within the required length and width being used is covered by the following: (a) surface water more than 3 mm (0,125 in) deep, or by slush, or loose snow, equivalent to more than 3 mm (0,125 in) of water; (b) snow which has been compressed into a solid mass which resists further compression and will hold together or break into lumps if picked up (compacted snow); or (c) ice, including wet ice. "Damp runway". A runway is considered damp when the surface is not dry, but when the moisture on it does not give it a shiny appearance. "Dry runway". A dry runway is one which is neither wet nor contaminated, and includes those paved runways which have been specially prepared with grooves or porous pavement and maintained to retain "effectively dry" braking action even when moisture is present. "Wet runway." A runway is considered wet when the runway surface is covered with water, or equivalent, less than specified in subparagraph (a)(2) above or when there is sufficient moisture on the runway surface to cause it to appear reflective, but without significant areas of standing water. Note: CONTAMINATED => MORE than 25% of the Runway and 3mm or MORE depth of water; WET => 25% of the runway and 3mm or LESS depth of water.

content.question:
An aeroplane is maintaining FL350 at M0.78 (262 kt CAS), when an engine failure forces the pilot to commence a driftdown procedure. The three driftdown strategies below, assume that MCT (Maximum Continuous thrust) is set on the remaining engine(s) prior to commencing the driftdown, if possible. Which one of the statements is correct ?
Standard strategy: M0.78/300 kt
Obstacle strategy: Minimum drag speed VMD (241 kt CAS)
ETOPS strategy: M0.80/340 kt

options.A: The Standard strategy gives the shortest time in the descent to reach the drift-down level-off altitude.
options.B: The Standard strategy ensures that the greatest excess thrust is available to reduce the rate of descent.
options.C: For the Obstacle strategy, decelerating to VMD before commencing the descent improves the obstacle clearance.
options.D: For the ETOPS strategy, the aeroplane must accelerate to the descent speed before commencing the descent.

key_points: If an engine fails in the cruise, then the remaining engine(s) are set to Maximum Continuous Thrust (MCT), in an attempt to maintain height

At cruise altitudes, the attempt to maintain height usually fails, because of inadequate thrust on the remaining engine(s) and the aircraft will descend down to a height at which it is able to stabilise
This is called "driftdown" and it is a "power on" descent
learning.explanation: If an engine fails in the cruise, then the remaining engine(s) are set to Maximum Continuous Thrust (MCT), in an attempt to maintain height. At cruise altitudes, the attempt to maintain height usually fails, because of inadequate thrust on the remaining engine(s) and the aircraft will descend down to a height at which it is able to stabilise. This is called "driftdown" and it is a "power on" descent. The driftdown is flown at the best angle of descent speed, which is VMD and is also the best angle of climb speed for a jet, Vx. Also, the greatest excess thrust is found at VMD and it minimizes the descent angle, not the Rate of Descent (ROD). The lowest ROD is achieved at VMP. A deceleration to VMD at FL350, will create a nose-up attitude and will delay for some seconds the commencement of the descent, improving that way the obstacle clearance. Thus, the Obstacle strategy, where the cruise speed M0.78 (262 kt CAS) is reduced to the Minimum drag speed VMD (241 kt CAS) before commencing the descent, improves the obstacle clearance.

content.question:
Refer to figure.
The annex shows take-off rejected take-off distance for an aeroplane in given conditions. The balanced field is shown at distance...

key_points: The diagram shown is a distance vs V1 speed graph
It shows the distance of each scenario for different V1 speeds
For instance, look at the ASD line (Accelerate-Stop Distance)
learning.explanation: The diagram shown is a distance vs V1 speed graph. It shows the distance of each scenario for different V1 speeds. For instance, look at the ASD line (Accelerate-Stop Distance). It shows that, with a low speed V1, the ASD is short, and when the V1 increases, so does the accelerate-stop distance. This stands to reason, as the faster we get to before we stop, the longer our total distance is going to be. The TODN-1 and TORN-1 lines are the opposite, as they correspond to how long the take-off distance and take-off run will be in an engine failure scenario. With a lower V1, they are both long distances, as the aircraft will have to accelerate most of the way up to rotate speed on only 1 engine. As the V1 increases, they both decrease in distance. The TODN and TORN lines are fixed at a certain distance, and do not vary due to V1, as those scenarios do not change at V1 at all. The balanced V1 exists when the ASD is equal to the TODN-1, meaning that for a balanced field runway, there is one perfect V1, which allows the absolute maximum possible mass, and there are no wasted safety margins. The aircraft will use the same distance to stop as it would do to reach screen height from that exact V1 speed. Even if the aircraft is not taking off at this maximum mass (called the FLLTOM), the balanced V1 is usually used anyway to provide equivalent safety margins in both the stop and go scenarios.

content.question: The optimum long-range cruise altitude for a turbojet aeroplane:

options.A: increases when the aeroplane mass decreases.
options.B: is always equal to the powerplant ceiling.
options.C: is only dependent on the outside air temperature.
options.D: is independent of the aeroplane mass.

key_points: Optimum Altitude It is defined as being the pressure altitude which provides the greatest specific range or fuel mileage at a given weight and speed
Flying higher or lower than the optimum altitude will decrease the range of the airplane
It is important to understand that the optimum altitude is not fixed
learning.explanation: Optimum Altitude It is defined as being the pressure altitude which provides the greatest specific range or fuel mileage at a given weight and speed. Flying higher or lower than the optimum altitude will decrease the range of the airplane. It is important to understand that the optimum altitude is not fixed. As the weight decreases through fuel burn, the drag curve moves down and left. Therefore, the best range speed, 1.32VMD, falls and the total drag decreases. With decreasing weight, the airplane needs to slow down to maintain the best range speed. As it does so, the Mach number will also decrease meaning that the airplane is not limited by the high Mach number and corresponding high drag. This fact allows the airplane to climb a little. As the airplane climbs, the Mach number will increase again to its previous limiting value and drag will increase back to its previous value. But more importantly the higher altitude has decreased the specific fuel consumption. This means that over time, as the weight decreases with fuel burn, the optimum altitude increases.

content.question: Which cruise system gives minimum fuel consumption during cruise between top of climb and top of descent? (still air, no turbulence)

key_points: The advantage of flying at the maximum range speed is simply that the airplane will use the least amount of fuel and therefore have the least fuel cost for a given distance
In this case, the question asks for minimum fuel consumption for the cruise portion between top of climb and top of descent
If they ask about a defined space (from TOC to TOD) go for Maximum Range; if not, the minimum fuel burn will be Maximum Endurance
learning.explanation: The advantage of flying at the maximum range speed is simply that the airplane will use the least amount of fuel and therefore have the least fuel cost for a given distance. In this case, the question asks for minimum fuel consumption for the cruise portion between top of climb and top of descent. If they ask about a defined space (from TOC to TOD) go for Maximum Range; if not, the minimum fuel burn will be Maximum Endurance. The cruise regime that offers us the maximum range possible will naturally be the most efficient in this circumstance. Range is the distance an aircraft can fly on the amount of fuel available. Endurance is defined as the time an aircraft can fly on the amount of fuel available.

learning.explanation: Maximum Brake Energy Speed (VMBE) The maximum speed on the ground from which an airplane can safely stop within the energy capabilities of the brakes. V1 must not be greater than VMBE. At V1 the airplane must be able to stop or continue the take-off, but above VMBE it is impossible to bring the airplane safely to a stop. With an uphill slope it will be easier for the aircraft to stop, increasing the VMBE. Increasing the VMBE limit, a higher V1 allowed permits a higher maximum take-off mass. On the other hand, a downslope will have an adverse effect on braking ability. VMBE and V1 will be reduced.

content.question: During a descent with constant Mach number below the tropopause in ISA conditions, how do the TAS and CAS change? TAS...

content.question: A pilot is operating his first flight on a longer variant of an aircraft type he currently flies. Due to the increased risk of a tailstrike, pilot decides to rotate at a slower (but still acceptable) rate. This will have an effect on (1) _____ TOR, (2) _____ TOD and (3) _____ climb gradient.

key_points: Over rotating to a high pitch attitude can lead to a ground stall and quite possibly a tail strike
If you do actually get airborne, high pitch attitudes maintained after take-off will lead to low airspeed and again a possible stall
Under rotating will increase the Take-off Run (TOR) and Take-off Distance (TOD) and therefore reduce the obstacle clearance
learning.explanation: Over rotating to a high pitch attitude can lead to a ground stall and quite possibly a tail strike. If you do actually get airborne, high pitch attitudes maintained after take-off will lead to low airspeed and again a possible stall. Under rotating will increase the Take-off Run (TOR) and Take-off Distance (TOD) and therefore reduce the obstacle clearance. Rotation at a slower rate means that the aircraft will cover more runway distance until the required pitch attitude is achieved and the VR and VLOF will be achieved at a higher TAS and groundspeed. As a result, both TOR and TOD will increase. Climb gradient is given by the formula: Climb Gradient = (T - D) / W. Once airborne with an increased VR closer to VMD, the climb gradient will increase, since the difference between the thrust available and drag increases too.

metadata.topic: 25/Applicable Operational Requirements Performance Class A – Theory

content.question: A Medium-Range Jet Transport aeroplane is planned to depart from a sufficiently long runway and the correct V-speeds have been calculated. The pilot has not flown this variant of the aircraft before, and it has a longer fuselage than the variant they have flown before. As the tail clearance during rotation is reduced on this longer aircraft, the pilot performs their rotation at a slightly slower (but still acceptable) rate than they would normally. What will this change?

options.A: It will increase the take-off run, but the take-off distance will be reduced since the aeroplane will attain a climb speed that is slightly faster.
options.B: It will increase both the take-off run and the take-off distance and potentially reduce the clearance over low obstacles close to the runway.
options.C: It will improve the climb performance of the aeroplane as this procedure is effectively the same as using an increased V2 procedure.
options.D: It will reduce the climb performance of the aeroplane since the speed will be above V2, which is the speed tor maximum climb angle.

key_points: Learning Objective 032
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 032.04.01.02.04: Explain the consequence of errors in rotation technique on take-off distance: early and late rotation; too high and too low rotation angle; too high and too low rotation rate. When a rotation is made slower, the aircraft spends longer in contact with the runway (and therefore has an increased take-off run), and also spends longer reaching the correct attitude, and therefore does not climb as well during the rotation and climb to 35ft screen height. This increases the take-off distance (to get to 35 ft) and may reduce the obstacle clearance margin with close in obstacles. It will increase the initial climb speed of the aircraft slightly, but we cannot say if this will continue into the climb out, as the pilot may pitch to a higher attitude to compensate for the extra speed. Also, the examiner has framed this slower rotation as less effective for takeoff, so the correct answer would usually have a worse result than the normal rotation rate, and therefore the "increased V2" option is not the most correct option in our opinion.

metadata.topic: 25/Applicable Operational Requirements Performance Class A – Theory

content.question: Which of the following will happen if the pilot sets take-off thrust using the actual OAT instead of the FLEX temperature calculated for a reduced thrust take-off?

options.C: The ASDR increases and the climb gradient decreases.

key_points: A reduced thrust take-off is a take-off that is accomplished utilising less thrust than the engines are capable of producing under the existing conditions of temperature and pressure altitude
The procedure can be used any time the actual take-off mass is less than the maximum permissible take-off mass and there is an available take-off distance that greatly exceeds that which is required
It has some other restrictions as well, such as not being used on a contaminated runway, or if reversers are unavailable, etc
learning.explanation: A reduced thrust take-off is a take-off that is accomplished utilising less thrust than the engines are capable of producing under the existing conditions of temperature and pressure altitude. The procedure can be used any time the actual take-off mass is less than the maximum permissible take-off mass and there is an available take-off distance that greatly exceeds that which is required. It has some other restrictions as well, such as not being used on a contaminated runway, or if reversers are unavailable, etc. It is used to reduce engine wear and increase engine lifespan. The limitation is posed on the engine computer by inputting a flexible thrust temperature (FLEX) for the engine, which essentially tells the engine computer an artificial outside air temperature that is higher than the actual temperature. This way the engine computer believes that the entering air is hotter than it really is. At outside air temperatures above the flat rated temperature, there is a specific thrust value (variable by pressure altitude) for each temperature, which reduces as the temperature increases, so as not to exceed the engine's maximum TGT (Turbine Gas Temperature). If the thrust requirement for the take-off is known, the associated temperature at which this thrust would be produced can be extracted from the applicable charts. This "assumed" temperature is then entered into the FMS, making the engines think that they can only produce a certain amount of thrust. The pilot can then use that amount of thrust for take-off, or they can use TO/GA (Take-Off/Go-Around) thrust instead, and the engine would revert back to using the maximum thrust for the actual outside air temperature. This would cause an increased thrust output, and would lead to better take-off performance. That is what this question is referring to when it says "using the actual OAT instead of the FLEX temperature".

metadata.topic: 25/Applicable Operational Requirements Performance Class A – Theory

content.question: In relation to the net take-off flight path, the required 35 ft vertical distance to clear all obstacles is...

options.A: height at which power is reduced to maximum climb thrust.
options.B: the minimum vertical distance between the lowest part of the aeroplane and all obstacles within the obstacle corridor.
options.D: the height by which acceleration and flap retraction should be completed.

key_points: Segments of the Take-off Climb For a class A aircraft, the T/O climb is divided into 4 segments: The take-off flight path starts once the take-off is complete, at 35 ft with the airplane at V2 with one engine inoperative
On a wet runway, the screen height is reduced to 15'
Operating engines are at takeoff thrust, the flaps/slats are in takeoff configuration and landing gear retraction is initiated once safely airborne with positive climb
learning.explanation: Segments of the Take-off Climb For a class A aircraft, the T/O climb is divided into 4 segments: The take-off flight path starts once the take-off is complete, at 35 ft with the airplane at V2 with one engine inoperative. On a wet runway, the screen height is reduced to 15'. Operating engines are at takeoff thrust, the flaps/slats are in takeoff configuration and landing gear retraction is initiated once safely airborne with positive climb. The first segment ends when the landing gear is fully retracted. Begins when the landing gear is fully retracted. Engines are at takeoff thrust and the flaps/slats are in the takeoff configuration. This segment ends at the higher of 400'. Begins at 400' or higher specified acceleration altitude. Engines are at takeoff thrust and the aircraft is accelerated in level flight. Slats/flaps are retracted on speed. The segment ends when aircraft is in clean configuration and the final take-off speed has been achieved. Once this has happened, thrust can be reduced from maximum take-off thrust, TOGA, to maximum continuous thrust, MCT. Starts when the flaps are retracted, the final segment speed is achieved, and the thrust is set to maximum continuous thrust. From this point the airplane is climbed to above 1500 ft where the take-off flight path ends. Each segment of the one engine inoperative takeoff flight path has a mandated climb gross gradient requirement. To ensure obstacle clearance while allowing for aircraft performance degradation and less than optimum pilot technique, the gross gradients are reduced by a safety factor. The net gradient is the gross gradient reduced by: 0.8% for 2-engine aircraft 0.9% for 3-engine aircraft 1.0% for 4-engine aircraft Using the net gradient instead of the gross gradient in the take-off flight path will produce a net take-off flight path. As we stated at the beginning, the net take-off flight path must clear all obstacles by 35 ft.

metadata.topic: 25/Applicable Operational Requirements Performance Class A – Theory

content.question: Which factors must be taken into account when calculating landing performance?

options.B: Runway type, type of contamination, pilot-reported braking action.

When calculating landing performance, there are many factors that must be accounted for. These include factors such as: Runway length Runway slope Runway type (surface, grooved or not) Runway condition (dry, wet, contaminated, what type of contamination, depth, coverage, etc.) Wind Temperature Aircraft weight Aircraft equipment (unserviceable equipment, MEL items, autobrake, anti-skid, spoilers, etc.) Flap configuration Ambient pressure (QNH) As well as some more niche factors for specific airports or situations, such as reducing the landing weight due to a missed approach climb gradient, etc. We can go through each option now: "Runway type, contamination, approach type." For the purposes of this question, it is incorrect. "Runway width, wet or dry, tyre type." Runway width affects some elements of landing such as crosswind limitations, but not performance, so incorrect. "Aircraft weight, wind conditions, runway length." Correct. These are some of the biggest factors, and all 3 must be accounted for on every landing.

content.question: Which statement regarding the influence of a runway down-slope is correct for a balanced take-off? Down-slope:

options.A: reduces V1 and reduces take-off distance required (TODR).
options.B: increases V1 and reduces the accelerate stop distance required (ASDR).
options.C: increases V1 and increases the take-off distance required (TODR).
options.D: reduces V1 and increases the accelerate stop distance required (ASDR).

key_points: RUNWAY SLOPE impacts both the take-off and landing distances
When taking-off or landing on a sloping runway, a component of weight will act along the longitudinal axis of the airplane
This will either augment thrust, or augment drag which will increase or decrease the accelerating force
learning.explanation: RUNWAY SLOPE impacts both the take-off and landing distances. When taking-off or landing on a sloping runway, a component of weight will act along the longitudinal axis of the airplane. This will either augment thrust, or augment drag which will increase or decrease the accelerating force. When the aircraft is on a downslope, the weight component will act in the direction of thrust => adding forward force. As a result, deceleration decreases which increases landing distance and decreases take-off distance. Whereas, on an upslope situation, the component of weight acts in the direction of drag (backwards along the longitudinal axis). This will result in a reduced acceleration force and, consequently, decreased landing distance and increased take-off distance. When departing from a runway with a downslope, the procedure is to decrease V1 slightly => With a downslope the acceleration of the aircraft is better, however it will not help us stopping if an engine fails before V1. "reduces take off distance required (TODR)" CORRECT. Take off distance - a down slope allows the aircraft to accelerate faster which decreases the take of distance "reduces V1" CORRECT. When departing from a runway with a downslope, the procedure is to decrease V1 slightly => With a downslope the acceleration of the aircraft is better, however it will not help us stopping if an engine fails before V1. For this reason, reduction of V1 shortens the acceleration segment and gives more safety margin for stopping.

content.question: V1 for a balanced-field is calculated when:

options.A: the take-off mass is field-length limited by the clearway to produce the maximum take-off mass.
options.B: the acceleration/stop distance available is equal to the take-off distance available.
options.C: the speed is equal to V2.
options.D: the take-off mass is field-length limited by the stopway to produce the maximum take-off mass.

key_points: BALANCED FIELD LENGTH When the Accelerate-stop Distance Available (ASDA) is equal to the Take-off Distance Available (TODA), this is known as a Balanced Field Length
Likewise, when the ASDA and TODA are different lengths, this is known as an Unbalanced Field Length

BALANCED FIELD TAKE-OFF A balanced field take-off is performance based and is a condition where the Accelerate-stop Distance Required (ASDR) is equal to the Take-off Distance Required (TODR) for the aircraft weight, engine thrust, aircraft configuration and runway condition
learning.explanation: BALANCED FIELD LENGTH When the Accelerate-stop Distance Available (ASDA) is equal to the Take-off Distance Available (TODA), this is known as a Balanced Field Length. Likewise, when the ASDA and TODA are different lengths, this is known as an Unbalanced Field Length. BALANCED FIELD TAKE-OFF A balanced field take-off is performance based and is a condition where the Accelerate-stop Distance Required (ASDR) is equal to the Take-off Distance Required (TODR) for the aircraft weight, engine thrust, aircraft configuration and runway condition. The balanced field length is the shortest field length at which a balanced field take-off can be performed. A Balanced field length is used to simplify the field-length take-off mass. When applying this concept, TOD = ASD and V1 = V1 Balanced. And this means that we are using the minimum requirements in case of engine failure, thus increasing safety margins. When using stopway or clearway, extra distance will be available and V1 will vary. BALANCED V1 The first graph on the attached figure, helps understanding the impact of increasing or decreasing V1. Analyzing it, we can conclude the following: A Balanced V1 is a V1 speed which results in TODR equal to ASDR. Often called the “Ideal V1” as it gives the minimum field length required for a given weight and optimum performance. Any lower V1 (V1 < V1B) would increase TODR, as it would take longer for the aircraft to accelerate to V2 with OEI. As a result, the total field required increases. Any higher V1 (V1 > V1B) would increase ASDR due to a higher energy absorption by the brakes. As a result, the total field required would also increase. => In essence, Balanced V1 improves field length limited take-off performance. => Unbalanced V1 allows for higher take-off weights by taking advantage of any runway and clearway or stopway available in excess of balanced field length. Summary and extra info: If TOD = ASD, V1 = BALANCED, Balanced condition. If TOD > ASD, V1 < V1 BALANCED, Unbalanced condition. Clearway, no stopway = higher mass and lower V1 speed If TOD < ASD, V1 > V1 BALANCED, Unbalanced condition. Stopway, no clearway = higher mass and higher V1 speed. TORA (Take-Off Run Distance Available) => RUNWAY only (no STOPWAY or CLEARWAY) TODA (Take-Off Distance Available) => TORA + CLEARWAY ASDA (Accelarate-Stop Distance Available) => TORA + STOPWAY

content.question: Under which circumstances can the V2 (improved climb) procedure be used?

options.A: When recommended to use Noise Abatement Departure Procedure 1 (NADP 1).
options.B: To reach optimum altitude as fast as possible.
options.C: With a long runway and to clear close-in obstacles.
options.D: With a short runway and to clear distant obstacles.

key_points: Take-off with Increased V2 Speed This procedure is used when the performance limited mass is the climb limit mass
At V2 the climbing performance is poor and limits the maximum take-off mass
It is important to understand that in the event of engine failure, the initial climb out speed is V2
learning.explanation: Take-off with Increased V2 Speed This procedure is used when the performance limited mass is the climb limit mass. At V2 the climbing performance is poor and limits the maximum take-off mass. It is important to understand that in the event of engine failure, the initial climb out speed is V2. However, V2 is not the best climb angle speed. V2 is considerably slower than the best angle of climb speed, which is VX. Climbing with a speed closer to the best angle of climb greatly enhance the climb performance. If runway available it would be possible to stay on the runway for longer during the take-off to build up more speed to a higher V1, this will ensure that at the screen height, a faster V2 will be reached, closer to VX. As a result of the improved climb performance, the climb limit mass can be increased.

learning.explanation: Advantages of using reduced take-off thrust Using reduced thrust lowers the jet engine's internal operating pressure and temperature. The primary advantage of the use of reduced take-off thrust is cost savings through increased engine life and reduced overhaul costs. Secondarily, it may be possible to increase the maximum take-off weight for a specific runway by using a reduced thrust profile. Therefore, the main benefits are: Reduced stress and wear on the engine; Reduced cost on parts and mainenance; Increased engine life; Increased reliability, thus improving operating safety and efficency. content.question: For which of the following situations is a step climb recommended?

options.A: When flying at the optimum altitude in order to optimise maximum range.
options.B: When flying 2 000 ft above the optimum altitude in order to optimise maximum endurance.
options.C: When flying 2 000 ft below the optimum altitude in order to optimise maximum range.
options.D: When flying below the optimum altitude in order to optimise maximum endurance.

key_points: The optimum flight profile for a jet aircraft requires a climb after take-off to the optimum altitude
Once you have achieved your initial optimum cruise altitude, flying at 1
32 VMD (best range speed for jet aircraft) and with the engines at around 90% RPM, the fuel burn will reduce the aircraft weight
learning.explanation: The optimum flight profile for a jet aircraft requires a climb after take-off to the optimum altitude. Once you have achieved your initial optimum cruise altitude, flying at 1.32 VMD (best range speed for jet aircraft) and with the engines at around 90% RPM, the fuel burn will reduce the aircraft weight. As the weight decreases, both VMD and the induced drag decrease. This means that in level flight, 90% thrust will accelerate you beyond 1.32 VMD, in effect your optimum altitude has increased. In order to avoid this, the aircraft can be put into either a cruise climb or step climb. Air Traffic Control probably will not allow a cruise climb, because it is a very very slow climb during cruise, so that the aircraft is always at the optimum altitude, where 90% RPM always gives the best range speed. The step climb is the most common way of operating jets in the cruise in real life. It is a compromise between a level cruise and a cruise climb, where the aircraft initially climbs to the nearest level and reaches a little above the optimum altitude and then fly level for a while, reducing thrust as the weight reduces to maintain the best range speed. As the weight reduces, the optimum level rises through your level and then, when the aircraft is 1 000 ft to 2 000 ft below the optimum altitude, you can climb again to the next ATC-approved level available above the optimum and so on.

content.question: For a given flap setting, how do aerodrome pressure altitude and temperature affect the Maximum Quick Turnaround Mass? The Maximum Quick Turnaround Mass is reduced with

options.B: lower pressure altitudes and higher temperatures.
options.C: higher pressure altitudes and lower temperatures.
options.D: higher pressure altitudes and higher temperatures.

key_points: The Quick Turnaround limit is related to the wheel fusible alloy plugs that are designed to melt at a predetermined temperature to prevent the tyre exploding when its been subjected to high temperatures caused by heavy braking

After a brake application, the energy which the brake has absorbed is released as heat and until this heat is dissipated, the amount of additional energy which the brake can absorb without failure is reduced

Take a look at the attached figure taken from CAP 698 - you can clearly see that the Maximum Permissible Landing Mass for a Quick Turnaround is limited by the Aerodrome Pressure Altitude, Airport OAT, Flaps setting, Runway Slope and Wind
learning.explanation: The Quick Turnaround limit is related to the wheel fusible alloy plugs that are designed to melt at a predetermined temperature to prevent the tyre exploding when its been subjected to high temperatures caused by heavy braking. After a brake application, the energy which the brake has absorbed is released as heat and until this heat is dissipated, the amount of additional energy which the brake can absorb without failure is reduced. Take a look at the attached figure taken from CAP 698 - you can clearly see that the Maximum Permissible Landing Mass for a Quick Turnaround is limited by the Aerodrome Pressure Altitude, Airport OAT, Flaps setting, Runway Slope and Wind. The higher the pressure altitude and the temperature, the lower the density. As a result, the aircraft produces less lift and thrust for a given speed and power setting. Therefore, the aircraft must fly a higher approach speed, leading to higher TAS and consequently higher groundspeeds on landing => higher brake temperatures due to heavier braking required.

content.question: An airline wishes to operate a new commercial route on one of their jet aircraft to an airfield with a high field elevation. In summer, the climate of the airfield includes frequent low pressure systems, and the temperatures can get as high as 30ºC. In comparison to an airfield at sea level in ISA conditions, what will be the likely effect of this destination on the maximum landing mass?

options.A: The MLM will remain fairly constant as the pressure difference compensates for the higher temperature.
options.C: The MLM will increase slightly as the temperature difference compensates for the lower pressure.

key_points: The question describes an airfield with high density altitude (hot and high) airfield and asks about landing performance
For take-off and landing, higher density altitude causes low air density, which decreases performance
For landing, this comes as a longer landing distance, and a lower gradient of climb after a balked landing (which is a criteria that must be considered as part of the legal performance calculation)
learning.explanation: The question describes an airfield with high density altitude (hot and high) airfield and asks about landing performance. For take-off and landing, higher density altitude causes low air density, which decreases performance. For landing, this comes as a longer landing distance, and a lower gradient of climb after a balked landing (which is a criteria that must be considered as part of the legal performance calculation). A higher density altitude therefore means having a lower maximum landing mass (MLM). Compared to an airfield at sea level, the high field elevation, low pressure systems and high temperatures decrease the air density, which causes a higher TAS for the same IAS, and means that an aircraft will cross the threshold at a higher groundspeed on landing, and will therefore take a longer distance to decelerate from that higher speed. To combat this, the aircraft mass has to be reduced, allowing for a lower approach speed and less energy to slow down during landing.

content.question: When the OAT at an airfield is +8°C, your aircraft's VMC is 80 kt. What will happen to the VMC if OAT increases to +20°C?

options.A: It will increase because the engines will produce more thrust and thus create a larger yawing moment.
options.B: It will decrease because the engines will produce less thrust and thus create a smaller yawing moment.
options.C: It will remain the same because temperature does not affect VMC.
options.D: It will increase because the aircraft will have more lift and less drag.

key_points: VMC is the lowest speed, at which the aircraft can maintain directional control with one engine inoperative
It is called the minimum control speed
There are two types, VMCG and VMCA, for control on the ground and in the air respectively (though specific definitions do exist for each, and there are also take-off climb and landing climb variants)
learning.explanation: VMC is the lowest speed, at which the aircraft can maintain directional control with one engine inoperative. It is called the minimum control speed. There are two types, VMCG and VMCA, for control on the ground and in the air respectively (though specific definitions do exist for each, and there are also take-off climb and landing climb variants). If the question mentions VMC without specifying which type, you would usually assume VMCA, but in many cases it is the same answer regardless. VMCG is the lowest speed that the rudder is effective enough to counteract a sudden engine failure on take-off, and VMCA is the lowest speed where the rudder has enough authority in flight to keep the heading stable without banking after an engine failure. The major factor that affects VMC is the difference in engine thrust. VMC will therefore be lower at higher airport elevations and at a higher OAT, due to the associated lower thrust. If conditions are hot, high and humid the air is less dense. This reduces thrust and, consequently, when you lose the critical engine on take-off, there is less yawing moment from asymmetric thrust than there would be in denser air. It is effectively the only thing that "poor performance" is useful for. The less thrust, the smaller the asymmetry, the lower the VMC.

content.question:
Which of the following statements are true regarding the ASDA:
1. It includes all of the TORA
2. It includes a starter extension
3. It includes a stopway in the direction of take-off
4. It includes a stopway in both directions

key_points: ASDA Distance from the start of the take-off run to the nearest point in the direction of take-off at which the aircraft cannot roll over the surface and be brought to rest in case of an aborted take-off without risk of accident
ASDA consists of TORA plus the stopway if available
The ASDA is the Accelerate-Stopping Distance available, for use in case of a Rejected Take-Off (RTO)
learning.explanation: ASDA Distance from the start of the take-off run to the nearest point in the direction of take-off at which the aircraft cannot roll over the surface and be brought to rest in case of an aborted take-off without risk of accident. ASDA consists of TORA plus the stopway if available. The ASDA is the Accelerate-Stopping Distance available, for use in case of a Rejected Take-Off (RTO). The majority of the statements in this question are quite simple, the ASDA includes the TORA (Take-Off Run Available), and the stopway for the take-off runway, but not the clearway, nor the stopway for the opposite direction runway, as this is not always part of the "starter extension" discussed below. A starter extension is where a displaced threshold exists, and an aircraft can begin the take-off roll before the threshold of the runway. Therefore, any starter extension is part of the take-off run, and is included in the ASDA. However, the opposite runway stopway (if present) is not automatically considered a starter extension for the take-off runway, so is not included.

content.question: Does using engine bleed air affect the take-off performance?

options.A: No, it only affects the landing performance.
options.B: Yes, it increases the take-off performance.
options.C: Yes, it decreases the take-off performance.
options.D: No, it does not have an affect on the take-off performance.

key_points: Engine Bleed Air Whenever bleed air is extracted from an engine, and the value of the thrust setting parameter is appropriately reduced, the amount of thrust the engine generates is reduced
Therefore, the use of engine bleed air for air conditioning / pressurization reduces the airplane’s potential takeoff performance for a given set of runway length, temperature and altitude conditions
When required, using engine and/or wing anti-ice further decreases the performance on some airplane models
learning.explanation: Engine Bleed Air Whenever bleed air is extracted from an engine, and the value of the thrust setting parameter is appropriately reduced, the amount of thrust the engine generates is reduced. Therefore, the use of engine bleed air for air conditioning / pressurization reduces the airplane’s potential takeoff performance for a given set of runway length, temperature and altitude conditions. When required, using engine and/or wing anti-ice further decreases the performance on some airplane models. This “lost” thrust may be recoverable via increased takeoff EPR or N1 limits as indicated in the airplane operating manual. It depends on engine type, airplane model, and the specific atmospheric conditions.

content.question: A flight crew is due to collect an empty passenger jet from the manufacturer on an exceptionally cold winter day. What effects on the V speeds should the crew take into consideration in such a scenario?

options.A: The low weight and cold air will cause VR to be less than VMC.
options.B: VR and V2 would be equal.
options.C: V2MIN and consequently V2, would be restricted by VLOF.
options.D: V1 could be limited by VMCG.

key_points: Note: We have received feedback about a slightly simplified verson of this question (same question and options, but with a few less words) We do not know if it is just the feedback that is like this, or if the question has been changed slightly

Please let us know what you can remember from the exam if you see this, thank you! VMCG is defined as "the minimum CAS on the take-off run at which, on failure of the critical engine and with the remaining engine(s) at maximum take-off power, the pilot can retain control of the aircraft using the primary aerodynamic controls alone
" After an engine failure during take-off, if the decision is made to continue the take-off, then the asymmetric thrust will force the aircraft off the runway centre line
learning.explanation: Note: We have received feedback about a slightly simplified verson of this question (same question and options, but with a few less words) We do not know if it is just the feedback that is like this, or if the question has been changed slightly. Please let us know what you can remember from the exam if you see this, thank you! VMCG is defined as "the minimum CAS on the take-off run at which, on failure of the critical engine and with the remaining engine(s) at maximum take-off power, the pilot can retain control of the aircraft using the primary aerodynamic controls alone." After an engine failure during take-off, if the decision is made to continue the take-off, then the asymmetric thrust will force the aircraft off the runway centre line. The pilot will try to keep the aircraft straight with rudder application, producing an aerodynamic force. The rudder effectiveness increases with forward speed. Below the minimum control speed on the ground, VMCG, the aircraft cannot be kept straight. VEF (engine failure speed), therefore, must be greater than or equal to VMCG and as V1 is greater than VEF, it follows that V1 must be greater than VMCG. If V1 is less than VMCG, then the aircraft will not be able to be kept straight on the runway, if a "go" decision is made. If a range of decision speeds exists, that encompasses the VMCG as the highest speed which can be chosen to satisfy the requirement. If not, the TOM must be reduced until the range of speeds just encompasses VMCG and then V1 is set equal to VMCG. This creates a VMCG limited take-off mass. In most cases VMCG intrudes only on to the lowest decision speeds of a range. If this is the case, the speeds in the range below VMCG cannot be used. VMCG is most likely to be limiting where the asymmetric thrust is greatest: At low pressure altitudes At low temperature conditions At low humidity At short runways, leading to low values of V1, being derived from the One-Engine-Inoperative Field-Length-Limited calculation. The other options are incorrect because: A) VR cannot be less than 1.05 x VMC so can never be less than VMC. B) VR being the same as V2 would mean that no speed is expected to be gained between rotation and reaching 35 ft, which is very unlikely, particularly in these high power output conditions. C) Looking at the CS-25 regulations, the V2min and V2 are not legally limited by VLOF at all. The only time they could be technically limited by it is if the VLOF was too high to allow the V2 to be reached by screen height, which would not be the case on a high performance day such as this one (and it is debatable whether it would ever be able to happen at all)

content.question:
Which of the following items can limit the Maximum Permissible Landing Mass for a Quick Turnaround?
1. Aerodrome pressure altitude
2. Aerodrome temperature
3. Air conditioning packs ON/OFF
4. Flap setting
5. Runway slope
6. Use of reverse thrust
7. Wind component

key_points: Take a look at the attached figure taken from CAP 698 - you can clearly see that the Maximum Permissible Landing Mass for a Quick Turnaround is limited by the Aerodrome Pressure Altitude (1), Airport OAT (2), Flaps setting (4), Runway Slope (5) and Wind (7)

The Quick Turnaround limit is related to the wheel fusible alloy plugs that are designed to melt at a predetermined temperature to prevent the tyre exploding when its been subjected to high temperatures caused by heavy braking

After a brake application, the energy which the brake has absorbed is released as heat and until this heat is dissipated, the amount of additional energy which the brake can absorb without failure is reduced
learning.explanation: Take a look at the attached figure taken from CAP 698 - you can clearly see that the Maximum Permissible Landing Mass for a Quick Turnaround is limited by the Aerodrome Pressure Altitude (1), Airport OAT (2), Flaps setting (4), Runway Slope (5) and Wind (7). The Quick Turnaround limit is related to the wheel fusible alloy plugs that are designed to melt at a predetermined temperature to prevent the tyre exploding when its been subjected to high temperatures caused by heavy braking. After a brake application, the energy which the brake has absorbed is released as heat and until this heat is dissipated, the amount of additional energy which the brake can absorb without failure is reduced. Therefore, take-off planning must consider the effects of residual brake energy (or brake temperature) if the previous landing involved significant braking and/or the airplane turnaround is relatively short.

content.question: The Cost Index (CI) can be defined as the...

options.B: costs incurred by flying the aeroplane over time, divided by the cost of the fuel.
options.C: total fuel costs divided by the total flight time.
options.D: ratio of the actual cost of the fuel to the average price at a reference airport.

key_points: Cost Index The cost index is used to take into account the relationship between fuel-related costs and time-related costs
With time-related costs, the faster the aircraft is flown, the more money is saved in time costs
This is because the faster the aircraft is flown, the more miles can be flown for time-related components
learning.explanation: Cost Index The cost index is used to take into account the relationship between fuel-related costs and time-related costs. With time-related costs, the faster the aircraft is flown, the more money is saved in time costs. This is because the faster the aircraft is flown, the more miles can be flown for time-related components. It also means that more miles can be flown between inspections when considering maintenance costs. These costs are minimum at the maximum operating speed VMO/MMO. At high speed, the fuel burn increases and total fuel cost for the trip increases. Fuel costs on the other hand will be minimum at the maximum range cruise speed (MRC) and maximum at the maximum operating speed. Adding the time-related costs and fuel-related costs together produces a direct operating cost. Cost Index = Cost of Time ÷ Cost of Fuel

key_points: In an emergency descent, for instance a descent initiated by the pilot following depressurization, the aim is to reach FL100 as soon as possible
To achieve this requirement, the airplane would need to lose height with the maximum possible rate of descent
ROD (ft/m) = G/S x Gradient of Descend To maximize the ROD, the airspeed should be maximize within the operational limits of the aircraft
learning.explanation: In an emergency descent, for instance a descent initiated by the pilot following depressurization, the aim is to reach FL100 as soon as possible. To achieve this requirement, the airplane would need to lose height with the maximum possible rate of descent. ROD (ft/m) = G/S x Gradient of Descend To maximize the ROD, the airspeed should be maximize within the operational limits of the aircraft. At cruising altitude an airliner will be flying Mach no. so the operational limit is the MMO (Maximum Operating Mach Number). If airbrakes in use, the gradient of descend increases, consequently the ROD increases as well.

metadata.topic: 25/Applicable Operational Requirements Performance Class A – Theory

content.question: Under which condition should you fly considerably lower (4 000 ft or more) than the optimum altitude?

options.A: If at the lower altitude there is less tailwind.
options.B: If the maximum altitude is below the optimum altitude.
options.C: If at the lower altitude there is a greater headwind.
options.D: If at the lower altitude either considerably less headwind or considerably more tailwind can be expected.

key_points: Optimum Altitude Optimum altitude is defined as the pressure altitude for the best possible fuel efficiency in cruise, at which a given thrust setting results in the corresponding maximum range speed at a given weight and speed
As a result, if flown at a higher or lower pressure altitude than the optimum altitude will decrease the aircraft range
The optimum altitude is not constant and changes over the period of a long flight as atmospheric conditions and the weight of the aircraft change
learning.explanation: Optimum Altitude Optimum altitude is defined as the pressure altitude for the best possible fuel efficiency in cruise, at which a given thrust setting results in the corresponding maximum range speed at a given weight and speed. As a result, if flown at a higher or lower pressure altitude than the optimum altitude will decrease the aircraft range. The optimum altitude is not constant and changes over the period of a long flight as atmospheric conditions and the weight of the aircraft change. Optimum altitude increases with reducing aircraft weight: the drag curve will move down and to the left as the weight decreases through fuel burn. The aeroplane maximizes its specific range by remaining at the optimum altitude as it slowly increases (it must climb along the green line shown in the attached figure). As the optimum altitude increases, the specific range increases. However, for a number of reasons, ATC will probably not allow a cruise climb. The compromise between a level cruise and a cruise climb is a step climb. STEP CLIMB means that the airplane climbs to about 2000 ft above the optimum altitude and levels off. As fuel is used and weight falls, the optimum altitude will increase to a point where it is again 2000 ft above the airplane’s current level. And thereafter the climb process can be repeated. This is the most common way of operating jets in real life. The pilot should always aim to use the step climb technique to remain as close as possible to the optimum altitude. However, it can be beneficial to fly at an altitude other than the optimum altitude in case of, for example, significant tailwind at a different level - even if it means flying significantly below the Optimum Altitude. Or when experiencing severe turbulence at the Optimum Altitude.

content.question: During the initial climb out, the pilot is required to do a 15° turn to the left to avoid an obstacle. The total drag will:

options.A: Decrease and the climb gradient will increase.
options.B: Increase and the climb gradient will increase.
options.C: Increase and the climb gradient will decrease.
options.D: Decrease and the climb gradient will decrease.

key_points: Any manoeuvre such as a turn calls for more lift
Due to the bank angle of the aircraft, the lift vector is tilted, therefore only a component of lift counteracts weight
But since level flight must be maintained, the component of lift has to be equal to weight
learning.explanation: Any manoeuvre such as a turn calls for more lift. Due to the bank angle of the aircraft, the lift vector is tilted, therefore only a component of lift counteracts weight. But since level flight must be maintained, the component of lift has to be equal to weight. Consequently, lift must be increased. By increasing the bank angle, load factor increases. Due to increased lift, induced drag also increases producing greater drag, this in turn increases total drag. For a given aircraft mass the maximum climb gradient will occur when the excess thrust over drag is greatest. As seen above, the drag increases in a turn, provided that thrust remains the same, the climb gradient will decrease.

content.question:
Refer to figure.
Why has the chart not accounted for any wind?

options.A: There is a safety margin built-in.
options.B: The limitation shown in this chart is taken relative to air.
options.C: The effect of the wind must be taken from another chart.
options.D: The wind does not affect the climb angle relative to the ground.

key_points: The chart shown in the annex is the climb limited take-off mass chart
This chart uses the current conditions and gives you the maximum mass the aircraft can be in order to achieve the required still air climb gradients after take-off
This is usually the second segment climb gradient of the net take-off flight path (NTOFP) with an engine failure at V1
learning.explanation: The chart shown in the annex is the climb limited take-off mass chart. This chart uses the current conditions and gives you the maximum mass the aircraft can be in order to achieve the required still air climb gradients after take-off. This is usually the second segment climb gradient of the net take-off flight path (NTOFP) with an engine failure at V1. This is based on climb gradients in still air (relative to the air mass), and the wind therefore has no bearing on this mass. The wind does have an effect on an airport's specific FLLTOM (Field Length Limited Take-off Mass) and OLTOM (Obstacle Limited Take-off Mass), but they are not considered.

content.question: An aircraft is flying at VMCL. Following an engine failure, does the aircraft have sufficient performance for both approach and go-around?

options.A: Yes, the performance is good enough.
options.B: No, the aircraft is not able to continue the approach.
options.C: Only the approach can be flown.
options.D: Go-Around can only be flown over flat terrain.

key_points: VMCL is the minimum control speed during the approach and landing
It covers the situation where an aircraft is making an approach, in trim and with all engines operating, and then has to initiate a go-around at which point one engine fails
The immediate situation is that the live engine is at full go-around power and producing powerful yawing moments before the pilot has had time to re-trim the aircraft for that conditions
learning.explanation: VMCL is the minimum control speed during the approach and landing. It covers the situation where an aircraft is making an approach, in trim and with all engines operating, and then has to initiate a go-around at which point one engine fails. The immediate situation is that the live engine is at full go-around power and producing powerful yawing moments before the pilot has had time to re-trim the aircraft for that conditions. CS 25.149 Minimum control speed (f) (See AMC 25.149 (f)) VMCL, the minimum control speed during approach and landing with all engines operating, is the calibrated airspeed at which, when the critical engine is suddenly made inoperative, it is possible to maintain control of the aeroplane with that engine still inoperative, and maintain straight flight with an angle of bank of not more than 5º. VMCL must be established with – (1) The aeroplane in the most critical configuration (or, at the option of the applicant, each configuration) for approach and landing with all engines operating; (2) The most unfavourable centre of gravity; (3) The aeroplane trimmed for approach with all engines operating; (4) The most unfavourable weight, or, at the option of the applicant, as a function of weight; (5) For propeller aeroplanes, the propeller of the inoperative engine in the position it achieves without pilot action, assuming the engine fails while at the power or thrust necessary to maintain a 3 degree approach path angle; and (6) Go-around power or thrust setting on the operating engine(s).

metadata.topic: 25/Applicable Operational Requirements Performance Class A – Theory

content.question: What is the primary advantage of using the increased V2 (improved climb) procedure on take-off?

options.A: The associated higher V1 allows for an increased take-off mass.
options.B: The safety margin of the field-length limited mass is increased.
options.C: The obstacle-limited take-off mass is increased.
options.D: The time to reach the optimum altitude is reduced.

key_points: Take-off with Increased V2 Speed This procedure is used when the performance limited mass is the climb limit mass
At V2 the climbing performance is poor and limits the maximum take-off mass
It is important to understand that in the event of engine failure, the initial climb out speed is V2
learning.explanation: Take-off with Increased V2 Speed This procedure is used when the performance limited mass is the climb limit mass. At V2 the climbing performance is poor and limits the maximum take-off mass. It is important to understand that in the event of engine failure, the initial climb out speed is V2. However, V2 is not the best climb angle speed. V2 is considerably slower than the best angle of climb speed, which is VX. Climbing with a speed closer to the best angle of climb greatly enhance the climb performance. If runway available it would be possible to stay on the runway for longer during the take-off to build up more speed to a higher V1, this will ensure that at the screen height, a faster V2 will be reached, closer to VX. As a result of the improved climb performance, the climb limit mass can be increased.

content.question: The pilots are analysing the aircraft's fuel consumption whilst in the cruise, noticing that the fuel consumption is higher than planned. ATC instructs the pilot to descend at high speed. Which of the following speeds is the best to descend at?

options.C: Minimum drag to achieve maximum range

key_points: This is a strange question, as you have to read into the question and make a balanced judgement
Our feedback states that LRC (Long Range Cruise) is the correct answer
We think this is a fair answer, but there is definitely a range of interpretations for this question
learning.explanation: This is a strange question, as you have to read into the question and make a balanced judgement. Our feedback states that LRC (Long Range Cruise) is the correct answer. We think this is a fair answer, but there is definitely a range of interpretations for this question. We would be tempted to appeal this question if it came up in the exam in this form. Please let us know if you receive a similar question to this in the exam, the wording and the answer, thank you! As our aircraft has been using more fuel than expected, we want to conserve it over the rest of the flight, to make sure our reserves remain intact, and so that we do not have to divert. To do this, we would usually slow down and fly at the ECON (economy) speed, but ATC have asked us to descend at high speed. This is an odd request, but not unheard of. We could expedite our descent the most by descending at MMO/VMO but this would be very innefficient, and we would lose a lot of energy to drag unnnecessarily. In this case, we can choose to fly at LRC (Long Range Cruise). It is faster than ECON, but with not much more fuel burn. It means that we can both conserve fuel and obey ATC's request.

The aircraft will have a limit weight for a particular scenario based on the maximum tyre speed

The aircraft will have a limit weight for a particular scenario based on the maximum tyre speed. This is, of course, in reference to the ground speed at lift-off, as the tyre will be spinning at the rate of ground speed, not the airspeed. A tailwind will therefore make a tyre overspeed much more likely.

content.question: According to CS-25, there may be NO buffeting condition in normal flight, including configuration changes during the cruise, severe enough to interfere with the control of the aeroplane, to cause excessive fatigue to the crew, or to cause structural damage. Stall warning buffeting within these limits is allowable. There may be NO perceptible buffeting condition in the cruise configuration in straight flight at any speed up to VMO/MMO (except the stall warning buffeting). Which of the following statements is correct?

options.A: When buffet becomes noticeable, it will probably be so severe that the pilot will NOT be able to read the instruments or to control the aeroplane.
options.B: The aeroplane has entered an undesired state if high-speed buffet becomes perceptible and recovery from this may be impossible.
options.C: High-speed buffet may occur at speeds around VMO/MMO during manoeuvres away from straight flight.
options.D: NO high-speed buffet will occur at any speed up to VMO/MMO, unless the aeroplane is approaching the stall.

key_points: This question is making a statement about how an aircraft must be built to avoid buffet within certain parameters
Then you have to check each answer to decide which one fits the statement fully
We will now analyse each possible answer and find the most correct one
learning.explanation: This question is making a statement about how an aircraft must be built to avoid buffet within certain parameters. Then you have to check each answer to decide which one fits the statement fully. We will now analyse each possible answer and find the most correct one. When buffet becomes noticeable, it will probably be so severe that the pilot will NOT be able to read the instruments or to control the aeroplane. The statement does not mention that all buffet is severe buffet. Light buffet is possible also, and is easy to correct, with no lasting damage, so this is incorrect. The aeroplane has entered an undesired state if high-speed buffet becomes perceptible and recovery from this may be impossible. Again, a small amount of high-speed buffet is easy to handle and is definitely recoverable. Only severe buffet is undesirable and potentially unrecoverable, again, incorrect. NO high-speed buffet will occur at any speed up to VMO/MMO, unless the aeroplane is approaching the stall. The statement specified that there may be no perceptible buffeting condition in the cruise configuration in straight flight at any speed up to VMO/MMO (other than stall buffet). It only specifies straight flight though; and does not stop high-speed buffet during manoeuvres within this speed range. Therefore, buffet is possible within the speed range and this answer is incorrect. High-speed buffet may occur at speeds around VMO/MMO during manoeuvres away from straight flight. This is true; as said previously, there is no part of the statement that disallows high-speed buffet during manoeuvres, so it can occur.

content.question: During a climb after passing the cross-over altitude, which statement is correct?

options.A: TAS will decrease in the troposphere, and thereafter remain constant above the tropopause.
options.B: TAS will increase steadily throughout the climb.
options.C: TAS will remain constant throughout the climb.
options.D: TAS will fluctuate unpredictably during the climb.

key_points: This is a very similar question to Q329425, but differently phrased and with different options
Variation of TAS with Altitude at a Constant Mach Number Mach no
= TAS ÷ LSS then, TAS = Mach no
learning.explanation: This is a very similar question to Q329425, but differently phrased and with different options. Variation of TAS with Altitude at a Constant Mach Number Mach no. = TAS ÷ LSS then, TAS = Mach no. x LSS As altitude increases the temperature drops, local speed of sound decreases and therefore TAS decreases up to the tropopause, where the temperature remains the same with altitude, so the TAS then remains constant (parallel to the Mach No.). As altitude decreases the temperature will rise, local speed of sound will increase and TAS will increase. When we climb an aircraft, initially we maintain a constant IAS/CAS, and with decreasing air density this leads to TAS increasing steadily, but at the cross-over altitude (depicted as FL270 in the figure), we then change to maintaining a constant Mach No., which means our IAS/CAS reduces steadily, and our TAS decreases also. This happens until the tropopause is reached, when the temperature stops changing with altitude, and the TAS then remains constant.
