content.question: Which of the following statements concerning take-off speeds is correct?

options.D: V1 is lower or equal to VR.

key_points: V1 is called the decision speed
V1 determines the outcome of a critical decision that must be made following an engine failure or other major critical systems failure
V1 is defined as being the maximum speed at which the pilot must take the first action in order to stop the airplane within the remaining accelerate-stop distance
learning.explanation: V1 is called the decision speed. V1 determines the outcome of a critical decision that must be made following an engine failure or other major critical systems failure. V1 is defined as being the maximum speed at which the pilot must take the first action in order to stop the airplane within the remaining accelerate-stop distance. V1 is also the minimum speed following engine failure that the pilot is able to continue the take-off within the remaining take-off distance. Rotation speed, VR, is the speed at which the pilot initiates action to raise the nose gear off the ground, with the intention of becoming airborne. VR may not be less then decision speed V1.

metadata.topic: 25/Applicable Operational Requirements Performance Class A – Theory

content.question: When should an aeroplane perform a step climb?

options.A: Whenever possible to keep the cruise altitude close to the optimum altitude, in order to increase endurance.
options.B: Anytime between the top of climb and the top of descent, in order to increase endurance.
options.C: When approximately 2 000 ft below the optimum altitude, in order to increase range.
options.D: Anytime between the top of climb and the top of descent in order to increase fuel mileage.

key_points: The optimum flight profile for a jet aircraft requires a climb after take-off to the optimum altitude
Once you have achieved your initial optimum cruise altitude, flying at 1
32 VMD (best range speed for jet aircraft) and with the engines at around 90% RPM, the fuel burn will reduce the aircraft weight
learning.explanation: The optimum flight profile for a jet aircraft requires a climb after take-off to the optimum altitude. Once you have achieved your initial optimum cruise altitude, flying at 1.32 VMD (best range speed for jet aircraft) and with the engines at around 90% RPM, the fuel burn will reduce the aircraft weight. As the weight decreases, both VMD and the induced drag decrease. This means that in level flight, 90% thrust will accelerate you beyond 1.32 VMD, in effect your optimum altitude has increased. In order to avoid this, the aircraft can be put into either a cruise climb or step climb. Air Traffic Control probably will not allow a cruise climb, because it is a very very slow climb during cruise, so that the aircraft is always at the optimum altitude, where 90% RPM always gives the best range speed. The step climb is the most common way of operating jets in the cruise in real life. It is a compromise between a level cruise and a cruise climb, where the aircraft initially climbs to the nearest level and reaches a little above the optimum altitude and then fly level for a while, reducing thrust as the weight reduces to maintain the best range speed. As the weight reduces, the optimum level rises through your level and then, when the aircraft is 1 000 ft to 2 000 ft below the optimum altitude, you can climb again to the next ATC-approved level available above the optimum and so on.

content.question:
You are flying an aircraft with an ACN of 34 upon landing. For the next departure, your ACN is 38. Considering the following PCNs for the airport you are flying to, are there any operational concerns?
Runway PCN: 47
Taxiway PCN: 36
Apron PCN: 42
For this exercise, disregard tire pressure and pavement strength, which are usually taken into account.

options.A: There is a risk while operating before take-off due to the PCN of the taxiway.
options.B: There are no concerns about the operation of your aircraft.
options.C: There are risks due to Landing ACN being less than the reported Runway PCN.
options.D: There is a risk when the aircraft operates before Take-Off since the Apron PCN is higher than the Aircraft's ACN upon departure.

key_points: The operating mass of the aircraft may be limited by runway strength considerations

The runway should be of sufficient strength to support normal operations of the most demanding aircraft without risk of damage either to the aeroplane or the runway The bearing strength of a pavement is expressed by a pavement classification number (PCN) and this is compared to the aircraft classification number (ACN) at maximum structural takeoff limit mass
The PCN is also a number which represents the load-bearing strength of the pavement in terms of the highest ACN which can be accepted on the pavement for unrestricted use
learning.explanation: The operating mass of the aircraft may be limited by runway strength considerations. The runway should be of sufficient strength to support normal operations of the most demanding aircraft without risk of damage either to the aeroplane or the runway The bearing strength of a pavement is expressed by a pavement classification number (PCN) and this is compared to the aircraft classification number (ACN) at maximum structural takeoff limit mass. The PCN is also a number which represents the load-bearing strength of the pavement in terms of the highest ACN which can be accepted on the pavement for unrestricted use. Therefore, the PCN is compared to the ACN and operation on the pavement (runway and taxiways) is permissible if the ACN is less than or equal to the PCN (ACN ≤ PCN).

content.question: In the CS-25 specifications VREF must not be lower than the greater of 1.23 VSR0, VMCL or any other speed that provides a minimum level of controllability. In this context, VSR0 is a speed NOT less than...

options.A: the stall speed in a specific configuration where the aeroplane remains controllable and possible to recover.
options.B: the minimum steady flight speed at which the aeroplane is controllable when in the landing configuration.
options.C: the speed when the aeroplane shows the distinctive behaviour associated with defining a stall, when in the landing configuration.
options.D: the speed when the aeroplane, in landing configuration, reaches CLMAX and the load factor is equal to or greater than 1.

key_points: Learning Objective 032
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 032.04.06.02.04: Define and explain the following speeds in accordance with CS-25 or CS-Definitions: reference stall speed in the landing configuration (VSR0); reference landing speed (VREF); - minimum control speed, approach and landing (VMCL). VSR is the reference stall speed of an aircraft. It is a figure provided by the manufacturer that can be used to work out speeds such as VREF, VR, V2, etc. It cannot be less than the VS1G speed. It can be split into VSR1 and VSR0. VSR1 is the reference stall speed in a particular configuration (so can have many different values, depending on configuration), whereas VSR0 is the reference stall speed in the landing configuration. VS1G is the speed at which the aircraft reaches the CLMAX with the lift equal to the aircraft weight (load factor of 1). Even though the reference stall speed is not formally defined by a particular condition, we can see from the information above that VSR0 is a speed at or above the speed an aircraft reaches CLMAX in the landing configuration with a load factor equal to 1 (or greater than 1 even, but that would be an unusual case). The other options are cleverly written to draw you in, but are either not real speeds, or talking about speeds such as VMCL or VS.

content.question: What is the effect of taking-off with TOGA instead of the calculated reduced thrust?

options.A: TODA, TORA, ASDA, and the climb gradient will decrease.
options.B: TODA, TORA, ASDA, and the climb gradient will increase.
options.C: The ASDR decreases and the climb gradient increases.
options.D: The ASDR and the climb gradient decrease.

key_points: A reduced thrust takeoff is a take-off that is accomplished utilising less thrust than the engines are capable of producing under the existing conditions of temperature and pressure altitude
The procedure can be used any time the actual take-off mass is less than the maximum permissible take-off mass and there is an available distance that greatly exceeds that which is required
Using Maximum Take-Off Thrust Set (TOGA) will result in an increased take-off performance
learning.explanation: A reduced thrust takeoff is a take-off that is accomplished utilising less thrust than the engines are capable of producing under the existing conditions of temperature and pressure altitude. The procedure can be used any time the actual take-off mass is less than the maximum permissible take-off mass and there is an available distance that greatly exceeds that which is required. Using Maximum Take-Off Thrust Set (TOGA) will result in an increased take-off performance. Therefore, in order to increase the safety margin in case of any system failure, emergency or adverse weather conditions the pilot can decide to proceed with the normal configuration with the Maximum Take-Off Thrust Set (TOGA). => Using TOGA, you will reach V1 quicker, you will then have more length to stop within ASD, thus lowering the ASDR. => Using TOGA = improved performance = improved climb gradient.

2%, with the engines at the power or thrust that is available 8 seconds after initiation of movement of the power or thrust controls from the minimum flight idle to the go-around power or thrust setting

[.] EASA CS 25.121 - Climb: one-engine inoperative [.] (d) Approach: In a configuration corresponding to the normal all-engines-operating procedure in which VSR for this configuration does not exceed 110% of the VSR for the related all-engines-operating landing configuration: (1) The steady gradient of climb may not be less than 2.1% for two-engined aeroplanes, 2.4% for three-engined aeroplanes and 2.7% for four-engined aeroplanes, with: (i) The critical engine inoperative, the remaining engines at the go-around power or thrust setting; (ii) The maximum landing weight; (iii) A climb speed established in connection with normal landing procedures, but not more than 1.4 VSR; and (iv) Landing gear retracted. content.question: When a landing is performed above the Maximum Quick Turnaround Mass, the pilot must...

options.A: wait for a specified time before the next take-off.
options.C: avoid vacating the runway via the high speed taxiway.
options.D: reduce the speed at touchdown in order to avoid a tailstrike.

key_points: The Quick Turnaround limit is related to the wheel fusible alloy plugs that are designed to melt at a predetermined temperature to prevent the tyre exploding when it's been subjected to high temperatures caused by heavy braking

After a brake application, the energy which the brake has absorbed is released as heat and until this heat is dissipated, the amount of additional energy which the brake can absorb without failure is reduced

Therefore, take-off planning must consider the effects of residual brake energy (or brake temperature) if the previous landing involved significant braking and/or the airplane turnaround is relatively short or the Maximum Quick Turnaround Mass has been exceeded
learning.explanation: The Quick Turnaround limit is related to the wheel fusible alloy plugs that are designed to melt at a predetermined temperature to prevent the tyre exploding when it's been subjected to high temperatures caused by heavy braking. After a brake application, the energy which the brake has absorbed is released as heat and until this heat is dissipated, the amount of additional energy which the brake can absorb without failure is reduced. Therefore, take-off planning must consider the effects of residual brake energy (or brake temperature) if the previous landing involved significant braking and/or the airplane turnaround is relatively short or the Maximum Quick Turnaround Mass has been exceeded. If the actual landing mass exceeds the Maximum Quick Turnaround Mass, then you would have to wait a specified time and after this time, you would have to re-check the wheels to make sure that they have not deflated.

metadata.topic: 25/Applicable Operational Requirements Performance Class A – Theory

content.question:
The crew of a Medium-Range Jet Transport aeroplane are planning for a Commercial Air Transport flight departing from Mykonos (LGMK) Runway 16, which is 1902 m long with a take-off path over the sea. The aeroplane has three take-off flap settings, which give the following maximum take-off masses:
T/O 1: 1 stage of slats and 1 stage of flaps - 78.1 tonnes.
T/O 2: 2 stages of slats and 2 stages of flaps - 81.1 tonnes.
T/O 3: 2 stages of slats and 3 stages of flaps - 82.9 tonnes.
These maximum take-off masses are limited by the...

options.A: Field-Length Limited Take-Off Mass (FLLTOM), which is a factor with short runways and will increase with more slats/flaps.
options.B: Accelerate-Stop Distance Mass (ASDM), which is a factor with long runways and will increase with more slats/flaps.
options.C: Climb Limit Mass from the 2nd segment, which is a factor with close-in obstacles and will increase with more slats/flaps.
options.D: Climb-Limited Take-Off Mass (CLTOM), which is a factor independent of obstacles and will increase with more slats/flaps.

key_points: This appears to be a common topic of questions, with two other questions (323946 and 328175 both contain similar situations, but asking different questions about it)
When we do our take-off performance calculations for a specific runway in specific conditions, the main factor (and often the figure we are trying to find) is our maximum take-off mass (MTOM)
In actual fact, there are many different MTOMs, and we have to find the most limiting, which will be the lowest of the set
learning.explanation: This appears to be a common topic of questions, with two other questions (323946 and 328175 both contain similar situations, but asking different questions about it). When we do our take-off performance calculations for a specific runway in specific conditions, the main factor (and often the figure we are trying to find) is our maximum take-off mass (MTOM). In actual fact, there are many different MTOMs, and we have to find the most limiting, which will be the lowest of the set. This is called our RTOM (regulated take-off mass), and is the most limiting of our climb limited take-off mass (CLTOM), obstacle limited take-off mass (OLTOM), field length limiting take-off mass (FLLTOM) and maximum structural take-off mass (MSTOM). The most limiting (smallest value) of these will be the one where our aircraft will struggle most for performance, so if we have a long runway surrounded by mountains, then we will likely be limited by the obstacle limited take-off mass, as its value will be lower than all the others. The questions asks which is the likely limiting mass for this runway, giving us the RTOM for all 3 of the aircraft's allowable takeoff flap settings. We can see that the flap settings using MORE flaps increases the RTOM, so the limiting weight must be one that increases with extra flaps. The only part of the takeoff where extra flaps improve performance is the takeoff roll, which is made shorter by greater flap settings, as we can rotate and lift off at a slower speed. Therefore, the limiting weight is the FLLTOM, and it does increase with greater flap settings. This also stands to reason, as the runway is relatively short (for a MRJT aircraft) with a departure over the sea, where obstacle clearance is not a problem. To go through each option: "Field-Length Limited Take-Off Mass (FLLTOM), which is a factor with short runways and will increase with more slats/flaps." This is correct, as mentioned above. "Accelerate-Stop Distance Mass (ASDM), which is a factor with long runways and will increase with more slats/flaps." The ASDM is not a recognised term, and if we take it literally, it would be a factor on short runways, not long ones. "Climb Limit Mass from the 2nd segment, which is a factor with close-in obstacles and will increase with more slats/flaps." The CLTOM (Climb Limited Takeoff Mass) has nothing to do with the obstacles, and would not increase with extra flaps, it would decrease. "Climb-Limited Take-Off Mass (CLTOM), which is a factor independent of obstacles and will increase with more slats/flaps." The CLTOM would decrease with more slats/flaps, due to flaps worsening the climb gradient.

metadata.topic: 25/Applicable Operational Requirements Performance Class A – Theory

content.question: On a segment of the take-off flight path an obstacle requires a minimum gradient of climb of 2.6% in order to provide an adequate margin of safe clearance. At a mass of 110 000 kg the gradient of climb is 2.8%. For the same power and assuming that the sine of the angle of climb varies inversely with mass, at what maximum mass will the aeroplane be able to achieve the minimum gradient?

key_points: There are three ways of solving this exercise: 1) Use the formula: (old / new) x mass = new mass (2
6) x 110 000 kg = 118 461 kg 2) Use the climb gradient formula: Climb Gradient = ((Thrust - Drag) ÷ Weight) × 100 2
learning.explanation: There are three ways of solving this exercise: 1) Use the formula: (old / new) x mass = new mass (2.8 / 2.6) x 110 000 kg = 118 461 kg 2) Use the climb gradient formula: Climb Gradient = ((Thrust - Drag) ÷ Weight) × 100 2.8 = (constant ÷ 110 000) × 100 constant = 3 080 Now use the same formula with the value of 2.6% climb gradient and the constant of 3 080: 2.6 = (3 080 ÷ New Mass) × 100 New Mass = 3 080 ÷ 2.6 × 100 New Mass = 118 461 kg 3) For a more precise result, remember the question's instruction "the sine of the angle of climb varies inversely with mass": 110 000 x sin 2.8 / sin 2.6 = 118 455 kg

metadata.topic: 25/Applicable Operational Requirements Performance Class A – Theory

content.question:
You have reached the top of descent and you are cleared to start descending down to FL100. How will your descent profile be affected, if you fly at constant descent speed of Mach 0.78 and forget to switch over from Mach to IAS at the appropriate crossover altitude?
A descent with a constant speed of Mach 0.78 will result in (1) _____ IAS and (2) _____ rate of descent.

key_points: A usefool tool in determining the changing relationship between EAS, CAS, TAS and Mach in climbs and descents below the tropopause, is the ECTM graphs
CAS can be considered to be identical to IAS

The ECTM graphs are used to determine what happens to the other three speeds when climbing or descending, whilst holding one speed constant, by drawing initially the parameter that is to be held constant as a vertical line and drawing, later, connecting lines to the remaining letters
learning.explanation: A usefool tool in determining the changing relationship between EAS, CAS, TAS and Mach in climbs and descents below the tropopause, is the ECTM graphs. CAS can be considered to be identical to IAS. The ECTM graphs are used to determine what happens to the other three speeds when climbing or descending, whilst holding one speed constant, by drawing initially the parameter that is to be held constant as a vertical line and drawing, later, connecting lines to the remaining letters. The lines are always in the sequence "ECTM", in the standard atmosphere and the speed held constant is drawn vertically. Thus, according to the ECTM graph, during descent with a constant Mach speed, the IAS/CAS increases. As for the rate of descent, it is known that IAS is increasing. The Sine of Descent angle is given by the formula: Sin Descent angle = (D - T) / W. Since we move away from the VMD, the excess of drag over thrust will increase and the glide angle will become steeper (increased glide angle). The Rate of Climb is given by the formula: ROC = Sin glide angle x TAS. Thus, with a steeper angle, the Rate of Climb will increase. NOTE: Crossover altitude is the altitude where the climb changes from a fixed IAS to a fixed Mach number or the descent changes from a fixed Mach number to a fixed IAS.

metadata.topic: 25/Applicable Operational Requirements Performance Class A – Theory

content.question: You are flying to a destination with limited fuel services and a short runway. To minimise fuel uplift requirements at the destination you plan to land with the maximum amount of fuel possible. What factor might limit your landing mass?

options.A: High OAT as it leads to a higher groundspeed.
options.B: Low OAT as it leads to a lower groundspeed.
options.C: A runway upslope as it increases landing distance.
options.D: A runway downslope as it leads to a reduced landing distance.

key_points: The target threshold speed is an IAS and will be the same for all combinations of pressure and temperature
Also, the threshold speed increases as mass increases and an increase in mass increases the landing distance considerably
Also, the Groundspeed is based on the TAS, plus ir minus the wind component
learning.explanation: The target threshold speed is an IAS and will be the same for all combinations of pressure and temperature. Also, the threshold speed increases as mass increases and an increase in mass increases the landing distance considerably. Also, the Groundspeed is based on the TAS, plus ir minus the wind component. The speed at touchdown that concerns us is the true Groundspeed and is affected in turn by the air density. Overspeed landings can invalidate the field length calculation and easily lead to an overrun. For this question, so as to land within the short runway, the increased mass, because of the extra carried fuel, will increase the landing distance required (LDR). If the air density is low, because of the the high pressure altitude or the high temperature, then the TAS will be higher for a given IAS. Thus, the true Groundspeed will be also higher. The combination of an increased landing mass and high OAT, which leads to a higher Groundspeed, may increase the LDR beyond the LDA, especially on a short runway. In these temperature conditions, the landing mass must be decreased until the LDR is equal or the LDA.

metadata.topic: 25/Applicable Operational Requirements Performance Class A – Theory

content.question: Descending at a constant IAS in standard atmospheric conditions, which of the following is correct?

options.A: EAS increases, TAS and Mach number decrease.
options.B: EAS decreases, TAS and Mach number increase.
options.C: EAS, TAS, and Mach number remain constant.
options.D: EAS remains constant, TAS and Mach number decrease.

key_points: The 4 different airspeeds are all linked
Starting from the beginning; EAS - Equivalent Airspeed is the CAS, corrected for compressibility at different altitude
CAS/IAS - Indicated airspeed is the dynamic pressure measured in a pitot tube, and Calibrated Airspeed is that, just corrected for instrument and position errors
learning.explanation: The 4 different airspeeds are all linked. Starting from the beginning; EAS - Equivalent Airspeed is the CAS, corrected for compressibility at different altitude. CAS/IAS - Indicated airspeed is the dynamic pressure measured in a pitot tube, and Calibrated Airspeed is that, just corrected for instrument and position errors. They are usually within a couple of knots of each other, so often considered the same. TAS - True Airspeed is the actual speed of air particles passing the airframe. It is the CAS corrected for density. Mach Number - This is the TAS as a percentage of the local speed of sound. There is a very simple graph that can be drawn to measure the changes in these airspeeds with altitude. It is the ECTM graph (EAS, CAS, TAS, Mach), and the common advice is to "Eat Chicken Tikka Masala", which reminds us of the order to use. The airspeed which is being maintained can be made as a vertical line, then all the other lines around it spread outwards from the bottom to the top. See the annex above. CAS/IAS is remaining constant, so is the vertical line. When climbing, go up each line, and go down each line to descend, the direction they go laterally tells us whether that measure increases or decreases in value. Therefore, when descending as shown on the diagram, the Mach number line goes to the left, and therefore the Mach Number decreases. When climbing, the opposite occurs, and the Mach Number would be increasing. The graph is different for each airspeed that is maintained, and there are modifications to TAS vs Mach for inversions and isothermal layers. From that point the rest of this question is incredibly simple, descending at a constant CAS/IAS, the EAS increases, the TAS and the Mach number decrease.

metadata.topic: 25/Applicable Operational Requirements Performance Class A – Theory

content.question: This formula for calculating the dynamic hydroplaning speed distinguishes between rotating and non-rotating tyres. Which of the following statements best describes the most limiting speed for an aircraft operating on a wet runway?

options.A: Hydroplaning speed is lowest for low-pressure rotating tyres and can be calculated using the aircraft mass multiplied by the tyre pressure.
options.B: The hydroplaning speed of rotating tyres is lower, because there is a higher risk of hydroplaning during the roll-out phase.
options.C: Hydroplaning speed depends only on the amount of standing water and tyre rotation, and can be calculated using the aircraft mass multiplied by the amount of standing water.
options.D: The hydroplaning speed of non-rotating tyres is lower, because there is a higher risk of hydroplaning immediately following wheel spin-up during touchdown.

key_points: Dynamic hydroplaning is an event which occurs when water forms a wedge between a tyre and the ground, effectively creating a barrier that stops the tyre gaining any traction, and therefore any braking ability, from the runway
It happens above the hydroplaning speed, which is calculated depending on the tyre pressure and whether the tyre is rotating or non-rotating at the time
(non-rotating is referring to landing, before the wheels spin up)
learning.explanation: Dynamic hydroplaning is an event which occurs when water forms a wedge between a tyre and the ground, effectively creating a barrier that stops the tyre gaining any traction, and therefore any braking ability, from the runway. It happens above the hydroplaning speed, which is calculated depending on the tyre pressure and whether the tyre is rotating or non-rotating at the time. (non-rotating is referring to landing, before the wheels spin up). A higher hydroplaning speed is better. If rotating, Hydroplaning speed = 9 x √(Tyre Pressure (psi)) If not rotating, Hydroplaning speed = 7.7 x √(Tyre Pressure (psi)) The non-rotating tyres hydroplane easier (e.g. at a slower speed) as they require extra traction to spin up, which is more easily stopped by the ‘water barrier’ than if they were already spinning. Note: The aircraft mass does not directly affect hydroplaning speed.

metadata.topic: 25/Applicable Operational Requirements Performance Class A – Theory

content.question: On approach to an aerodrome, the runway is reported to be wet due to a recent rain shower. There are tyre marks in the touchdown zone on both ends of the runway. The runway is very long so there is no need to apply heavy braking, however there is some crosswind. After touchdown, which of the following may be expected to occur?

options.A: Dynamic hydroplaning due to the standing water, but it will not have any effect due to the low braking.
options.B: Dynamic hydroplaning at low speed when turning off the runway.
options.C: Viscous hydroplaning in the areas of the rubber deposits, which could reduce directional control.
options.D: Reverted rubber hydroplaning due to the skidding caused by the crosswind.

key_points: Note: There is a very similar question to this that is seen less commonly, and with feedback that is not quite as complete, question 328148
Hydroplaning is caused by a thin layer of fluid that separates the tires from the runway
It causes substantial reduction in friction between the airplane tires and the runway surface and results in poor/no braking action
learning.explanation: Note: There is a very similar question to this that is seen less commonly, and with feedback that is not quite as complete, question 328148. Hydroplaning is caused by a thin layer of fluid that separates the tires from the runway. It causes substantial reduction in friction between the airplane tires and the runway surface and results in poor/no braking action. High aircraft speed, standing water, slush, and a smooth runway texture are factors conductive to hydroplaning. Dynamic hydroplaning occurs when there is standing water or slush on the runway deeper than the tread depth of the tyres. A wedge of water builds up, lifting the tires away from the runway surface. The speed of the airplane, the depth of the water, and the air pressure in the tires are some of the factors that affect dynamic hydroplaning. Viscous hydroplaning can occur when oil or accumulated rubber combines with water on a runway, it forms a very thin, impenetrable layer of slippery liquid your tires can’t break through. This is especially problematic on smooth runways, and it can occur on just a thin film of water. Viscous hydroplaning typically occurs in the touchdown zone of the runway, where you get a build-up of black rubber deposit. Reverted rubber hydroplaning is the result of a prolonged locked-wheel skid, in which reverted rubber acts as a seal between the tire and the runway. Entrapped water is heated to form steam, which supports the tire off the pavement. Particularly important in this question is the mention of the rubber deposits in the touchdown zone and the runway being wet (indicating viscous hydroplaning). As an extra help, the examiner says that the runway is long so heavy braking is not required, and is also wet, removing the possibility of reverted rubber hydroplaning. The crosswind is the only real problem here, as the lack of traction in the touchdown zone is not a massive issue for braking, but directional control may be difficult if the gear cannot gain traction in crosswind conditions.

metadata.topic: 25/Applicable Operational Requirements Performance Class A – Theory

content.question: An aeroplane is conducting a 6 hour sector flying from North Africa to Europe. The initial cruising altitude is FL340 with the recommended maximum being FL390. Normally the optimum cruising altitude is 500 ft to 2 500 ft below the recommended maximum and the recommended maximum altitude increases by 100 ft for every 10 minutes of flight time as the fuel burns off. On this occasion the FMS computes an optimum altitude of FL340 for the entire flight. What could be the reason for it not recommending a step climb to FL370 or higher?

options.A: The FMS has not been programmed properly with the correct aeroplane weights, thus giving inaccurate information.
options.B: Normally it is more efficient to stay at lower altitudes to take advantage of a higher TAS for the same Mach number.
options.C: The wind component at higher altitudes is less favourable, offsetting the increased fuel burn at the lower altitude.
options.D: The aeroplane is too heavy for any higher altitudes during the course of the flight to allow for a 2 000 ft climb.

key_points: There are some situations in which the pilots may decide not to make use of the step climb method and yet obtain better overall performance

One of them would be to make use of advantageous meteorological conditions such as staying within the core of a tailwind jet stream to reduce the air distance to be travelled, flight time and associated fuel consumption
Rather than blindly going +2 000 or -2 000 feet (or whatever is required in RVSM) from optimum, use your wind forecasts and tradeoff tables to figure out when you should climb
learning.explanation: There are some situations in which the pilots may decide not to make use of the step climb method and yet obtain better overall performance. One of them would be to make use of advantageous meteorological conditions such as staying within the core of a tailwind jet stream to reduce the air distance to be travelled, flight time and associated fuel consumption. Rather than blindly going +2 000 or -2 000 feet (or whatever is required in RVSM) from optimum, use your wind forecasts and tradeoff tables to figure out when you should climb. Depending on the specific airplane, altitude range, and wind situation, staying low may actually use less fuel.

content.question:
Which statements are true regarding the 4th segment of the net take-off flight path?
1. Flaps and slat are extended.
2. Flaps and slats are retracted.
3. The landing gear is extended.
4. The landing gear is retracted.
5. This segment is flown at the V2 speed.
6. This segment is flown on maximum continuous thrust.

key_points: Segments of the Take-off Climb For a class A aircraft, one engine inoperative, the T/O climb is divided into 4 segments: The take-off flight path starts once the take-off is complete, at 35 ft with the airplane at V2 with one engine inoperative
On a wet runway, the screen height is reduced to 15 ft
Operating engines are at take-off thrust, the flaps/slats are in take-off configuration and landing gear retraction is initiated once safely airborne with positive climb
learning.explanation: Segments of the Take-off Climb For a class A aircraft, one engine inoperative, the T/O climb is divided into 4 segments: The take-off flight path starts once the take-off is complete, at 35 ft with the airplane at V2 with one engine inoperative. On a wet runway, the screen height is reduced to 15 ft. Operating engines are at take-off thrust, the flaps/slats are in take-off configuration and landing gear retraction is initiated once safely airborne with positive climb. The first segment ends when the landing gear is fully retracted. Begins when the landing gear is fully retracted. Engines are at take-off thrust and the flaps/slats are in the take-off configuration. This segment ends at the higher of 400 ft. Begins at 400 ft or higher specified acceleration altitude. Engines are at take-off thrust and the aircraft is accelerated in level flight. Slats/flaps are retracted on speed. The segment ends when aircraft is in clean configuration and the final take-off speed has been achieved. Once this has happened, thrust can be reduced from maximum take-off thrust, TOGA, to maximum continuous thrust, MCT. Starts when the flaps are fully retracted, the final segment speed is achieved, and the thrust is set to maximum continuous thrust. The landing gear is retracted, of course, after segment 1. From this point the airplane is climbed to at or above 1500 ft (depending on terrain/obstacles), where the take-off flight path ends. The climb gradient for this last stage must not be less than 1.2%. 1st Segment 2nd Segment 3rd Segment 4th Segment Starts 35 ft Gear Up > 400 ft AGL Flaps Up VFTO MCT Action Select Gear Up Climb to > 400 ft AGL Retract Flaps Accelerate to VFTO Set MCT Climb to MINIMUM 1500 ft AGL Gradient for 2 Engines > 0% > 2.4% N/A > 1.2% Gradient for 3 Engines > 0.3% > 2.7% N/A > 1.5% Gradient for 4 Engines > 0.5% > 3.0% N/A > 1.7%

content.question: A pilot is flying to a destination close to the aeroplane maximum range, flying at maximum range cruise speed, with NO significant forecast winds. However, during the flight the pilot experienced a headwind. To achieve maximum range over the ground, the pilot should…

options.A: Decrease the airspeed compared to the speed for maximum cruise with NO wind.
options.B: Continue to fly at an airspeed equal to speed for maximum cruise with NO wind.
options.C: Fly at an airspeed equal to the maximum endurance speed.
options.D: Increase the airspeed compared to the speed for maximum cruise with NO wind.

key_points: The maximum range is obtained when the most miles are travelled for every amount of fuel
The air range improves as the Specific Fuel Consumption (SFC) reduces and is also dependent on the best ratio of TAS to Drag or TAS to Power required
Thus, the best TAS/Drag or TAS/Pwr Required ratio occurs at the tangent to the drag or power required curve, correspondingly
learning.explanation: The maximum range is obtained when the most miles are travelled for every amount of fuel. The air range improves as the Specific Fuel Consumption (SFC) reduces and is also dependent on the best ratio of TAS to Drag or TAS to Power required. Thus, the best TAS/Drag or TAS/Pwr Required ratio occurs at the tangent to the drag or power required curve, correspondingly. Unlike endurance, range is affected by the horizontal wind component (headwind or tailwind). Theory suggests you should fly slightly slower in a tailwind and slightly faster in a headwind. This can be illustrated by plotting the tangent to the drag curve at different groundspeeds assuming for simplicity Sea Level ISA conditions and therefore TAS=IAS. NOTE: The headwinds require greater speed changes than tailwinds.

content.question: A pilot is asked by ATC to descend to FL120 at a point 50 NM away. He/she realizes he/she won’t make it. What should the pilot do?

options.A: Descend at MMO until changeover altitude, switch to IAS as long as you don’t exceed VMO. Use speed brakes if needed.
options.B: Descend at MMO all the way down to FL120. Use speed brakes if needed.
options.C: Descend at VMO all the way to FL120 without speed brakes.

key_points: To maximize the ROD, the airspeed should be maximized within the operational limits of the aircraft
At cruising altitude an airliner will be flying Mach number, so the operational limit is the MMO (Maximum Operating Mach Number)
However, if the aircraft keeps descending at a constant Mach, the TAS and IAS will keep increasing, leading to a VMO overspeed situation
learning.explanation: To maximize the ROD, the airspeed should be maximized within the operational limits of the aircraft. At cruising altitude an airliner will be flying Mach number, so the operational limit is the MMO (Maximum Operating Mach Number). However, if the aircraft keeps descending at a constant Mach, the TAS and IAS will keep increasing, leading to a VMO overspeed situation. Therefore, at the changeover altitude, the flight crew must stop flying at a Mach number and fly at constant IAS. Thus, the aircraft would initially descend at MMO, at the crossover altitude the limiting speed will become VMO. With airbrakes in use, the gradient of descend increases, consequently the ROD increases as well.

content.question: The take-off runway performance requirements for transport category aeroplanes are based upon:

options.B: failure of the critical engine or all engines operating whichever requirement gives the greater distance.
options.D: failure of the critical engine only.

key_points: CS 25

113 Take-off distance and takeoff run (a) Take-off distance on a dry runway is the greater of – (1) The horizontal distance along the take-off path from the start of the take-off to the point at which the aeroplane is 11 m (35 ft) above the take-off surface, determined under CS 25

111 for a dry runway; or (2) 115% of the horizontal distance along the take-off path, with all engines operating, from the start of the take-off to the point at which the aeroplane is 11 m (35 ft) above the take-off surface, as determined by a procedure consistent with CS 25
learning.explanation: CS 25.113 Take-off distance and takeoff run (a) Take-off distance on a dry runway is the greater of – (1) The horizontal distance along the take-off path from the start of the take-off to the point at which the aeroplane is 11 m (35 ft) above the take-off surface, determined under CS 25.111 for a dry runway; or (2) 115% of the horizontal distance along the take-off path, with all engines operating, from the start of the take-off to the point at which the aeroplane is 11 m (35 ft) above the take-off surface, as determined by a procedure consistent with CS 25.111. (See AMC 25.113(a)(2), (b)(2) and (c)(2).) (c) If the take-off distance does not include a clearway, the take-off run is equal to the take-off distance. If the take-off distance includes a clearway – (1) The take-off run on a dry runway is the greater of – (i) The horizontal distance along the take-off path from the start of the takeoff to a point equidistant between the point at which VLOF is reached and the point at which the aeroplane is 11 m (35 ft) above the take-off surface, as determined under CS 25.111 for a dry runway; or (ii) 115% of the horizontal distance along the take-off path, with all engines operating, from the start of the take-off to a point equidistant between the point at which VLOF is reached and the point at which the aeroplane is 11 m (35 ft) above the take-off surface, determined by a procedure consistent with CS 25.111. (See AMC 25.113(a)(2), (b)(2) and (c)(2).) As you can see from the above regulation, the take-off performance will be determined on the greater distance of "all engines operating" and "failure of critical engine".

content.question: A crew is cruising at LRC when they realize the fuel consumption is too high. They decide to decrease airspeed. This will (1) _____ fuel flow and (2) _____ speed stability.

key_points: The advantage of flying at the maximum range speed is simply that the airplane will use the least amount of fuel and therefore have the least fuel cost for a given distance
Operationally a faster “long range cruise” is often used
This speed is used because, by getting to destination more quickly, more revenue earning flights can be carried out over a given period
learning.explanation: The advantage of flying at the maximum range speed is simply that the airplane will use the least amount of fuel and therefore have the least fuel cost for a given distance. Operationally a faster “long range cruise” is often used. This speed is used because, by getting to destination more quickly, more revenue earning flights can be carried out over a given period. For a given time period, 4% more flights can be carried out with only a per-mile fuel consumption increase of 1%. This means that there are 3 key speeds to remember for a jet aeroplane. The slowest is VMD (minimum drag speed), used for best endurance, such as when in the hold. Faster than this is the maximum range speed (often quoted at 1.32 x VMD, though this is an approximation), and changes with wind. Even faster than this is the LRC speed, where the fuel consumption per mile is 1% higher than maximum range, so not as efficient, but the aircraft flies around 4% faster, so can perform more flights in the day. Whilst the crew are cruising at LRC, a reduction in speed will initially decrease fuel flow, as the aircraft is flying with lower drag. Initially, the maximum range of the aircraft will increase slightly, and after a certain speed reduction, it will start to decrease. Therefore, the usefulness of reducing speed is only small (the crew may be able to squeeze around 1% extra range out of the aircraft by flying for max range), and any further reduction in speed will still reduce fuel flow for a while, until VMD is reached, when the aircraft is at its maximum endurance speed. In terms of speed stability, we usually like to operate a speed stable aircraft, where any increase in speed increases total drag, which slows the aircraft back down to the equilibrium speed (where drag = thrust). This occurs when faster than VMD. When flying slower than VMD (often called being on the back side of the drag curve), the aircraft is speed unstable, and any reduction in speed causes an increase in drag, causing a further reduction in speed. It is rare for the examiner to ask about "how speed stable" the aircraft is, they usually just ask if it is speed stable/unstable/neutral, however, it is not too difficult to understand. The steeper the gradient of the drag curve at that speed, the stronger the effect of the stability/instability. Therefore, as the aircraft slows down from LRC speed, it gets closer to VMD and the aircraft becomes a little less speed stable. Whilst the speed is higher than VMD the speed is still considered stable, but as the graph is flatter here, it is a lesser effect.

content.question: What effect does temperature have on the performance limited take-off mass?

options.A: Falling temperatures will require a lower performance limited take-off mass.
options.B: A change in temperature does not affect the performance limited take-off mass.
options.C: Rising temperatures will lower the performance limited take-off mass.
options.D: Rising temperatures will permit a higher performance limited take-off-mass.

key_points: Density altitude is pressure altitude corrected for non-standard temperature
You probably noticed that in hot days your airplane not well-performing
That's because with hot temperatures, density altitude increases and your airplane "feels" like it's flying at a higher altitude
learning.explanation: Density altitude is pressure altitude corrected for non-standard temperature. You probably noticed that in hot days your airplane not well-performing. That's because with hot temperatures, density altitude increases and your airplane "feels" like it's flying at a higher altitude. Less air mass flowing over your wings prevents you from generate as much lift, and less oxygen mass in your cylinders prevents you from burning as much fuel, meaning less power. Decreasing air density decreases performance, so be careful on hot days at high altitudes. The higher the air temperature, the less thrust can be produced by the engine. Because of that the difference between the thrust and the drag during takeoff is smaller. Therefore the rate of acceleration is smaller and the aircraft will need a longer takeoff distance. The PLTOM is the lowest of the: FLTOM Climb Limited Mass Tyre Limited Mass Obstacle Limited Mass Practically, the tyre limited mass is rarely limiting because hot, high conditions also reduce the climb limited mass. However, taking off with a tailwind in hot, high conditions could result in a tyre limiting mass and must be checked. This situation could also result in an obstacle limiting mass. If there are no significant obstacles to be cleared after take-off, either the FLTOM or climb limited mass normally limits the PLTOM. To ensure that the aeroplane completes its take-off within the field length available, and then climbs at least the minimum required gradient, the PLTOM must be the lighter of these two masses. However, the pilot has a choice of flap settings. Increasing flap setting increases the FLTOM but reduces the climb limited mass.

content.question: At some distance from the destination aerodrome, the ATC advises the crew of a jet aircraft that a holding procedure is expected, because of traffic. The recommended action taken by the crew, is to...

options.A: increase speed to reach the hold earlier.
options.B: request descent to be ahead of other traffic for arrival.
options.D: reduce cruise speed to save fuel.

key_points: In case a holding procedure is expected, the crew’s major concern is the maximum endurance and not the maximum range
Thus, during holding, it is recommended to reduce the cruise speed and maintain a holding speed equal to the VMD, maximizing that way the maximum endurance
Maximum Endurance is the maximum flight time that an aircraft can remain airborne burning the available fuel
learning.explanation: In case a holding procedure is expected, the crew’s major concern is the maximum endurance and not the maximum range. Thus, during holding, it is recommended to reduce the cruise speed and maintain a holding speed equal to the VMD, maximizing that way the maximum endurance. Maximum Endurance is the maximum flight time that an aircraft can remain airborne burning the available fuel. This depends entirely on the fuel flow, which is a product of the Specific Fuel Consumption (SFC), and Drag. SFC is the ratio of fuel mass consumed to produce a unit of thrust per unit of time. The lower the SFC, the better. The maximum (optimum) endurance will be increased, if flying at a speed where the minimum drag is produced, at VMD, where the SFC is at its lowest.

content.question: Regarding an engine failure on take-off, the net take-off flight path is:

options.A: The minimum height that will be attained by an aircraft flown in accordance with the Aircraft Flight Manual (AFM) after failure of the critical power unit and taking into account exceptional pilot skill.
options.B: The minimum height that will be attained by an aircraft flown in accordance with the Aircraft Flight Manual (AFM) after failure of the critical power unit.
options.C: The minimum height that will be attained by an aircraft flown in accordance with the Aircraft Flight Manual (AFM) after failure of the critical power unit in specific weather conditions.
options.D: The maximum height that will be attained by an aircraft flown in accordance with the Aircraft Flight Manual (AFM) after failure of the critical power unit.

key_points: The difference between the net and gross flight paths/performance is as follows: The gross performance is the average performance that a fleet of aircraft should achieve if maintained satisfactorily and flown in accordance with the techniques established during flight certification and subsequently described in the aircraft performance manual
Gross performance therefore defines a level of performance that any aircraft of the same type has a 50 percent chance of exceeding at any time
The net performance is the gross performance diminished to allow for various contingencies that cannot be accounted for operationally, e
learning.explanation: The difference between the net and gross flight paths/performance is as follows: The gross performance is the average performance that a fleet of aircraft should achieve if maintained satisfactorily and flown in accordance with the techniques established during flight certification and subsequently described in the aircraft performance manual. Gross performance therefore defines a level of performance that any aircraft of the same type has a 50 percent chance of exceeding at any time. The net performance is the gross performance diminished to allow for various contingencies that cannot be accounted for operationally, e.g., variations in piloting technique, temporarily below-average performance, etc. It is improbable that the net performancel flight path will not be achieved in operation, provided the aircraft is flown in accordance with the recommended techniques, i.e., power, attitude, and speed. Normally, performance graphs show net performance; however, some performance charts, especially for three-engined aircraft, assume gross is equal to net performance. This means that no margin exists between what the graph suggests the aircraft will achieve and what the aircraft will achieve. The net gradient refers to the minimum attainable vertical profile following failure of the critical power unit on take-off (assuming the AFM is adhered to).

metadata.topic: 25/Applicable Operational Requirements Performance Class A – Theory

content.question: When performing an increased V2 takeoff, our V1 speed will be increased. What related hazards shoud we pay most attention to?

options.A: The climb gradient is reduced, and we may not clear distant obstacles.
options.B: The new V1 may be above controllability limits.
options.C: The braking efficiency during a rejected take-off will be reduced.
options.D: The stop distance may be compromised.

key_points: Take-off with Increased V2 Speed This procedure is used when the performance limited mass is the climb limit mass
At V2 the climbing performance is poor and limits the maximum take-off mass
It is important to understand that in the event of engine failure, the initial climb out speed is V2
learning.explanation: Take-off with Increased V2 Speed This procedure is used when the performance limited mass is the climb limit mass. At V2 the climbing performance is poor and limits the maximum take-off mass. It is important to understand that in the event of engine failure, the initial climb out speed is V2. However, V2 is not the best climb angle speed. V2 is considerably slower than the best angle of climb speed, which is VX. Climbing with a speed closer to the best angle of climb will greatly enhance the climb performance. If extra runway length is available it would be possible to stay on the runway for longer during the take-off to build up more speed to a higher V1, this will ensure that at the screen height, a faster V2 will be reached, closer to VX. As a result of the improved climb performance, the climb limited mass can be increased. "The climb gradient is reduced, and we may not clear distant obstacles." Incorrect. Increased V2 procedure increases climb gradient, so obstacle clearance should be less of a problem. "The new V1 may be above controllability limits." Incorrect. Controllability limits are talking about VMCG, which is the minimum control speed on the ground, below which the rudder does not have enough airflow to fight an asymmetry if the engine fails. At higher speeds, this would not be a problem. "The braking efficiency during a rejected take-off will be reduced." Incorrect. The braking ability and efficiency will be the same. The increased V1 will mean that we are faster if we do a high speed RTO (Rejected Take-Off), so we will take further to stop, but our braking ability should be unaffected. "The stop distance may be compromised." Correct. Increasing our V1 reduces the safety margin of our ASDA (Accelerate-Stop Distance Available), and must be checked to make sure our ASDR is within our ASDA.

content.question: Which combination of circumstances or conditions would most likely lead to a tyre speed limited take-off?

key_points: TIRE SPEED LIMITED TAKE-OFF When dispatching an airplane in compliance with the certified Airplane Flight Manual, the airplane take-off speeds are designed to ensure that the lift-off speed does not exceed the tire speed rating
While rotation and lift-off speeds are generally expressed in knots indicated airspeed, the tire speed limit is the ground speed
Since tires are limited by Ground Speed, the tire limit is affected by pressure altitude, temperature and tailwinds
learning.explanation: TIRE SPEED LIMITED TAKE-OFF When dispatching an airplane in compliance with the certified Airplane Flight Manual, the airplane take-off speeds are designed to ensure that the lift-off speed does not exceed the tire speed rating. While rotation and lift-off speeds are generally expressed in knots indicated airspeed, the tire speed limit is the ground speed. Since tires are limited by Ground Speed, the tire limit is affected by pressure altitude, temperature and tailwinds. They are most likely to be limiting where the TAS is highest and where the groundspeeds are highest, at high temperatures, high pressure altitudes and with tailwinds (higher than anticipated). Dispatch at or near the airplane’s tire speed limit is most likely to occur during take-offs from airports at high altitudes on warm days, because these conditions tend to drive the ground speed at lift-off of the airplane closer to the tire speed limit.

content.question: The pilot sets the autobrake to MAX due to fear of exceeding runway distance. The pilot will…

options.B: Expect the autobrake system to apply necessary braking to stay on the runway.
options.C: Expect the autobrake system to apply maximum braking effort.
options.D: Expect the autobrake system to modulate braking pressure to maintain given rate.

key_points: While this question may be type-specific, the learning objectives offer limited room for discussion as you can read above

Automatic Braking (Autobrake) systems offer two modes of operation: Landing Mode Rejected Take-Off (RTO) Mode In Landing Mode (1, 2, 3, MAX), calibrated pressure is automatically applied to the brakes upon touchdown, regardless of pilot input
This system adjusts brake pressure to counteract aircraft drag, thrust reversers, and spoilers, maintaining the chosen deceleration level for modes 1, 2 and 3 and maximum braking for MAX
learning.explanation: While this question may be type-specific, the learning objectives offer limited room for discussion as you can read above. Automatic Braking (Autobrake) systems offer two modes of operation: Landing Mode Rejected Take-Off (RTO) Mode In Landing Mode (1, 2, 3, MAX), calibrated pressure is automatically applied to the brakes upon touchdown, regardless of pilot input. This system adjusts brake pressure to counteract aircraft drag, thrust reversers, and spoilers, maintaining the chosen deceleration level for modes 1, 2 and 3 and maximum braking for MAX. The Rejected Take-Off (RTO) setting instructs the autobrake system to apply full pressure to the wheel brakes, bringing the aircraft to a stop. Activation of RTO mode occurs when a rejected takeoff is initiated by the pilot at a groundspeed exceeding 88 knots. Note: On a Boeing 737, the 1, 2, 3, and MAX deceleration positions control the autobrake system during landing, modulating brake pressure to achieve specified deceleration rates until the aircraft comes to a complete stop. Regarding other options, the use of reverse thrust and autobrake is not mutually exclusive - Flight crews can employ reverse thrust in conjunction with autobrake for maximum deceleration. Although the autobrake system is designed to facilitate a smooth landing rollout and keep the aircraft on the runway, pilots must always conduct calculations to ensure that the aircraft does not exceed the available landing distance.

content.question: If the airworthiness documents do not specify a correction for landing on a wet runway, the landing distance must be increased by:

POL
A
learning.explanation: EASA AIR OPS Regulation (EU) No 965/2012 CAT. POL. A.225 Landing — destination and alternate aerodromes (a) The landing mass of the aeroplane determined in accordance with CAT. POL. A.105(a) shall not exceed the maximum landing mass specified for the altitude and the ambient temperature expected for the estimated time of landing at the destination aerodrome and alternate aerodrome. CAT. POL. A.230 Landing — dry runways (a) The landing mass of the aeroplane determined in accordance with CAT. POL. A.105(a) for the estimated time of landing at the destination aerodrome and at any alternate aerodrome shall allow a full stop landing from 50 ft above the threshold: for turbo-jet powered aeroplanes, within 60% of the landing distance available (LDA); and for turbo-propeller powered aeroplanes, within 70% of the LDA. (b) For steep approach operations, the operator shall use the landing distance data factored in accordance with (a), based on a screen height of less than 60 ft, but not less than 35 ft, and shall comply with CAT. POL. A.245. (c) For short landing operations, the operator shall use the landing distance data factored in accordance with (a) and shall comply with CAT. POL. A.250. (d) When determining the landing mass, the operator shall take the following into account: the altitude at the aerodrome; not more than 50% of the headwind component or not less than 150% of the tailwind component; and the runway slope in the direction of landing if greater than ± 2%. (e) For dispatching the aeroplane it shall be assumed that: the aeroplane will land on the most favourable runway, in still air; and the aeroplane will land on the runway most likely to be assigned, considering the probable wind speed and direction, the ground handling characteristics of the aeroplane and other conditions such as landing aids and terrain. (f) If the operator is unable to comply with (e)(1) for a destination aerodrome having a single runway where a landing depends upon a specified wind component, the aeroplane may be dispatched if two alternate aerodromes are designated that permit full compliance with (a) to (e). Before commencing an approach to land at the destination aerodrome, the commander shall check that a landing can be made in full compliance with (a) to (d) and CAT. POL. A.225. (g) If the operator is unable to comply with (e)(2) for the destination aerodrome, the aeroplane shall be only dispatched if an alternate aerodrome is designated that allows full compliance with (a) to (e). CAT. POL. A.235 Landing — wet and contaminated runways (a) When the appropriate weather reports and/or forecasts indicate that the runway at the estimated time of arrival may be wet, the LDA shall be at least 115% of the required landing distance, determined in accordance with CAT. POL. A.230. (b) When the appropriate weather reports and/or forecasts indicate that the runway at the estimated time of arrival may be contaminated, the LDA shall be at least the landing distance determined in accordance with (a), or at least 115% of the landing distance determined in accordance with approved contaminated landing distance data or equivalent, whichever is greater. The operator shall specify in the operations manual if equivalent landing distance data are to be applied. (c) A landing distance on a wet runway shorter than that required by (a), but not less than that required by CAT. POL. A.230(a), may be used if the AFM includes specific additional information about landing distances on wet runways. (d) A landing distance on a specially prepared contaminated runway shorter than that required by (b), but not less than that required by CAT. POL. A.230(a), may be used if the AFM includes specific additional information about landing distances on contaminated runways. (e) For (b), (c) and (d), the criteria of CAT. POL. A.230 shall be applied accordingly, except that CAT. POL. A.230(a) shall not be applied to (b) above.

content.question: A crew is planning their departure from Mykonos (Greece), expecting a take-off towards the sea, from a short field runway. Which of these is most likely to be the limiting take-off mass?

key_points: When we do our take-off performance calculations for a specific runway in specific conditions, the biggest factor (and often the figure we are trying to find) is our maximum take-off mass (MTOM)
In actual fact, there are many different MTOMs, and we have to find the most limiting, which will be the lowest of the set

This is called our MATOM (maximum allowed take-off mass), and is the most limiting of our climb limited take-off mass (CLTOM), obstacle limited take-off mass (OLTOM), field length limiting take-off mass (FLLTOM) and maximum structural take-off mass (MSTOM)
learning.explanation: When we do our take-off performance calculations for a specific runway in specific conditions, the biggest factor (and often the figure we are trying to find) is our maximum take-off mass (MTOM). In actual fact, there are many different MTOMs, and we have to find the most limiting, which will be the lowest of the set. This is called our MATOM (maximum allowed take-off mass), and is the most limiting of our climb limited take-off mass (CLTOM), obstacle limited take-off mass (OLTOM), field length limiting take-off mass (FLLTOM) and maximum structural take-off mass (MSTOM). The most limiting (smallest value) of these will be the one where our aircraft will struggle most for performance, so if we have a long runway surrounded by mountains, then we will likely be limited by the obstacle limited take-off mass, as its value will be lower than all the others. In this question, we have a short-field runway, with a take-off profile over the sea. This means that we will be very much field-length limited, but not at all obstacle limited, as there are rarely obstacles to avoid in the sea. Therefore, our FLLTOM will be the lowest (and most limiting), as a heavy aircraft would not be able to lift off the short runway in time, but would not have a problem with obstacle clearance.

content.question: What is true regarding the V2MIN speed for a dual engine turbo-jet aircraft?

options.A: It's the minimum safe take-off speed with all engines operating.
options.B: At low altitudes it's often limited by the minimum control speed.
options.C: At low altitudes it's often limited by the stall speed.
options.D: It may not be less than 1.3 x VMC.

key_points: CS 25

107 Take-off speeds (b) V2MIN, in terms of calibrated airspeed, may not be less than – (1) 1·13 VSR for – (i) Two-engined and three-engined turbo-propeller powered aeroplanes; and (ii) Turbojet powered aeroplanes without provisions for obtaining a significant reduction in the one-engineinoperative power-on stall speed; (2) 1·08 VSR for – (i) Turbo-propeller powered aeroplanes with more than three engines; and (ii) Turbojet powered aeroplanes with provisions for obtaining a significant reduction in the one-engine-inoperative power-on stall speed: and (3) 1·10 times VMC established under CS 25
learning.explanation: CS 25.107 Take-off speeds (b) V2MIN, in terms of calibrated airspeed, may not be less than – (1) 1·13 VSR for – (i) Two-engined and three-engined turbo-propeller powered aeroplanes; and (ii) Turbojet powered aeroplanes without provisions for obtaining a significant reduction in the one-engineinoperative power-on stall speed; (2) 1·08 VSR for – (i) Turbo-propeller powered aeroplanes with more than three engines; and (ii) Turbojet powered aeroplanes with provisions for obtaining a significant reduction in the one-engine-inoperative power-on stall speed: and (3) 1·10 times VMC established under CS 25.149. V2 is the minimum speed that needs to be maintained up to acceleration altitude, in the event of an engine failure after V1. The 1.1 VMC limitation is not affected by weight. However, it is affected by density altitude due to the asymmetric engine thrust – which increases with air density (low altitudes, temperatures and humidity). Based on this, VMC limit is likely a controlling factor at low density altitudes and low aircraft weights (where 1.13 VSR limit is lower).

15 One engine inoperative (dry runway)

content.question: Two aircraft of the same mass in ISA, one at M0.74 the other at M0.76, were following the same climb angle. Which one has a greater Rate Of Climb (ROC)?

key_points: The Rate of Climb (ROC) is the aircraft’s vertical speed, i
e

the height gained per unit of time, usually expressed in feet per minute (fpm) and is given by the formula: ROC = Speed x sin θ, where θ is the climb angle and equal to: sin θ = (T - D) / W = Excess Thrust / W
learning.explanation: The Rate of Climb (ROC) is the aircraft’s vertical speed, i.e. the height gained per unit of time, usually expressed in feet per minute (fpm) and is given by the formula: ROC = Speed x sin θ, where θ is the climb angle and equal to: sin θ = (T - D) / W = Excess Thrust / W. Thus, the ROC is, also, equal to: ROC = Speed x (T - D) / W. So, considering an aircraft in a steady climb, the ROC is affected by: The speed The climb angle (θ) The excess of thrust (T - D). Anything that increases the drag, such as the increase of the speed, will reduce the climb angle, because of the reduction in the excess of thrust (T - D). But, flying with a higher speed, the aircraft gains altitude at a higher rate than the climb angle decreases. Thus, the M0.76 speed will give a greater Rate of Climb.

content.question: Consider a medium jet transport aircraft taking off from a contaminated runway where the minimum control speed on the ground (VMCG) is the limiting factor. What could be used to improve the take-off performance in this scenario?

options.A: Reduced take-off thrust to lower VMCG
options.B: Reduced take-off thrust to Increase VMCG
options.C: Derated take-off thrust to increase VMCG
options.D: Derated take-off thrust to lower VMCG

key_points: A derated thrust take-off is considered to be a normal take-off and therefore can be carried out both on dry and on wet and contaminated runways, always subject to the Aircraft Flight Manual data and other operating restrictions

Because the take-off speeds are calculated at the lower thrust, the derated thrust setting is considered to be a limit and therefore full thrust or TOGA thrust cannot be selected, even in an emergency, until the hazard area for VMCG and VMCA is well passed

The primary advantage of the derated thrust take-offs, compared to flex take-offs, is that the lower rated thrust will lead to lower values of VMCG and VMCA and this fact may avoid a VMCG limited take-off, in some circumstances, leading to a greater MTOM at a lower thrust setting
learning.explanation: A derated thrust take-off is considered to be a normal take-off and therefore can be carried out both on dry and on wet and contaminated runways, always subject to the Aircraft Flight Manual data and other operating restrictions. Because the take-off speeds are calculated at the lower thrust, the derated thrust setting is considered to be a limit and therefore full thrust or TOGA thrust cannot be selected, even in an emergency, until the hazard area for VMCG and VMCA is well passed. The primary advantage of the derated thrust take-offs, compared to flex take-offs, is that the lower rated thrust will lead to lower values of VMCG and VMCA and this fact may avoid a VMCG limited take-off, in some circumstances, leading to a greater MTOM at a lower thrust setting. The requirement is that V1 must be greater than VMCG, so a lower value of VMCG may allow a higher limiting TOM, improving the take off performance. NOTE: Remember that flexible or reduced thrust take-offs are not permitted on contaminated runways and offer no VMC advantage, because it is possible and permitted to increase to TOGA thrust at any point during the take-off, so no reduction in VMCG is possible and a greater distance to V1 will result. This is why flexible thrust is not permitted when anything causes a reduction in aircraft performance (e.g. contamination) or an increase on take-off run required (e.g. increased V2).

content.question:
A two engine turbojet has to initiate a turn in the second segment of the take-off flight path. During the turn there is an obstacle that requires a net climb gradient of 2.0% in order to clear the obstacle. The bank angle during the turn is 15° and the flight manual gives a decrement for the turn of 0.5%.
Taking into account both the regulation and obstacle clearance, what will be the minimum gross gradient required before commencing the turn?

key_points: Class A Gross Gradients 1st Segment 2nd Segment 3rd Segment 4th Segment Gradient for 2 Engines > 0% > 2
learning.explanation: Class A Gross Gradients 1st Segment 2nd Segment 3rd Segment 4th Segment Gradient for 2 Engines > 0% > 2.4% > 1.2% > 1.2% Gradient for 3 Engines > 0.3% > 2.7% > 1.5% > 1.5% Gradient for 4 Engines > 0.5% > 3.0% > 1.7% > 1.7% Note: While third segment is usually flown in level flight, the available gradient must be at least equal to that required in final segment (1.2%). During the third segment the high lift devices are retracted. EU-OPS states that the climb gradient to use for the purpose of calculating obstacle clearance must be the net climb gradient. Net gradient is the gross gradient reduced by a safety factor: 0.8% for 2-engine aircraft 0.9% for 3-engine aircraft 1.0% for 4-engine aircraft Solution: Minimum climb gradient is 2%. The turning requires an additional increment of 0.5%, addition of 0.8% for the net to gross conversion. 2% + 0.5% + 0.8% = 3.3 %

This reduces the take-off distance

content.question: Performance Class A, Take-Off. The selected V1 is the balanced V1. As a consequence of this the:

options.A: All engine take-off distance is equal to the take-off distance available.
options.B: All engine take-off distance is equal to the accelerate-stop distance.
options.C: All engine take-off distance is equal to the engine failure take-off distance.
options.D: Accelerate stop distance is equal to the engine failure take-off distance.

key_points: The diagram shown is a distance vs V1 speed graph
It shows the distance of each scenario for different V1 speeds
For instance, look at the ASD line (Accelerate-Stop Distance)
learning.explanation: The diagram shown is a distance vs V1 speed graph. It shows the distance of each scenario for different V1 speeds. For instance, look at the ASD line (Accelerate-Stop Distance). It shows that, with a low speed V1, the ASD is short, and when the V1 increases, so does the accelerate-stop distance. This stands to reason, as the faster we get to before we stop, the longer our total distance is going to be. The TODN-1 and TORN-1 lines are the opposite, as they correspond to how long the take-off distance and take-off run will be in an engine failure scenario. With a lower V1, they are both long distances, as the aircraft will have to accelerate most of the way up to rotate speed on only 1 engine. As the V1 increases, they both decrease in distance. The TODN and TORN lines are fixed at a certain distance, and do not vary due to V1, as those scenarios do not change at V1 at all. The balanced V1 exists when the ASD is equal to the TODN-1, meaning that for a balanced field runway, there is one perfect V1, which allows the absolute maximum possible mass, and there are no wasted safety margins. The aircraft will use the same distance to stop as it would do to reach screen height from that exact V1 speed.

options.A: by banking as much as needed if aeroplane is more than 50 ft above runway elevation.
options.C: by banking not more than 15° between 50 ft and 400 ft above the runway elevation.
options.D: by standard turns but only after passing 1500 ft.

key_points: Obstacle Clearance In EU-OPS it states that an operator must ensure that the net take-off flight path must clear all obstacles by a vertical margin of 35 ft for Class A airplanes to 50 ft for Class B airplanes
If the airplane is unable to do so it must turn away from the obstacle and clear it by a horizontal distance of at least a horizontal distance of at least 90 m + 0
125D where D is the distance from the end of the TODA, or the end of the TOD if a turn is scheduled before the end of the TODA
learning.explanation: Obstacle Clearance In EU-OPS it states that an operator must ensure that the net take-off flight path must clear all obstacles by a vertical margin of 35 ft for Class A airplanes to 50 ft for Class B airplanes. If the airplane is unable to do so it must turn away from the obstacle and clear it by a horizontal distance of at least a horizontal distance of at least 90 m + 0.125D where D is the distance from the end of the TODA, or the end of the TOD if a turn is scheduled before the end of the TODA. For airplanes with a wingspan of less than 60 m the horizontal distance may be taken as 60 m + half the wingspan + 0.125D. Turns on the Flight Path Turns are not allowed below a height of half the wingspan or 50 ft whichever is greater. Up to 400 ft, bank angle may not be more than 15°. Above 400 ft, bank angle may not be more than 25°.

content.question: A pilot is operating a series of short-haul flights. The landing at one destination was performed at the maximum landing mass and the aircraft is only scheduled to spend a short time on the ground prior to the next departure. Brake temperature…

options.A: should NOT limit the turnaround time, because the regulated take-off mass calculation will take into account brake temperature considerations.
options.B: may limit the turnaround time for brake cooling, to ensure the brakes will have adequate capacity to absorb the energy in the event of a rejected take-off.
options.C: may limit the turnaround time, to ensure that the wheel fuse plugs will NOT melt during the subsequent taxi-out or take-off.
options.D: should NOT limit the turnaround time, because brakes are mainly used during the landing phase of a flight, and there is NO need to delay the departure.

key_points: Important Note: The current feedback from ANAC (Portugal) provides option C (fusible wheel plugs melting) as the correct answer in the exam

We believe that option B (absorbing brake energy) is far more correct, and a much more important factor, whilst option C is still a possible scenario, but very unlikely and much less dangerous than a runway excursion during a rejected take off
Nonetheless, if these two options are present in your exam, you should appeal this question on those grounds
learning.explanation: Important Note: The current feedback from ANAC (Portugal) provides option C (fusible wheel plugs melting) as the correct answer in the exam. We believe that option B (absorbing brake energy) is far more correct, and a much more important factor, whilst option C is still a possible scenario, but very unlikely and much less dangerous than a runway excursion during a rejected take off. Nonetheless, if these two options are present in your exam, you should appeal this question on those grounds. We hope that a previous appeal will remove it from the Portuguese exams at least, but we can never be sure. The Quick Turnaround weight limit is related to the heat of the aeroplane wheel brakes, which absorb the vast majority of the aeroplane's kinetic energy (as heat) during landing. These brakes are then hot (and the temperature of them depends on the weight, approach speed, wind, use of reverse thrust, autobrake setting, etc.). Hot brakes introduce 2 major problems: 1) If the aircraft attempts to take off soon after this, but has to reject the take off at or near V1, the brakes may still be hot, and not able to absorb enough energy to stop the aircraft. This occurs as "brake fade", where the extremely hot brakes stop gaining much grip between the brakes and the pads (other, more minor, issues can also occur). 2) To prevent the intense heat from the brakes over pressuring the tyres, the tyres contain "fusible plugs" that melt at a certain temperature, allowing a controlled escape of the gas, rather than an explosion. Having hot brakes could cause these to melt, but this usually happens just after extreme braking, such as a RTO (Rejected Take Off) at a heavy weight, and they do not usually melt just after landing, and very rarely during taxi and take off (unless the turnaround time has been very short indeed, and taxiing requires lots of braking) These reasons mean that we would like to get our brakes down to a suitable temperature prior to the next flight, and why pilots may sometimes have to consult the "minimum turnaround time" table/figure to find out when this will be. Other methods to help cool the brakes quicker are to place brake fans pointing at them to provide fresh air for improved cooling. Giving the above explanation, we strongly believe the brake fade (absorbing the energy of an RTO) to be the most correct answer here, but see the note above and check the comments for the current feedback on what is considered correct in the exam, as this appears to be disputed by some authorities.
