content.question: Which of the following options will be most likely to cause airframe buffet if an aircraft climbs with a constant indicated airspeed (IAS) below the tropopause?

options.A: High Angle of Attack due to the decrease in TAS.
options.B: High Mach Number due to the increase in LSS.
options.C: High Angle of Attack due to the increase in TAS.
options.D: High Mach Number due to the increase in TAS.

key_points: Effect on Mach Number of Climbing at a Constant IAS Below the tropopause, temperature decreases with increasing altitude, and therefore local speed of sound will decrease as altitude increases
It is know that if altitude is increased at constant IAS the TAS will increase due to a reduction in air density
Mach no
learning.explanation: Effect on Mach Number of Climbing at a Constant IAS Below the tropopause, temperature decreases with increasing altitude, and therefore local speed of sound will decrease as altitude increases. It is know that if altitude is increased at constant IAS the TAS will increase due to a reduction in air density. Mach no. = TAS / LSS Climbing at constant IAS, TAS will increase and therefore the Mach no. increases as well. But the Mach no. will increase at a bigger rate than TAS, because the LSS will decrease with altitude. Therefore, the Mach number will increase if altitude is increased at a constant IAS and at a certain altitude MMO (maximum operating Mach No.) may be reached, above which, buffeting may occur.

content.question:
Which of the following will affect the level-off altitude during a drift-down?
1) outside air temperature
2) wind
3) distance to alternate airport
4) engine thrust

key_points: Engine Failure and Drift Down In the case of an engine failure, the remaining thrust is not sufficient to balance the drag force and the cruise speed cannot be maintained
The only solution is to descend to a lower flight altitude, where the remaining engine can provide enough thrust to balance the drag and allow level flight

As the airplane descends into the lower atmosphere where density is greater, the remaining engine can develop more thrust which will equal the drag force, this is the GROSS level-off altitude, but would give no performance margin
learning.explanation: Engine Failure and Drift Down In the case of an engine failure, the remaining thrust is not sufficient to balance the drag force and the cruise speed cannot be maintained. The only solution is to descend to a lower flight altitude, where the remaining engine can provide enough thrust to balance the drag and allow level flight. As the airplane descends into the lower atmosphere where density is greater, the remaining engine can develop more thrust which will equal the drag force, this is the GROSS level-off altitude, but would give no performance margin. So the DRIFT DOWN PROCEDURE is continued to a lower altitude, the NET level-off altitude. The main purpose of the drift down procedure is to bring the aircraft to an altitude where the aircraft can generate enough trust with the remaining to balance the drag. The level-off altitude is determined by the actual air density.

content.question:
With regards to the difference in steel and carbon brakes on aircraft stopping, which of the following statements are correct?
1. Carbon brakes are most efficient at high temperatures; their wear is primarily determined by the number of applications.
2. In the event that, after landing, a brake temperature warning occurs, the parking brake should be set as soon as possible.

key_points: Whilst this is more of a question that belongs in AGK, we have evidence to say that it is also a question in the Performance exam
The two usual materials for aircraft brakes are steel and carbon
They vary somewhat in characteristics, and in cost
learning.explanation: Whilst this is more of a question that belongs in AGK, we have evidence to say that it is also a question in the Performance exam. The two usual materials for aircraft brakes are steel and carbon. They vary somewhat in characteristics, and in cost. Steel brakes are usually much cheaper than carbon brakes. Steel brakes perform better at lower temperatures, and when they get hot, suffer from brake fade, where the rotors do not apply as much traction onto the stators due to the intense heat. Carbon brakes, however, have a much hotter operating window. In fact, carbon brakes are not very effective at low temperatures, so need to have some heat in them already, to be able to produce the peak braking force. The wear of carbon brakes is based mainly on the number of times they are applied, meaning that a short application wears them down a similar amount to one long application. This is why the two types should be treated differently. Steel brakes should be kept cool, by using them softly with gaps to allow them to cool. Carbon brakes, on the other hand, should be applied firmly all at once when possible, to allow them to work in their operating window as much as possible. If either of these brakes overheat though, they will lose effectiveness, and should be cooled as soon as possible, particularly as they may overheat their tyres and cause the fusible plugs to melt. The parking brake should NOT be set in this scenario, as that does not allow any airflow to the brakes, which would prevent effective cooling.

content.question: Which of the following speed schedules, applicable to the same aeroplane, represents the highest cost index?

options.A: Climb: 340 kt / M 0.80, Cruise: M 0.80, Descent: M 0.80/340 kt
options.B: Climb: 296 kt / M 0.80, Cruise: M 0.80, Descent: M 0.80/288 kt
options.C: Climb: 280 kt / M 0.76, Cruise: M 0.76, Descent: M 0.76/294 kt
options.D: Climb: 255 kt / M 0.76, Cruise: M 0.76, Descent: M 0.76/245 Kt

key_points: The two major variable costs are the cost of fuel and the cost of flight time, excluding fuel
The longer the time airborne, the higher will be the scheduled maintenance, salary and leasing charges
Flying faster will save on flight time costs, but increases the fuel burn and therefore fuel cost
learning.explanation: The two major variable costs are the cost of fuel and the cost of flight time, excluding fuel. The longer the time airborne, the higher will be the scheduled maintenance, salary and leasing charges. Flying faster will save on flight time costs, but increases the fuel burn and therefore fuel cost. The factor derived from the ratio of these two costs, the aircraft operating cost divided by the fuel cost, is called Cost Index (CI) and is given by the formula: CI = Costs incurred over time / Fuel cost. "Costs incurred over time" or "time related costs" contain the sum of several components, such as hourly maintenance cost, flight crew and cabin crew cost per flight hour, the cost of ownership or aircraft rental, overtime, passenger dissatisfaction, hubbing or missed connections, etc. The CI is a number from 000 to a maximum which could, depending on type, be 100, 200, 500, 999 or even 9999. An index of 0 represents maximum range and the maximum value, whatever it is, represents minimum time. It is normal for a company route to have an attached CI. Alternatively, the CI can be manually input by the flight crew. Airlines determine this ratio using a somewhat complex formula that is presented as a number on the flight plan which the crew then sets in the FMS to control the speed. The higher the cost index the faster the speed, the greater the fuel burn and obviously the shorter the flight time. At a cost index of 000 the aircraft will be at maximum range speed (VMR). The effect of a higher cost index is to increase the speeds, thus saving flight time, but increasing the fuel consumption. The effect of a lower Cost Index is the opposite, to decrease the speeds, thus saving fuel but increasing flight time. The only flight profile that corresponds to the highest cost index is: Climb: 340 kt / M0.80, Cruise: M0.80, Descent : M0.80/340 kt, where all speeds at each phase of flight are the highest.

learning.explanation: On an approach, an aircraft should follow a particular angle of descent, often called the glidepath, as the majority of approaches around the world use an ILS, which is usually a 3º glidepath. learning.explanation: Cost Index The cost index is used to take into account the relationship between fuel-related costs and time-related costs. With time-related costs, the faster the aircraft is flown, the more money is saved in time costs. This is because the faster the aircraft is flown, the more miles can be flown for time-related components. content.question: A ‘Balanced Field Length’ is said to exist where:

options.A: the accelerate-stop distance is equal to the take-off distance.
options.B: the clearway length does not equal the stopway length.
options.C: the accelerate-stop distance available is equal to the take-off distance available.
options.D: the take-off run available is equal to the take-off distance available.

key_points: BALANCED FIELD LENGTH When the Accelerate-stop Distance Available (ASDA) is equal to the Take-off Distance Available (TODA), this is known as a Balanced Field Length
Likewise, when the ASDA and TODA are different lengths, this is known as an Unbalanced Field Length

BALANCED FIELD TAKE-OFF A balanced field take-off is performance based and is a condition where the Accelerate-stop Distance Required (ASDR) is equal to the Take-off Distance Required (TODR) for the aircraft weight, engine thrust, aircraft configuration and runway condition
learning.explanation: BALANCED FIELD LENGTH When the Accelerate-stop Distance Available (ASDA) is equal to the Take-off Distance Available (TODA), this is known as a Balanced Field Length. Likewise, when the ASDA and TODA are different lengths, this is known as an Unbalanced Field Length. BALANCED FIELD TAKE-OFF A balanced field take-off is performance based and is a condition where the Accelerate-stop Distance Required (ASDR) is equal to the Take-off Distance Required (TODR) for the aircraft weight, engine thrust, aircraft configuration and runway condition. The balanced field length is the shortest field length at which a balanced field take-off can be performed. A Balanced field length is used to simplify the field-length take-off mass. When applying this concept, TOD = ASD and V1 = V1 Balanced. And this means that we are using the minimum requirements in case of engine failure, thus increasing safety margins. When using stopway or clearway, extra distance will be available and V1 will vary. BALANCED V1 The first graph on the attached figure, helps understanding the impact of increasing or decreasing V1. Analyzing it, we can conclude the following: A Balanced V1 is a V1 speed which results in TODR equal to ASDR. Often called the “Ideal V1” as it gives the minimum field length required for a given weight and optimum performance. Any lower V1 (V1 < V1B) would increase TODR, as it would take longer for the aircraft to accelerate to V2 with OEI. As a result, the total field required increases. Any higher V1 (V1 > V1B) would increase ASDR due to a higher energy absorption by the brakes. As a result, the total field required would also increase. => In essence, Balanced V1 improves field length limited take-off performance. => Unbalanced V1 allows for higher take-off weights by taking advantage of any runway and clearway or stopway available in excess of balanced field length. Summary and extra info: If TOD = ASD, V1 = BALANCED, Balanced condition. If TOD > ASD, V1 < V1 BALANCED, Unbalanced condition. Clearway, no stopway = higher mass and lower V1 speed If TOD < ASD, V1 > V1 BALANCED, Unbalanced condition. Stopway, no clearway = higher mass and higher V1 speed. TORA (Take-Off Run Distance Available) => RUNWAY only (no STOPWAY or CLEARWAY) TODA (Take-Off Distance Available) => TORA + CLEARWAY ASDA (Accelarate-Stop Distance Available) => TORA + STOPWAY

content.question: A jet aeroplane is flying just below its maximum operating altitude. If the aircraft begins to descend at a constant mach number with no changes to its mass, CG or configuration...

options.A: the low-speed buffet margin will increase because stall speed decreases with reducing altitude.
options.B: the low-speed buffet margin will decrease because the critical Mach number decreases with reducing altitude.
options.C: its high-speed buffet margin will increase because stall speed decreases with reducing altitude.
options.D: its high-speed buffet margin will decrease because the critical Mach number decreases with reducing altitude.

key_points: An aircraft's buffet margin is how far away its speed is to the buffet speed at that moment
An aircraft's low speed buffet margin is how many knots away from low speed buffet it is, and its high speed buffet margin is how many knots away from high speed buffet it is
At high altitude, the buffet margins on either side are the lowest, in a place called "coffin corner", where only a few knots seperate an aircraft's high speed and low speed buffet boundaries
learning.explanation: An aircraft's buffet margin is how far away its speed is to the buffet speed at that moment. An aircraft's low speed buffet margin is how many knots away from low speed buffet it is, and its high speed buffet margin is how many knots away from high speed buffet it is. At high altitude, the buffet margins on either side are the lowest, in a place called "coffin corner", where only a few knots seperate an aircraft's high speed and low speed buffet boundaries. The aircraft must fly within this speed range, and the aircraft may come close to stall (low speed stall or shock stall) if it goes outside the range. An aircraft descending at a constant mach number will stay a fixed margin away from its high-speed buffet boundary, which is a fixed Mach number. The low speed buffet boundary, however, will decrease at high altitude, as the compressibility effects reduce with decreasing altitude. This means that our margin to the buffet boundary (our low speed buffet margin) increases in the descent. The ECTM graph above also shows that our IAS/CAS increases in a descent with constant Mach number, so that brings an even greater increase in our low speed buffet margin (however this is not mentioned in the correct answer).

A dry runway is one which is neither wet nor contaminated, and includes those paved runways which have been specially prepared with grooves or porous pavement and maintained to retain "effectively dry" braking action even when moisture is present. 3) When both main gears are on the ground and provided that the nose gear can be lowered in a controlled manner permitting it to touch down safely.
4) When all wheels are on the ground.

content.question: The type of hydroplaning that is most likely to occur at the touchdown area located at both ends of the runway is called...

key_points: Hydroplaning is caused by a thin layer of standing water that separates the tires from the runway
It causes substantial reduction in friction between the airplane tires and the runway surface and results in poor or nil braking action at high speeds
High aircraft speed, standing water, slush, and a smooth runway texture are factors conductive to hydroplaning
learning.explanation: Hydroplaning is caused by a thin layer of standing water that separates the tires from the runway. It causes substantial reduction in friction between the airplane tires and the runway surface and results in poor or nil braking action at high speeds. High aircraft speed, standing water, slush, and a smooth runway texture are factors conductive to hydroplaning. Dynamic hydroplaning occurs when there is standing water or slush on the runway deeper than the tread depth of the tyres. A wedge of water builds up, lifting the tires away from the runway surface. The speed of the airplane, the depth of the water, and the air pressure in the tires are some of the factors that affect dynamic hydroplaning. Viscous hydroplaning can occur when oil or accumulated rubber combines with water on a runway, it forms an impenetrable layer of liquid your tires can’t break through. This is especially problematic on smooth runways, and it can occur on just a thin film of water. Viscous hydroplaning typically occurs in the touchdown zone of the runway, where you get a build-up of black rubber deposit. Reverted rubber hydroplaning is the result of a prolonged locked-wheel skid, in which reverted rubber acts as a seal between the tire and the runway. Entrapped water is heated to form steam, which supports the tire off the pavement.

key_points: Segments of the Take-off Climb For a class A aircraft, one engine inoperative, the T/O climb is divided into 4 segments: The take-off flight path starts once the take-off is complete, at 35 ft with the airplane at V2 with one engine inoperative
On a wet runway, the screen height is reduced to 15'
1st segment: The aircraft accelerates from lift off speed to V2
learning.explanation: Segments of the Take-off Climb For a class A aircraft, one engine inoperative, the T/O climb is divided into 4 segments: The take-off flight path starts once the take-off is complete, at 35 ft with the airplane at V2 with one engine inoperative. On a wet runway, the screen height is reduced to 15'. 1st segment: The aircraft accelerates from lift off speed to V2. Engines are at take-off thrust and the flaps/slats are in the take-off configuration. This segment ends when the gear is retracted. 2nd segment: Starts with the gear up. Engines are still at take-off thrust and V2 is maintained. This segment ends at the higher of 400 ft. 3rd segment: Begins at 400 ft or higher specified acceleration altitude. Engines are at takeoff thrust and the aircraft is accelerated in level flight. Slats/flaps are retracted on speed. The segment ends when aircraft is in clean configuration and the final take-off speed has been achieved. Once this has happened, thrust can be reduced from maximum take-off thrust, TOGA, to maximum continuous thrust, MCT. 4th segment: Starts when the flaps are retracted, the final segment speed is achieved, and the thrust is set to maximum continuous thrust. From this point the airplane is climbed to above 1500 ft where the take-off flight path ends. 1º Segment 2º Segment 3º Segment 4º Segment Starts 35 ft Gear Up > 400 ft AGL Flaps Up VFTO MCT Action Select Gear Up Climb to > 400 ft AGL Retract Flaps Accelerate to VFTO Set MCT Climb to 1500 ft AGL
